title: Rethinking Minor Literature and Small Literature as Secondary Zone Literature
abstract: The aim of this article is to argue that both “minor literature” and “small literature” should be readdressed as Michel Ragon’s “secondary zone literature” from three perspectives. Firstly, it will be argued that “minor and small literature” began to lose its theoretical capacity with the advent of globalization after the new millennium. Secondly, the problems of “minor literature” and “small literature” will be updated. “Minor literature” mainly has two problems: 1)  The first feature of “minor literature” runs the risk of not only dismissing all literature written by minorities in “minor languages”, but also diminishing the possible meanings of the term, “minority”; and 2) The second and third characteristics of “minor literature” are unable to explain why only non-European arts are perceived to be political and collective. “Small literature” also has two problems: a) it fails to explain why countries that hardly qualify as ‘small’, face problems similar to those of “small literature” in the international literary context; and b) it does not have the capacity to explain the literature of minority and marginal groups within a nation or country. Thirdly, “minor and small literature” will be reconsidered as “secondary zone literature”, not only in an attempt to emphasize cultural dynamics and power relations based on the visibility of various “minor & small” related literary works, but also to demonstrate that literature may be minor or small, but it always has quantitative implications
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, Comparative Literature, Literary Theory
summary: This article argues for readdressing "minor literature" and "small literature" as Michel Ragon's "secondary zone literature." It posits that these concepts lost theoretical capacity post-globalization, and updates their inherent problems. "Minor literature" risks dismissing minority writings and fails to explain the perceived political nature of non-European arts. "Small literature" struggles to account for similar issues in non-'small' countries and cannot explain literature of marginal groups within nations. The proposed "secondary zone literature" framework emphasizes cultural dynamics, power relations, and the quantitative implications of literary works.

title: Literature
summary: This text explores a personal and emotional engagement with literature, specifically referencing a work that, despite not winning awards, holds a certain immortality through its inclusion in college syllabi. The author describes encountering 'smudges' on the pages, transforming the modern text into something ancient, and contrasts this with a child's innocent perspective that "it's just a book." The narrative culminates in a poignant moment of shared sorrow within the literary context, evoking themes of enduring narratives, the weight of academic expectation, and the human connection to stories.

title: A Literature Review of Complementary and Alternative Medicine Used Among Diabetes Mellitus Patients
abstract: Diabetes is a chronic disease that requires regular and sustainable health management that involves proper treatment. Some diabetic patients use CAM, as well as conventional medicine, to maintain their health and control their blood sugar. This literature review aimed to 1) determine the prevalence of CAM used by patients with diabetes, summarize and evaluate the CAM use that includes: characteristics, patterns, types and reasons, 2) propose a conceptual model associated with CAM used by patients with diabetes. Systematic reviews were searched using an electronic database. The systematic reviews were published between 2005 and 2015 by using specific keywords. The number of systematic reviews obtained as a search result is 14 articles from 14 countries. The prevalence of CAM used by patients with diabetes ranged from 16.6% to 76%. Determinants associated with the CAM use were age, gender, family income, occupation, residence, and the characteristics of the disease, such as the length of time since diagnosed and complications. Most patients used CAM, along with the conventional treatment, and did not inform health professionals about the CAM use. The CAM use by patients with diabetes was relatively high and the confidence of patients believed the benefits of CAM. Therefore, integration with health professionals to develop CAM management is highly required
fieldOfStudy: Public Health Science, Diabetes, Complementary and Alternative Medicine
summary: This literature review determined the prevalence (16.6% to 76%) and characteristics of complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) use among diabetic patients, aiming to propose a conceptual model. Analyzing 14 systematic reviews published between 2005 and 2015, findings revealed that age, gender, income, occupation, residence, disease duration, and complications influenced CAM adoption. Most patients combined CAM with conventional treatment without informing health professionals, driven by perceived benefits. The review highlights a high prevalence of CAM use in diabetes management and suggests a need for integrating CAM management with health professionals to improve patient care.

title: Making meaning and meaning making: memory, postmemory and narrative in Holocaust literature
abstract: This paper explores links between narration and memory in Holocaust literature and examines ways in which individuals construct memory and postmemory. Based on the premise that ‘All authors mediate reality through their writing...’ and taking into consideration that what we remember and how we remember is likely to have a significant impact on the narratives that we construct, this article considers the reliability of memory. It argues that whilst there is, at times, a blurring of boundaries between fact and fiction in Holocaust literature, this has little or no impact on the validity and authenticity of the narratives. In an attempt to address these issues more fully, this paper explores the notions of making meaning and meaning making, whilst considering the effects of positionality, time and trauma on memory. Key texts referred to in this discussion include Night (1958) by Elie Wiesel, All Rivers Run to the Sea (1996) by Elie Wiesel, In My Brother’s Shadow (2005) by Uwe Timm and The Dark Room (2001) by Rachel Seiffert. These texts have been chosen in order to highlight the subjectivity of memory and postmemory and to demonstrate the role that narrative plays in their construction and representation
summary: This paper investigates the intricate relationship between narration and memory within Holocaust literature, exploring how individuals construct personal and post-generational memories. It argues that while Holocaust narratives sometimes blur fact and fiction, this does not diminish their validity or authenticity. The discussion delves into meaning-making, considering the impact of positionality, time, and trauma on memory. Key texts analyzed include Elie Wiesel's "Night" and "All Rivers Run to the Sea," Uwe Timm's "In My Brother’s Shadow," and Rachel Seiffert's "The Dark Room," chosen to exemplify memory's subjectivity and narrative's role in its construction and representation.

title: Theology in Literature
fieldOfStudy: English, Christian Education, Theology in Literature
summary: This text reviews Sara Covin Juengst's "Equipping The Saints: Teacher Training in the Church," which addresses the critical need for effective teacher preparation within Christian denominations. Juengst, an ordained minister and educator, proposes a tested year-long training process designed to equip individuals called to teach. The book emphasizes Christian education's purpose beyond mere instruction, focusing on "traditioning"—passing on the faith community's meaning to future generations, illuminating lives, and fostering spiritual development. The reviewer commends Juengst's program as a commendable plan of action for qualitative and effective teacher training, vital for mainline Protestantism's future.

title: Children\u27s Literature
summary: This chapter examines how the American Civil War profoundly influenced children's literature, adapting existing forms and adding new moral and patriotic values to canonical strictures. Authors and publishers utilized books and magazines to help children understand the war's causes and progression, providing guidance for their responses. Prior to the war, children's literature emphasized self-improvement like temperance and piety, often focusing on racial differences rather than slavery's injustices. The post-war motto "Fighting Against Wrong, and for the Good, the True, and the Beautiful" from *The Little Corporal* exemplifies the blend of moral and patriotic urgency in children's writing. This analysis explores the evolution of themes and their impact on young readers during this turbulent period. Keywords: Children's Literature, Civil War, American Literature, Moral Education, Patriotism, Nineteenth Century.

title: Forum: Literature and Language Awareness: Using Literature to Achieve CEFR Outcomes
abstract: This article sets out to explore why literature (used in this article to mean poetry, plays, short stories or novels) is often a marginalised resource in EFL classrooms, even though the Common European Framework of References for Languages (CEFR) suggests it should have a role in the classroom. It first reports on the results of a questionnaire investigating English teachers’ attitudes towards using literature in the classroom. After a discussion of these results, it explores some ways in which the use of literature can be linked to CEFR outcomes in a practical teaching framework which teachers can apply to literature they choose to teach
summary: This article investigates why literature is often a marginalized resource in English as a Foreign Language (EFL) classrooms, despite its recommended role by the Common European Framework of References for Languages (CEFR). It presents findings from a questionnaire on English teachers' attitudes towards using literature. The authors discuss these results and propose practical ways to link literature use with CEFR outcomes, offering a teaching framework applicable to various literary choices. Keywords include literature, language teaching, language awareness, and CEFR.

title: Literature And Poetry
summary: This prose poem, a translation from Max Jacob's "Le cornet à dés," describes a walk near Lorient where the sea rises to cover the landscape, leading to a contemplative moment. A child in a sailor suit, saddened by the scene, shares a peculiar observation about the many small, solitary streets of Naples. The narrative explores themes of perception, imagination, and the nature of poetry, as the child's father dismisses his "lie" while the narrator identifies him as a poet, contrasting reality with imaginative experience and the power of poetic expression.

title: Poetry, resistance, world-literature : Adília Lopes and Marie Buck
abstract: This essay begins an exploration of how poetry functions within the field of world-literature, drawing specifically on the Warwick Research Collective’s Combined and Uneven Development: Towards a New Theory of World-Literature and reflecting comparatively on the poetry of Adília Lopes and Marie Buck. Even though there are many differences between the two authors and their works, one common feature of their poetics is the deployment of poetry as a form of resistance. As such, both can be seen as especially significant so as to probe into the condition of poetry within a conceptualization of world-literature understood as the literature of the capitalist world-system. As the essay argues, both Adília Lopes and Marie Buck register specific conditions of oppression within a capitalist, patriarchal, society and offer ways to contest them
summary:
This essay explores the function of poetry within world-literature, utilizing the Warwick Research Collective

s Combined and Uneven Development: Towards a New Theory of World-Literature. It comparatively analyzes the poetry of Ad


ília Lopes and Marie Buck, highlighting their shared deployment of poetry as a form of resistance against oppression in a capitalist, patriarchal society. The study positions their work as significant for understanding poetry's role within a world-literature framework conceptualized as the literature of the capitalist world-system. Key themes include poetry, resistance, world-literature, capitalism, and patriarchy.

title: A Wikipedia Literature Review
abstract:
This paper was originally designed as a literature review for a doctoral
dissertation focusing on Wikipedia. This exposition gives the structure of
Wikipedia and the latest trends in Wikipedia research
fieldOfStudy: Literature Review, Information Science, Computer Science
summary: This literature review, originally for a doctoral dissertation, outlines the structure and recent research trends concerning Wikipedia. It highlights Wikipedia's evolution into a complex and relevant dataset, emphasizing its robustness due to permanent edit storage. The paper notes the challenges of analyzing its massive, unstructured data, necessitating probabilistic and statistical inference approaches. Key areas covered include Wikipedia's system architecture, user communication, quality assurance, data integrity, and the need for scalable computational methods for its 368 million edits.

title: Abstracts of Current Literature
abstract: Material appearing in this column is thought to be of particular interest to the Catholic physician because of its moral, religious, or philosophic content. The medical literature constitutes the primary but not the sole source of such material. In general, abstracts are intended to reflect the substance of the original article. Parenthetical editorial comment may follow the abstract if considered desirable. Books are reviewed rather than summarized. Contributions and comments from readers are invited
summary: This compilation, intended for Catholic physicians, summarizes current literature on moral, religious, or philosophical aspects of medicine. It discusses ethical dilemmas in scientific research, including genetics, in vitro fertilization, and abortion, advocating for freedom of inquiry balanced against "real and present danger." It also covers the ethics of clinical trials, emphasizing the importance of true placebo control groups for valid data. Furthermore, it addresses medicolegal issues arising from prenatal genetic diagnosis, such as genetic counseling, carrier detection, and the rights of patients, fetuses, physicians, and society, urging proactive legal reform.

title: Interdisciplinary Thematic Literature Studies
summary: This article, "Interdisciplinary Thematic Literature Studies," by J. Lea Smith and Holly Johnson, explores the benefits of engaging young people in literature through interdisciplinary thematic studies. The authors advocate for creating immersive reading experiences for students, similar to the pleasure many adults find in books. The text highlights the potential for classroom teachers to leverage thematic literature studies to make reading an engaging adventure for students, fostering deeper connections with texts. Key concepts include thematic literature, interdisciplinary studies, reading engagement, and educational methods.

title: Song Literature III Recital
abstract: This is the concert program of the Song Literature III Recital on Tuesday, December 7, 1999 at 6:30 p.m., at the Marshall Room, 855 Commonwealth Avenue. Works performed were Clair de lune by Gabriel Faure, Les Berceaux by Gabriel Faure, Le Charme by Ernest Chausson, Nuits d'etoiles by Claude Debussy, Beau Soir by Claude Debussy, "Il pleure dans mon coeur" from Ariettes Oubliees by Claude Debussy, "Fantoches" from Fetes Galantes I by Claude Debussy, Soupir by Henri Duparc, Le Manoir de Rosemonde by Henri Duparc, Chanson Trist by Henri Duparc, "Psaume XXXIV" from Trois Psaumes by Arthur Honegger, "Berceuse" from Chants Populaire Hebraiques by Darius Milhaud, "Le Dromadaire" and "La Sauterelle" from Le Bestiaire by Francis Poulenc, "La Dame d'Andre" from Fiancailles pour Rire by Francis Poulenc, and "Violin" from Fiancailles pour Rire by Francis Poulenc. Digitization for Boston University Concert Programs was supported by the Boston University Humanities Library Endowed Fund
summary: This concert program details the Song Literature III Recital held at Boston University on December 7, 1999, featuring 19th-century French songs. The recital showcased works by prominent composers such as Gabriel Fauré, Ernest Chausson, Claude Debussy, Henri Duparc, Arthur Honegger, Darius Milhaud, and Francis Poulenc. Various vocalists performed pieces including "Clair de lune," "Les Berceaux," "Le Charme," "Nuits d'etoiles," and selections from "Ariettes Oubliees," "Fetes Galantes I," "Trois Psaumes," "Chants Populaire Hebraiques," "Le Bestiaire," and "Fiancailles pour Rire." The program highlights a significant event in song literature performance and study.

title: Abstracts of Current Literature
abstract: Material appearing below is thought to be of particular interest to Linacre Quarterly readers because of its moral, religious, or philosophic content. The medical literature constitutes the primary but not the sole source of such material. In general, abstracts\u27 are intended to reflect the substance of the original article. Contributions and comments from readers are invited. (E. C. Laforet, M.D. , 2000 Washington St. , Newton Lower Falls, MA. 02162.
fieldOfStudy: English, Ethics and Political Philosophy, Medicine and Health Sciences
summary: This collection presents abstracts of current literature relevant to moral, religious, or philosophic content, primarily from medical sources, for Linacre Quarterly readers. It reviews various books and articles touching on topics such as amphetamine use and abuse, women in medicine, women healers, and critical ethical discussions within medical research. Key themes include the ethics of medical education, the social dynamics of abortion, and the non-neutrality of hypothesis formulation in scientific endeavor. The compilation invites reader contributions and comments on these thought-provoking subjects, highlighting the intersection of medicine, ethics, and philosophy.

title: The Poetics of Good Literature
summary: This paper explores the characteristics that define "good" or "beautiful" literature, examining how human worldviews determine stances on beauty, art, and God, and subsequently influence judgments of cultural works. It expands on attributes of good literature, explaining how these aspects inform both Christian and secular audiences about how literature's goodness, through form and content, points toward God and ultimate reality. The research claims that good literature consistently influences through the sublime, impacts personal narrative, and imitates reality, functioning on both physical and spiritual levels to communicate truth. This reveals the fundamental relationship between art, beauty, and God, showcasing God's presence even in secular literature.

title: International student mobility literature review
abstract:
To bring their understanding of patterns in students' study and work abroad up to date, HEFCE and the British Council, the UK National Agency for Erasmus, commissioned a review of international student mobility. Professor Russell King and Jill Ahrens of the University of Sussex, and Professor Allan Findlay of the University of Dundee undertook the review which includes new evidence from interviews with staff in higher education institutions (HEIs). A group of several UK stakeholders in international student mobility, including the organisations BUTEX (British Universities Transatlantic Exchange) and HEURO (the Association of UK Higher Education European Officers), and the Department for Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) oversaw the work.



The report brings together recent literature and data on student mobility. It looks at the trends in UK international students' mobility and compares these internationally. It also considers the causal factors for students' choice to spend time abroad, the socio-economic and demographic characteristics of mobile students, and the impact that time abroad has on their employability; and it highlights policy and practice in HEIs in respect of student mobility
fieldOfStudy: English, International Student Mobility, Higher Education, Literature Review
summary: This literature review, commissioned by HEFCE and the British Council, updates understanding of international student mobility. Conducted by Professors Russell King, Allan Findlay, and Jill Ahrens, the study incorporates new evidence from higher education institutions. It analyzes trends in UK and international student mobility, investigating causal factors for studying abroad, socio-economic characteristics of mobile students, and the impact on employability. The report also highlights policy and practice within HEIs regarding student mobility, offering insights for international education and higher education policy.

title: Galapagos literature - fact and fantasy
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, Literary History, Galapagos Islands, Travel Writing
summary: This text explores the extensive and varied literature inspired by the Galapagos Islands, encompassing both scientific works and fiction. It traces the origins of Galapagos literature from 17th-century buccaneer accounts, which influenced works like Daniel Defoe's "Robinson Crusoe," to a later vogue for desert island narratives. The author discusses how the islands' isolation and connection to Darwinian evolution have attracted both scientists and novelists, highlighting figures such as Alexander Selkirk and Señora de Rendon, who depicted the unique environment and early human interactions before significant changes brought by conservation efforts. The article emphasizes the importance of fictional accounts for a complete understanding of the Galapagos.

title: Swiss-German Literature 1945-2000
fieldOfStudy: English Language and Literature, Swiss-German Literature
summary: This article examines the complex landscape of Swiss literature from 1945 to 2000, emphasizing its four distinct language regions: German, French, Italian, and Rhaeto-Romansh. The paper highlights that these literatures share little commonality, with authors often influenced by their larger neighboring countries. It traces key developments in Swiss-German literature through different epochs, from post-war existentialism and protest literature to postmodernism and the emergence of new talents in the late 20th century, discussing authors like Friedrich Dürrenmatt, Max Frisch, and recent writers such as Peter Stamm. The study provides an overview of influential works and literary trends.

title: Current Literature: Abstracts and Titles
abstract: Material appearing in this column is thought to be of particular interest to the Catholic physician because of its moral, religious, or philosophic content. The medical literature constitutes the primary but not the sole source of such material. In general, abstracts are intended to reflect the substance of the original article. Parenthetical editorial comment may follow the abstract if considered desirable. Books are reviewed rather than summarized. Contributions and comments from readers are invited
fieldOfStudy: Medical Ethics, Bioethics, Catholic Theology, Medical Literature
summary: This document, "Current Literature: Abstracts and Titles," from The Linacre Quarterly (1975), outlines the purpose and scope of a column dedicated to material of particular interest to Catholic physicians, focusing on moral, religious, or philosophic content within medical literature. It explains that abstracts reflect the original article's substance, while books are reviewed. The section invites contributions and comments from readers and announces Dr. Eugene Laforet as its new conductor, highlighting his expertise in medical ethics. The compilation also includes an author index for Volume 42, 1975, listing various articles and book reviews relevant to medical ethics and patient care.

title: Expression in music and literature
abstract: Thesis (M.A.)--Boston Universit
fieldOfStudy: English, Music, Literature, Art History, Aesthetics
summary: This thesis, submitted by Marion Susan Reynolds in 1912, explores the concept of "expression" within music and literature. It defines expression, examines art as a medium for ideas, and distinguishes between thought and emotion in both disciplines. The study posits music as the primary art form for expressing emotions due to its direct appeal to the human spirit, exemplified by folk songs and musical motives that create melody and harmony. It also analyzes the emotional element in literature, illustrated by lyric poetry and Greek literary forms, and the thought element in music, as seen in pastoral symphonies. The work concludes that the mission of art is to "sweeten, mellow and strengthen us."

title: The Sabah Oral Literature Project
abstract: George N. Appell, M.B.A., A.M. (Harvard), Ph.D. (Australian National University) is a social anthropologist. He has done fieldwork, assisted by his wife Laura W.R. Appell, among the Dogrib Indians of the Northwest Territories of Canada, the Rungus of Sabah, Malaysia, and the Bulusu’ of Indonesian Borneo. They began working with the Rungus in 1959 to record their social organization, language, religion and cultural ecology. They continue to work with the Rungus and are compiling ‘The Rungus Cultural Dictionary’ as well as managing the Sabah Oral Literature Project. This project continues to collect the oral literature of the Rungus and other peoples of the Kudat Peninsula. Dr Appell is cofounder and president of the Borneo Research Council, founder and president of the Firebird Foundation for Anthropological Research, founder of the Anthropologists’ Fund for Urgent Anthropological Research, and is Senior Visiting Scholar in the Department of Anthropology, Brandeis University. He is currently finishing a monograph on culture-free methods to determine rights over resource tenure and other property interests that are faithful to the local distinctions. Other information on the publications of the Appells can be found at: www.gnappell.orgGeorge and Laura Appell were prevented by the Sabah government from continuing their research among the Rungus, which had begun in 1959-1963. But in 1986 they were permitted to return to the Rungus and visit their friends. By then little of the traditional Rungus social organization and culture remained unchanged, except for their oral literature. Consequently, George and Laura Appell formed the Sabah Oral Literature Project to collect the various genre from the Rungus and related ethnic groups. The project was so constructed as to be run by the Rungus for the Rungus, with the Appells providing equipment, direction and training. It was hoped that this project would form a model for ethnic groups in other areas of Sabah and in other regions of the world to begin collecting their own oral literature. This article covers the various genre of Rungus oral literature from the extensive religious poems performed by priestesses to cure illness and promote fertility, to the prayers for the rice spirits, to historical narratives, songs, and word play. It discusses the selection of personnel to collect texts, their training, the equipment used, the payment of performers, the transcription of texts, the archiving of the recordings and problems in translating the texts. Translation and exegesis requires a detailed knowledge of the culture, which may necessitate study and analysis by scholars outside the society.World Oral Literature Project and the Firebird Foundation for Anthropological Research
summary: This article details the Sabah Oral Literature Project, initiated by George and Laura Appell, to collect and preserve the endangered oral literature of the Rungus people and related ethnic groups in Borneo, Malaysia. Due to restrictions on their previous research, the Appells shifted focus to oral traditions, forming a project designed to be run by the Rungus themselves. The paper outlines various genres of Rungus oral literature, including religious poems, prayers, historical narratives, and songs, and discusses the methodologies for personnel selection, training, equipment, performer payment, transcription, archiving, and translation challenges.

title: Current Literature: Titles and Abstracts
abstract: The purpose of this department in The Linacre Quarterly is to make available by titular listing such current articles as are thought to be of particular interest to the Catholic physician by virtue of their medical literature although, of necessity, this source is the most fruitful. When abstracts appear, they are intended to reflect the content of the original article. Parenthetical editorial comment may follow the abstract if considered desirable. Contributions from readers are invited
fieldOfStudy: Medicine and Health Sciences, Ethics and Political Philosophy
summary: This article from The Linacre Quarterly, Volume 27, Number 1 (1960), highlights current literature relevant to Catholic physicians, including titles and abstracts. It also documents significant events within Catholic Physicians' Guilds, such as the bestowing of honorary membership on 82 nun-physicians in 1959 and the presentation of the 1959 Catholic Physician of the Year Award to Dr. John J. Masterson. The text details Dr. Masterson's distinguished career, his contributions to medicine, his leadership roles, and his commitment to Catholic Action. Key themes include medical ethics, professional recognition, and the intersection of faith and medicine.

title: Reading Videogames as (authorless) Literature
abstract: This article presents the outcomes of research, funded by the Arts and Humanities Research Council in England and informed by work in the fields of new literacy research, gaming studies and the socio-cultural framing of education, for which the videogame L.A. Noire (Rockstar Games, 2011) was studied within the orthodox framing of the English Literature curriculum at A Level (pre-University) and Undergraduate (degree level). There is a plethora of published research into the kinds of literacy practices evident in videogame play, virtual world engagement and related forms of digital reading and writing (Gee, 2003; Juul, 2005; Merchant, Gillen, Marsh and Davies, 2012; Apperley and Walsh, 2012; Bazalgette and Buckingham, 2012) as well as the implications of such for home / school learning (Dowdall, 2006; Jenkins, 2006; Potter, 2012) and for teachers’ own digital lives (Graham, 2012). Such studies have tended to focus on younger children and this research is also distinct from such work in the field in its exploration of the potential for certain kinds of videogame to be understood as 'digital transformations' of conventional ‘schooled’ literature. The outcomes of this project raise implications of such a conception for a further implementation of a ‘reframed’ literacy (Marsh, 2007) within the contemporary curriculum of a traditional and conservative ‘subject’. A mixed methods approach was adopted. Firstly, students contributing to a gamplay blog requiring them to discuss their in-game experience through the ‘language game’ of English Literature, culminating in answering a question constructed with the idioms of the subject’s set text ‘final examination’. Secondly, students taught their teachers to play L.A. Noire, with free choice over the context for this collaboration. Thirdly, participants returned to traditional roles in order to work through a set of study materials provided, designed to reproduce the conventions of the ‘study guide’ for literature education. Interviews were conducted after each phase and the outcomes informed a redrafting of the study materials which are now available online for teachers – this being the ‘practical’ outcome of the research (Berger and McDougall, 2012). In the act of inserting the study of L.A. Noire into the English Literature curriculum as currently framed, this research moves, through a practical ‘implementation’ beyond longstanding debates around narratology and ludology (Frasca, 2003; Juul, 2005) in the field of game studies (Leaning, 2012) through a direct connection to new literacy studies and raises epistemological questions about ‘subject identity’, informed by Bernstein (1996) and Bourdieu (1986) and the implications for digital transformations of texts for both ideas about cultural value in schooled literacy (Kendall and McDougall, 2011) and the politics of ‘expertise’ in pedagogic relations (Ranciere, 2009, Bennett, Kendall and McDougall, 2012a)
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, New Literacy Studies, Gaming Studies
summary: This research explores the integration of the videogame L.A. Noire into the English Literature curriculum at A-level and undergraduate levels, informed by new literacy research and gaming studies. Using a mixed-methods approach, students engaged in a gameplay blog, taught teachers to play the game, and worked through traditional study materials. The study aims to understand videogames as 'digital transformations' of conventional literature, addressing implications for 'reframed' literacy and raising epistemological questions about 'subject identity' and cultural value in schooled literacy, moving beyond narratology and ludology debates in game studies.

title: A survey of Egyptian literature
abstract: Thesis (M.A.)--Boston Universit
summary: This thesis surveys Egyptian literature, focusing on its historical understanding and development. For centuries, knowledge was limited to unreliable ancient accounts; only with archaeological work and scholarly attention to original sources did Egypt's significance become clear. The Egyptians, though exclusive, influenced Hebrews, Phoenicians, and Greeks. While lacking artistic literary style and rhetorical development compared to the Greeks, Egyptian literature offers a fascinating study of a prolonged, isolated literary evolution in its primitive form, with its simplicity sometimes forming its main appeal. Keywords: Egyptian literature, ancient civilization, archaeology, literary development, rhetoric.

title: Beardsley on literature, fiction, and nonfiction
abstract: This paper attempts to revive interest in the speech act theory of literature by looking into Monroe C. Beardsley's account in particular. Beardsley's view in this respect has received, surprisingly, less attention than deserved. I first offer a reconstruction of Beardsley's account and then use it to correct some notable misconceptions. Next, I show that the reformulation reveals a hitherto unnoticed discrepancy in Beardsley's position and that this can be explained away by a weak version of intentionalism that Beardsley himself actually tolerates. Finally, I assess the real difficulty of Beardsley's theory and its relevance today
summary: This paper aims to reignite interest in Monroe C. Beardsley's speech act theory of literature, which has been underexplored. The author reconstructs Beardsley's account, addressing misconceptions, and reveals a previously unnoticed discrepancy in his position. This discrepancy is explained by a weak intentionalism that Beardsley himself tolerates. The paper concludes by assessing the inherent difficulties and contemporary relevance of Beardsley's theory, discussing concepts like illocutionary acts, representation, intentional fallacy, intention, and interpretation in literary analysis.

title: Encoding models for scholarly literature
abstract:
We examine the issue of digital formats for document encoding, archiving and
publishing, through the specific example of "born-digital" scholarly journal
articles. We will begin by looking at the traditional workflow of journal
editing and publication, and how these practices have made the transition into
the online domain. We will examine the range of different file formats in which
electronic articles are currently stored and published. We will argue strongly
that, despite the prevalence of binary and proprietary formats such as PDF and
MS Word, XML is a far superior encoding choice for journal articles. Next, we
look at the range of XML document structures (DTDs, Schemas) which are in
common use for encoding journal articles, and consider some of their strengths
and weaknesses. We will suggest that, despite the existence of specialized
schemas intended specifically for journal articles (such as NLM), and more
broadly-used publication-oriented schemas such as DocBook, there are strong
arguments in favour of developing a subset or customization of the Text
Encoding Initiative (TEI) schema for the purpose of journal-article encoding;
TEI is already in use in a number of journal publication projects, and the
scale and precision of the TEI tagset makes it particularly appropriate for
encoding scholarly articles. We will outline the document structure of a
TEI-encoded journal article, and look in detail at suggested markup patterns
for specific features of journal articles
fieldOfStudy: English Literature; Digital Humanities; Scholarly Publishing; Text Encoding Initiative
summary: This article examines digital formats for encoding, archiving, and publishing born-digital scholarly journal articles, critiquing traditional workflows and current file formats like PDF and MS Word. It argues strongly for XML as a superior encoding choice and explores various XML document structures, including DTDs and Schemas. The authors propose developing a subset or customization of the Text Encoding Initiative (TEI) schema for journal article encoding, highlighting its suitability for scholarly content due to its scale and precision, and detailing its potential document structure and markup patterns.

title: The sea in Sumerian literature
abstract: Surveying the references to the sea in Sumerian literature, this paper discusses the general idea that the sea is underrepresented in Mesopotamian cultures of the third millennium BCE. The common idea on Mesopotamian civilizations is that these were based on the rivers. However, recent research suggests the early Mesopotamian urban settlements of the third millennium BCE are on the ancient coast of the Persian Gulf and in the middle of lagoons or marshes. Coastal marsh cultures would not only have looked at the mainland, but also to the sea. Through a study of Sumerian literature and royal inscriptions, the historical relationship of the Mesopotamian cultures with the Persian Gulf is discussed. The image of the sea that emerges from literary sources reflects the changes that occurred in coastal region of southern Iraq during the third millennium BCE
fieldOfStudy: Literature, Ancient History, Mesopotamia, Mythology, Sumerian
summary: This paper challenges the conventional belief that the sea is underrepresented in third millennium BCE Mesopotamian cultures, which are commonly associated with rivers. Through an analysis of Sumerian literature and royal inscriptions, it argues that early Mesopotamian urban settlements along the ancient Persian Gulf coast, lagoons, and marshes fostered coastal marsh cultures with significant maritime connections. The study explores the historical relationship between Mesopotamian cultures and the Persian Gulf, revealing an image of the sea in literary sources that reflects regional changes in southern Iraq during the third millennium BCE. This research is important for understanding Mesopotamian civilization, ancient coastal environments, and the history of literature.

title: The familiar essay in American literature
abstract: Thesis (M.A.)--Boston Universit
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, American Literature, Essay, Literary Criticism
summary: This thesis, "The Familiar Essay in American Literature" by Marie Catherine Flannelly, explores the evolution and characteristics of the familiar essay genre. It defines the essay, classifies its types, and examines the essence and characteristics of the familiar essay. The study traces its development from English foundations (Addison, Steele, Lamb) to its American manifestation, highlighting the influence of Washington Irving, New England writers like Thoreau, Holmes, and Lowell, and other 19th-century essayists such as Donald G. Mitchell and George W. Curtis. This work provides a historical and analytical overview of the familiar essay within American literary traditions.

title: Technology and the Teaching of Literature
summary: This article addresses the imbalance in academic research concerning technology's application in teaching literature, especially compared to its integration in English language teaching. The author reviews current attitudes toward technology in education and explores the conditions under which it can be effectively applied to literary study. Faced with challenges like tight budgets, underprepared students, and public criticism, educators are increasingly encountering technology's influence. The paper aims to provide insights for English literature teachers to navigate the evolving landscape of high-tech teaching, offering a resource for understanding the uses and ramifications of technology in their field.

title: On the Ethical Character of Literature
summary: This philosophical essay explores how a distinct ethical dimension emerges in literary works, focusing on Franz Kafka's "The Trial" as a primary example. The author critiques prevailing views in contemporary Anglophone philosophical aesthetics regarding the ethical core of art. It argues that "The Trial" reveals an often-overlooked way for narrative to achieve ethical significance, distilling it into a value essential for appreciating artistic success. Key methods involve analyzing literary narrative structure and its capacity to convey moral meaning, offering insights into the intrinsic ethical worth of literature and its impact on artistic evaluation.

title: Eosinophilic otitis media a literature review
abstract: Eosinophilic otitis media is actually a recent introduction. These patients may manifest with sudden hearing loss. There may be associated bronchial asthma and allergic rhinitis. Diagnostic criteria of this condition are rather vague. A review of literature shows that demonstration of eosinophils in the middle ear secretion of these patients could be considered to be pathognomonic of this condition
summary: This review addresses eosinophilic otitis media, a recently recognized condition characterized by sudden hearing loss, often associated with bronchial asthma and allergic rhinitis. The diagnostic criteria are vague, but the presence of eosinophils in middle ear secretions is considered pathognomonic. The condition involves excessive eosinophil accumulation and persistent middle ear effusion, with pathophysiology linked to allergic reactions. The paper discusses its historical recognition, clinical manifestations, and potential treatments including steroids, antihistamines, and grommet insertion for acute hearing loss, highlighting the importance of eosinophil detection for diagnosis.

title: Identifying Data Sharing in Biomedical Literature
abstract: Many policies and projects now encourage investigators to share their raw research data with other scientists. Unfortunately, it is difficult to measure the effectiveness of these initiatives because data can be shared in such a variety of mechanisms and locations. We propose a novel approach to finding shared datasets: using NLP techniques to identify declarations of dataset sharing within the full text of primary research articles. Using regular expression patterns and machine learning algorithms on open access biomedical literature, our system was able to identify 61% of articles with shared datasets with 80% precision. A simpler version of our classifier achieved higher recall (86%), though lower precision (49%). We believe our results demonstrate the feasibility of this approach and hope to inspire further study of dataset retrieval techniques and policy evaluation.&#xa
fieldOfStudy: Biomedical Literature, Natural Language Processing, Data Sharing, Machine Learning
summary: This paper proposes a novel approach to identifying shared research datasets by using natural language processing (NLP) techniques on the full text of primary research articles. The researchers applied regular expression patterns and machine learning algorithms to open-access biomedical literature. Their system successfully identified 61% of articles with shared datasets at 80% precision, while a simpler classifier achieved 86% recall with 49% precision. These results demonstrate the feasibility of using NLP for dataset retrieval and evaluation of data sharing policies, aiming to inspire further study in this area.

title: Nursing recruitment literature and its use
abstract: Thesis (M.S.)--Boston Universit
summary: This field study, submitted for a Master of Science in Nursing at Boston University in 1963, investigates nursing recruitment literature and its usage. The research focuses on the National League for Nursing recruitment materials available to guidance counselors. The methodology involved data procurement through interviews with counselors, utilizing a structured interview form to assess their access, recency, sources, and methods of using this literature. The study also explored counselors' perceptions of the literature's informativeness regarding nursing programs and the profession, and sought suggestions for improvement. This work provides insight into recruitment strategies and communication in nursing education.

title: Aesthetics and literature : a problematic relation?
abstract: The paper argues that there is a proper place for literature within aesthetics but that care must be taken in identifying just what the relation is. In characterising aesthetic pleasure associated with literature it is all too easy to fall into reductive accounts, for example, of literature as merely "fine writing". Belleslettrist or formalistic accounts of literature are rejected, as are two other kinds of reduction, to pure meaning properties and to a kind of narrative realism. The idea is developed that literature-both poetry and prose fiction-invites its own distinctive kind of aesthetic appreciation which far from being at odds with critical practice, in fact chimes well with it
summary: This paper explores the complex relationship between aesthetics and literature, arguing for a distinct aesthetic appreciation of literary works that avoids reductive interpretations. It critiques approaches that limit literature to "fine writing," pure meaning properties, or narrative realism, emphasizing that both poetry and prose fiction invite unique aesthetic engagement. The author posits that this distinctive aesthetic appreciation is not at odds with critical practice but rather aligns with it, offering a framework for understanding literature's aesthetic value beyond simplistic reductions. This work contributes to philosophical studies of aesthetics, literary theory, and critical practice.

title: Attitudes to vocational learning : a literature review
publisher: Education Analytical Services Division, Scottish Government
summary: This literature review, commissioned by the Scottish Government in 2008, investigates attitudes towards vocational learning. Authored by Sheila Edward, Elisabet Weedon, and Sheila Riddell from the University of Edinburgh, it compiles existing research to understand perceptions of vocational education. The report reflects strategic objectives conceived under a previous administration, serving as a resource for those interested in the subject. It includes an analysis of people not in employment, education, or training (NEET) in Scotland, offering insights into youth engagement with vocational pathways and broader educational trends.

title: History, Literature, and Authority in International Law
abstract: One consequence of international law’s recent historical turn has been to sharpen methodological contrasts between intellectual history and international law.  Scholars including Antony Anghie, Anne Orford, Rose Parfitt, and Martti Koskenniemi have taken on board historians’ interest in contingency and context but pointedly relaxed historians’ traditional stricture against presentist instrumentalism.  This essay argues that such a move disrupts a longstanding division of labor between history and international law and ultimately brings international legal method closer to literature and literary scholarship.  The essay therefore details several more or less endemic ways in which literature and literary studies confront challenges of presentism, anachronism, meaning, and time.  Using examples from writers as diverse as Anghie, Spinoza, Geoffrey Hill, Emily St. John Mandel, China Miéville, John Hollander, Pascale Casanova, Matthew Nicholson, John Selden, Shakespeare, and Dante, it proposes a “trilateral” discussion among historians, international lawyers, and literary scholars that takes seriously the multipolar disciplinary field in which each of these disciplines makes and sustains relations with each of the others.
summary: This essay explores the methodological contrasts between intellectual history and international law, particularly concerning the relaxed strictures against presentist instrumentalism adopted by scholars like Anghie, Orford, and Koskenniemi. It argues that this shift disrupts the traditional division of labor and aligns international legal method closer to literature and literary scholarship. The study details how literary studies confront challenges of presentism, anachronism, meaning, and time, proposing a "trilateral" discussion among historians, international lawyers, and literary scholars. This interdisciplinary approach, drawing on diverse examples, fosters a nuanced understanding of their interconnected disciplinary fields.

title: Literature-based priors for gene regulatory networks
abstract: Motivation: The use of prior knowledge to improve gene regulatory network modelling has often been proposed. In this paper we present the first research on the massive incorporation of prior knowledge from literature for Bayesian network learning of gene networks. As the publication rate of scientific papers grows, updating online databases, which have been proposed as potential prior knowledge in past rese-arch, becomes increasingly challenging. The novelty of our approach lies in the use of gene-pair association scores that describe the over-lap in the contexts in which the genes are mentioned, generated from a large database of scientific literature, harnessing the information contained in a huge number of documents into a simple, clear format. Results: We present a method to transform such literature-based gene association scores to network prior probabilities, and apply it to learn gene sub-networks for yeast, E. coli and Human organisms. We also investigate the effect of weighting the influence of the prior know-ledge. Our findings show that literature-based priors can improve both the number of true regulatory interactions present in the network and the accuracy of expression value prediction on genes, in comparison to a network learnt solely from expression data. Networks learnt with priors also show an improved biological interpretation, with identified subnetworks that coincide with known biological pathways. Contact
fieldOfStudy: English Bioinformatics Gene Regulatory Networks Bayesian Networks Literature Mining
summary: This paper introduces a novel approach for incorporating massive prior knowledge from scientific literature to improve Bayesian network learning of gene regulatory networks. The method utilizes gene-pair association scores derived from a large database of scientific literature, representing contextual overlap in gene mentions. These scores are transformed into network prior probabilities and applied to learn gene sub-networks in yeast, E. coli, and human organisms. The findings demonstrate that literature-based priors enhance the number of true regulatory interactions, improve expression value prediction accuracy, and yield better biological interpretations, with identified subnetworks aligning with known biological pathways. This research significantly advances gene network modeling by leveraging vast textual data.

title: GCSE subject criteria for English literature
publisher: Office of Qualifications and Examinations Regulation
summary: This document outlines the GCSE Subject Criteria for English Literature, establishing common knowledge, understanding, skills, and assessment objectives for all GCSE specifications in the subject. It serves as a framework for awarding organizations, aiming to inspire and engage learners with literature. Key sections include aims and learning outcomes, subject content, assessment objectives, scheme of assessment, and grade descriptions, ensuring a broad and coherent study. The criteria emphasize developing interest in literature, analyzing language, structure, form, themes, and historical contexts, while making connections between texts to enhance understanding and enjoyment. This provides guidelines for English Literature education.

title: The Middle Ages in Children’s Literature
summary: Clare Bradford's "The Middle Ages in Children's Literature" examines the pervasive presence of "medievalisms" in contemporary youth literature, exploring how medieval culture elements function and convey meaning. Bradford argues that the past and present coexist, allowing present-day texts to analyze themselves by creating reassuring distance. The study posits the Middle Ages as a cultural lingua franca, reflecting both historical contexts and contemporary concerns. Rooted in an ideology-critical approach, the work advocates for empathy and openness to diverse perspectives, challenging binarisms, and serving as an inspiration for studies addressing discriminatory mindsets within children's literature.

title: How good is the orthopaedic literature?
abstract: Randomized trials constitute approximately 3% of the orthopaedic literature Concerns regarding quality of the orthopaedic literature stem from a widespread notion that the overall quality of the surgical literature is in need of improvement. Limitations in surgical research arises primarily from two pervasive issues: 1) A reliance on low levels of evidence to advance surgical knowledge, and 2) Poor reporting quality among the high level surgical evidence that is available. The scarcity of randomized trials may be largely attributable to several unique challenges which make them difficult to conduct. We present characteristics of the orthopaedic literature and address the challenges of conducting randomized trials in surgery
fieldOfStudy: Orthopaedic Surgery, Medical Literature, Randomized Trials
summary: This article addresses concerns regarding the quality of orthopaedic literature, noting that randomized trials comprise only about 3% of published works. The authors highlight limitations in surgical research, primarily stemming from a reliance on low-level evidence and poor reporting quality in higher-level studies. They investigate the unique challenges that make conducting randomized trials difficult in surgery and present characteristics of the orthopaedic literature. This study aims to improve understanding and execution of high-quality research within the field, emphasizing the scarcity of robust evidence.

title: Structured Review of Code Clone Literature
abstract: This report presents the results of a structured review of code clone literature. The aim of the review is to assemble a conceptual model of clone-related concepts which helps us to reason about clones. This conceptual model unifies clone concepts from a wide range of literature, so that findings about clones can be compared with each other
publisher: Centre for Telematics and Information Technology, University of Twente
summary: This report presents a structured review of code clone literature, aiming to construct a conceptual model of clone-related concepts. The purpose is to unify findings across various studies, enabling better comparison and reasoning about code duplication and its impact on software changeability. The review highlights the confusion of concepts in existing literature and emphasizes the need for a clearer understanding. Key methods involve a structured literature review to assemble the conceptual model, which is still a work in progress, requiring further refinement through additional research. Keywords: code clones, software duplication, conceptual model, literature review, changeability.

title: Hong Kong literature as Sinophone literature = 華語語系香港文學初論
summary: This article investigates Hong Kong literature through the lens of "Sinophone literature," extending Sau-ling Wong's denotative meaning of "Sinophone" to explore its connotative implications. The author examines how Hong Kong writers, including "namloi zokga" (writers who came South), engage with their local public and the concept of "concrete universality" as defined by Jean-Paul Sartre. It argues that the critical potential of Sinophone Hong Kong literature emerges when writers engage locally, moving beyond a "hollow dream of the absolute" rooted in seeking recognition from China. Key concepts include Sinophone, Hong Kong literature, concrete universality, and cultural authenticity.

title: A Taste of Indonesian Literature Today
abstract: https://scholarworks.sjsu.edu/chc_flyers/1030/thumbnail.jp
authors: San Jose State University, Cultural Heritage Center
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, Indonesian Literature, Cultural Heritage, Human Rights
summary: This document describes an event titled "A Taste of Indonesian Literature Today" held at San Jose State University's Cultural Heritage Center. The event, on September 29, 2015, featured award-winning Indonesian authors and translators who discussed their work and global topics including human rights, religious tolerance, environmental concerns, and women's equalization. Specific works highlighted are "Kei" by Erni Aladjai (translated by Nurhayat Indriyatno Mohamed) and "Daughters of Papua" by Anindita S. Thayf (translated by Stefanny Irawan). Lian Gouw of Dalang Publishing was also in conversation, with an author signing and Indonesian refreshments provided.

title: Dalit Literature as a Socio-political Tool
publisher: The Center for South Asian Studies, Tokyo University of Foreign Studies
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, Indian Society, Political Science
summary: This article examines Dalit literature as a powerful socio-political tool in India's caste-ridden society. It discusses how India's multi-layered social reality, particularly the caste system, fuels conflict and influences active politics, a divide that has deepened since independence. The paper argues that Dalit literature has become an important means of social and political transformation, supplanting traditional religious institutions in consciousness-building. By empowering and awakening all sections of society, Dalit literature strengthens the nation and increases the participatory role of Dalits in politics, indicating that no caste can be neglected in democratic India. Keywords: Dalit literature, caste system, India, social transformation, political activism.

title: Grey literature review code
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, Grey Literature, Review Processes, Peer Review
summary: This document proposes a set of "Review Codes" to standardize the indication of review processes for grey literature, which is often mistakenly assumed to lack quality scrutiny. It outlines various pre-publication review types, including independent peer review, expert panel review, and internal review, as well as an option for post-publication peer review. The codes aim to provide transparency on the rigor and quality control undertaken for such resources. Users are instructed to select an applicable code, add it to bibliographic information, and provide a brief explanation of the review process.

title: HUNGER AND WAITING IN THIRD WORLD LITERATURE
abstract:
Using colonial discourse and post-colonial theory as a point of reference, this article takes a look at colonialism as experienced in the so-called third world and see how the experience has helped shaped the literary production of the countries and people so colonized. The study examines the British idea of 'Empire' and the

colonial enterprise in a selected range of 20th-century texts, in an attempt to understand how imperialism affected literary texts produced in some former colonies particularly those in Africa, the Caribbean and Latin America. Texts to be considered in this study include: Marquez’s No One Writes to the Colonel, Enroll John’s

Moon on a Rainbow Shawl and Marechera’s House of Hunger. The

study will be viewing a literature characterized by elements of the fantastic woven into the story. A literature that scrutinizes society to its basis by examining the postcolonial hangover, a literary trend that separates the literature of the “subject” from the

literature of the “other
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, Postcolonial Theory, Literary Studies
summary: This article utilizes colonial discourse and post-colonial theory to analyze the impact of colonialism on literary production in former colonies, particularly in Africa, the Caribbean, and Latin America. It examines the British idea of 'Empire' and its influence on 20th-century texts, focusing on works like Márquez's "No One Writes to the Colonel," John's "Moon on a Rainbow Shawl," and Marechera's "House of Hunger." The study explores how these literary works incorporate elements of the fantastic and scrutinize society's postcolonial aftermath, highlighting themes of 'hunger' and 'waiting' as expressions of discontent and a yearning for freedom from oppression.

title: The canonization of German-language digital literature
abstract: In his paper, "The Canonization of German-language Digital Literature," Florian Hartling discusses "Net Literature," a relatively young phenomenon, that has its roots in experimental visual and concrete poetry and hypertext. With the use of new media technology, this new genre of literature has acquired much interest and is now considered to be one of the most important influences in contemporary art. Not only does Net Literature connect sound, video, and animation with interactivity and allows new forms of artistic expression, it also impacts significantly on the traditional functions of the literary system. Hartling suggests that, in relation to Net Literature, the notion of the "death of the author" gives birth to the "writing reader." Hartling presents the results of his study where he applies the concept of "canon" to German-language Net Literature and where he attempts to find out whether, in this new form of literature, a "canon" has already been formed. Based on Karl Erik Rosengren's framework of "mention technique," a sample of Germanlanguage reviews of Net Literature was analyzed. The study intends to test the applicability of Rosengren's method to the analysis of Net Literature, that is, whether it is valid to use a method that was originally developed for the empirical study of the traditional literary canon for the study of an emergent Net Literature
summary: Florian Hartling's paper, "The Canonization of German-language Digital Literature," explores "Net Literature," a relatively new genre stemming from experimental poetry and hypertext. This study investigates whether a literary canon has formed within German-language Net Literature, utilizing Karl Erik Rosengren's "mention technique" framework to analyze reviews. Hartling examines the applicability of traditional canon study methods to emergent digital literature, considering how new media impacts literary functions and shifts the notion of authorship from "death of the author" to the "writing reader." Key findings focus on canon formation and methodological validation in digital literary studies.

title: Anthologizing Sir Samuel Ferguson: Literature, History, Politics
abstract: Published Online: 2013-10-25; This content is open access.Although Sir Samuel Ferguson is generally recognized as one of the key figures of mid-nineteenth-century Irish literature, there has been no major edition of his poems since 1916, as a result of which his work tends to be known to the general reader through selections published in anthologies. The essay analyzes the selections of Ferguson’s work in anthologies of Irish literature published between 1895 and 2010 in an attempt to assess the impact of the cultural dynamics of twentieth-century Ireland on the interpretation of Ferguson’s achievement as a poet. The evidence collected demonstrates that the image of Ferguson perpetuated by most twentiethcentury anthologists, most of them Hibernocentric in approach, was that of a respectable if rather old-fashioned Romantic nationalist antiquarian, whose work focused primarily on familiarizing the Victorian reader with the ancient myths and traditions of Ireland. This interpretation of Ferguson’s achievement, motivated, it is argued, by the predominantly nationalist agenda of modern Ireland’s cultural establishment, has largely marginalized the other side of Ferguson—a political thinker committed to the unionist cause and vehemently opposed to the violence perpetrated by the emergent Irish republican movement and culminating in the Phoenix Park murders of 1882, which formed the subject of two of Ferguson’s most powerful late poems, “At the Polo-Ground” and “In Carey’s Footsteps.
summary: This essay analyzes selections of Sir Samuel Ferguson's work in Irish literature anthologies from 1895 to 2010 to assess the impact of twentieth-century cultural dynamics on his poetic interpretation. The study reveals that most Hibernocentric anthologists perpetuated an image of Ferguson as a Romantic nationalist antiquarian, focusing on Irish myths. This nationalist-driven interpretation, it is argued, marginalized his role as a unionist political thinker, vehemently opposed to the Irish republican movement's violence, as evidenced in his later poems like "At the Polo-Ground" and "In Carey's Footsteps." This research explores literary canon formation and political influence on reception.

title: Integrated assessment : new assessment methods literature review
abstract: The assessment of students in higher education performs a number of functions, some of which may not always be compatible with each other. Traditionally, the role of the assessor has involved determining the level of competence displayed in undertaking the task, and ideally, offering feedback on future learning needs (Rowntree, 1987). Assessment also provides grading for students’ work, allowing comparison of performance across a class, and across the curriculum for individual students. The subsequent gaining of a degree or professional qualification depends on students successfully completing a set of specified assessment tasks across the prescribed curriculum. As such, there may be stakeholders beyond the higher education institution, such as employers, regulatory bodies or clients, who believe the assessment process as being akin to certification or professional gatekeeping (Younes,1998). In professional courses such as social work, passing certain assessment tasks may be associated with notions such as fitness to practice and eligibility for professional registration as a social worker with the Scottish Social Services Council (SSSC) or similar bodies in England, Northern Ireland and Wales, and beyond the United Kingdom. In terms of gatekeeping, assessment tasks may not only restrict who gains certification on exiting an educational programme, but also who is admitted in the first place. For example, requirements by registration authorities that students admitted to social work programmes have achieved specified levels of literacy and numeracy will require appropriate assessment tasks to determine equivalence for those entrants who have not achieved formal qualifications in these areas. Entry point assessments may also be used to determine whether credit should be granted on the basis of prior learning or experience (Slater, 2000) or to identify areas in which additional training may be required (Shera, 2001) In addition to gatekeeping, assessment clearly has a vital role to play in the ongoing development of learning and teaching strategies. It can be crucial in determining what, why and how students learn (Brown, Bull and Pendlebury, 1997) and there is increasing recognition of the necessity to align learning and assessment tasks, so that learning and assessment become aligned rather than being somewhat independent of each other (Biggs, 2003). Furthermore, in an era when evaluation of teaching is often reduced to student satisfaction surveys, critical reflection on work submitted for assessment can serve as an alternative method of evaluating the success of teaching. The nature of assessment has changed considerably since the 1970s, and is ongoing. The key changes have included moves from written examinations to coursework assignments and more emphasis on student participation in assessment (self and peer assessments), processes rather than products, and on competencies rather than content (Brown et al., 1997). Even the more traditional forms of assessment such as essays and examinations have undergone considerable innovations. Yet, in practice these seemingly radical changes may be more a wish list than a statement of fact. In actuality, some new forms of assessment, such as self and peer assessment may simply have been added onto rather than replaced more traditional modes of assessment (Cree, 2000). Changes to assessment in social work tend to reflect changes in higher education more widely such as the emergence of competency based and modular approaches to learning, as well more proceduralised assessment processes necessary to cope with higher numbers of students (Cree, 2000). There is considerable divergence of opinion amongst the social work education community in the United Kingdom as to whether such changes actually benefit social work students and their learning (eg Clark, 1997; Ford and Hayes, 1996; O’Hagan, 1997; Shardlow and Doel, 1996). There have also been concerns expressed as to whether some new forms of assessment are actually capable of achieving the learning they claim to facilitate Boud, 1999; Entwistle, 1990; Taylor, 1993). This report was commissioned by the Scottish Institute for Excellence in Social Work Education (SIESWE) as a resource on assessment for the development of the new social work degree in Scotland and provides an overview of the current literature on assessment methods being utilised in social work education both in the United Kingdom and beyond. This report begins by reviewing the various methods of assessment in social work education which were found in the literature. We then go on to explore the developing literature on the involvement of persons other than social work academics, such as students and service users, in the assessment process. Finally, we consider the importance of developing and assessment strategy which might incorporate these various different forms of assessmen
publisher: Scottish Institute for Excellence in Social Work Education
summary: This report, commissioned by the Scottish Institute for Excellence in Social Work Education (SIESWE), reviews current assessment methods in social work education within and beyond the UK to inform the new social work degree in Scotland. It discusses the multifaceted functions of assessment, including competence evaluation, grading, and professional gatekeeping. The review explores traditional and evolving assessment practices, such as the shift from examinations to coursework, student participation, and competency-based approaches. It also examines the involvement of students and service users in assessment and the importance of developing integrated assessment strategies. Key findings highlight the ongoing changes and debates within the social work education community regarding the efficacy and benefits of these evolving assessment methods.

title: Cornish Language and Literature: A Brief Introduction
abstract:
Język kórnicki należy do języków celtyckich i jest spokrewniony z walijskim i bretońskim.
Jego historię dzieli się na trzy okresy: starokomicki (od czasów inwazji anglosaksońskich
aż po koniec XII w.), średniokornicki (1200-1600) i późnokornicki
(1600-1800). Do najstarszych zabytków języka kornickiego należy 19 glos z końca IX w. oraz
pochodzący z początku XII w. słownik łacińsko-kornicki (Vocabularium Cornicum) zawierający
961 słów. Najważniejsze dzieła literackie powstały w okresie średniokornickim. Były to misteria
(Ordinalia, Żywot iw . Meriaska) i wiersze, głównie o chrakterze religijnym (Męka Pańska).
Z okresu późnokomickiego pozostał, najprawdopodobniej jedynie we fragmencie, jeden dramat

(Stworzenie świata), krótka powiastka osnuta na motywach ludowych, piosenki, przysłowia
i tłumaczenia, zwłaszcza tekstów o charakterze religijnym. Na przełomie XVIII i XIX w. język
kórnicki przestał istnieć.
W XX w. są podejmowane próby wskrzeszenia języka. Mimo metodologicznych zastrzeżeń
wysuwanych przez niektórych językoznawców istnieje obecnie kilka wariantów rekonstruowanego
kornickiego (Unified Cornish, Common Cornish, Modern Comish). W każdym rozwija się
literatura, głównie poezja, ale także opowiadania, powieści, tłumaczenia, literatura dla dzieci,
a nawet słuchowiska radiowe. Warunkiem dalszego rozwoju literatury jest ujednolicenie
i upowszechnienie rekonstruowanego języka.Zadanie pt. „Digitalizacja i udostępnienie w Cyfrowym Repozytorium Uniwersytetu Łódzkiego kolekcji czasopism naukowych wydawanych przez Uniwersytet Łódzki” nr 885/P-DUN/2014 dofinansowane zostało ze środków MNiSW w ramach działalności upowszechniającej nauk
fieldOfStudy: English Language and Literature, Celtic Languages
summary: This article offers a concise introduction to the Cornish language and its literature, tracing its historical development through Old, Middle, and Late Cornish periods. It highlights key linguistic artifacts like the Vocabularium Cornicum and significant literary works, including medieval mysteries and religious texts. The paper also discusses the language's decline by the 19th century and contemporary efforts to revive it, noting various reconstructed variants (Unified, Common, and Modern Cornish) and the burgeoning literature (poetry, prose, translations) in these forms. The author emphasizes the need for standardization to ensure further literary growth.

title: Text and Context: Teaching Native American Literature
abstract: Silence is a major value in Native American culture, for silence is the token of acceptance, the symbol of peace and serenity, and the outward expression of harmony between the human and natural worlds. The result of this tradition of silence, however, is a limited written record, a limited number of texts produced by Native Americans themselves. This situation allowed the Anglo to step into the void and speak for Native Americans themselves, or more accurately, to claim to speak as their  interpreters.  The implication that white culture drew from the lack of a written language in any of the Native American tribes was that these people had nothing of value to say to themselves or to others. It was not until the past twenty years that Native Americans have begun to produce their own literary works written in English with an eye toward communicating with the American population as a whole. Until the publication of Scott Momaday\u27s House Made of Dawn (1968), the general population had not heard actual Native Americans speak in their own voices-the white culture had been speaking for them. During the past twenty years, however, there has been a veritable explosion of texts coming from the Native American community, and we now have a substantial corpus to use in teaching contemporary Native American literature
summary: This paper discusses the evolving landscape of Native American literature and its role in education. Historically, a tradition of silence in Native American culture resulted in limited written records, allowing Anglo voices to dominate the narrative. However, the last two decades, particularly since Scott Momaday's "House Made of Dawn" (1968), have seen a significant increase in Native American authors producing literary works in English, directly engaging with the American population. The author emphasizes the importance of teaching contemporary Native American literature to foster understanding and allow students to hear authentic Native American voices, promoting a positive growth experience for both students and educators.

title: Preserving Open Access Journals: A Literature Review
abstract:
This literature review addresses certain questions concerning the preservation of free, born-digital scholarly materials. It covers recent thinking on the current state of preservation efforts of born-digital materials; the range of actors involved in significant preservation initiatives of these artefacts; the perceived barriers preventing open access materials from benefiting from existing preservation efforts; initiatives that may enable local, small-scale preservation efforts to be undertaken; the challenges and opportunities posed to preservation by new models of scholarship such as open access datasets, reference sharing and annotation, collaborative authoring and community peer review.

The review identifies representative international collaborative preservation initiatives, describes their goals and results, their specific preservation strategie, and their applicability to the preservation of born digital open access materials
fieldOfStudy: Library Science, Digital Preservation, Open Access
summary: This literature review explores the challenges and initiatives surrounding the preservation of free, born-digital scholarly materials, particularly within the Open Access movement. It examines current preservation efforts, the range of actors involved, perceived barriers to open access materials benefiting from existing efforts, and strategies for local, small-scale preservation. The review also considers how new scholarly models, such as open access datasets and collaborative authoring, impact preservation. It identifies representative international collaborative preservation initiatives, detailing their goals, results, specific strategies, and applicability to born-digital open access content, ultimately addressing the "crisis in scholarly communications" by promoting free online access.

title: Traffic, diesel and asthma : a literature review
abstract: This article details the major pollutants from motor vehicle exhaust, mainly particulate matter, nitrogen dioxide and polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons. The emphasis is on motor vehicle emissions from diesel powered engines, which have become a significant source of air pollution in urban areas. The impact of motor vehicle pollutants on respiratory health is explored, and the major studies relating asthma to high volume of traffic and proximity to major traffic arteries are reviewed.peer-reviewe
