summary: This article reviews the major pollutants from motor vehicle exhaust, focusing on particulate matter, nitrogen dioxide, and polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, particularly from diesel engines in urban areas. It explores their impact on respiratory health, especially the link between asthma and high traffic volumes or proximity to major traffic arteries. The review synthesizes existing studies to highlight the significant contribution of vehicular emissions to air pollution and its adverse effects on human health, with keywords including asthma, traffic, diesel, and pollution.

title: Making Sense of Leased Popular Literature Collections
abstract: There is a well-publicized debate in the library field on whether or not it should be an academic library’s responsibility to collect and preserve popular culture materials.  Budget constraints, space issues, and the “quality” of these materials, are all widely documented concerns as to why popular culture materials—especially popular literature titles—are still not making their way into an academic library’s permanent collection.  This study describes a survey of 22 academic libraries throughout the country that use a leased popular literature collection in addition to or instead of purchasing popular literature titles for their permanent collection.  The study was designed to answer the following research questions and others:  Why do academic libraries choose to use a leasing plan to provide a popular literature collection for their users?  What are the values/benefits these collections provide for the library and its users
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
summary: This study addresses the ongoing debate within the library field regarding academic libraries' responsibility to collect and preserve popular culture materials, specifically popular literature. Facing budget constraints, space limitations, and concerns about material "quality," many libraries explore alternative collection strategies. The research describes a survey of 22 academic libraries utilizing leased popular literature collections, either supplementing or replacing permanent purchases. Key research questions explored the motivations for using leasing plans and the values or benefits these collections provide for both the library and its users. The findings aim to shed light on the efficacy and advantages of leased popular literature in academic settings.

title: The Chronotopic Imagination in Literature and Film
abstract: In this contribution, I would like to examine the way in which Bakhtin, in the two essays dedicated to the chronotope, lays the foundations for a theory of literary imagination. […] His concept of the chronotope may be interpreted as a contribution to a tradition in which Henri Bergson, William James, Charles Sander Peirce and Gilles Deleuze have been key figures. Like these four authors, Bakhtin is a philosopher in the school of pragmatism. His predilection for what Gary Saul Morson and Caryl Emerson have called “prosaics” puts him right at the heart of a philosophical family that calls forth multiplicity against metaphysical essentialism, and prefers the mundane to the universal. It seems wise to proceed carefully in the attempt to reconstruct Bakhtin’s theory of imagination. In this contribution to the debate, I choose to develop a philosophical dialogue between Bakhtin and the above-mentioned philosophical family. More specifically, it seems to me that the ideal point of departure for examining the way in which Bakhtin attempts to get to the bottom of the mysteries of literary imagination is Gilles Deleuze’s synthesis of Bergson’s epistemological view on knowledge as “the perception of images”, as well as Peirce’s theory of experience based on a typology of images. In the following, I show that Bakhtin’s view of the temporal-spatial constellations in literature demonstrates a strong affinity to the Bergsonian view that perception of the spatial world is colored by the lived time experienced by the observer. Based on this observation, I then develop a typology of images which places the concept of the chronotope in a more systematic framework
summary: This contribution examines Bakhtin's concept of the chronotope as a foundation for a theory of literary imagination, positioning him within a pragmatist philosophical tradition alongside figures like Bergson, James, Peirce, and Deleuze. The author proposes a philosophical dialogue between Bakhtin and this tradition, particularly using Deleuze's synthesis of Bergson's epistemological view and Peirce's theory of experience as a starting point. The paper demonstrates affinities between Bakhtin's and Bergson's views on temporal-spatial constellations in literature, leading to the development of a typology of images that systematically frames the chronotope concept.

title: Students’ Engagement in School: A literature review
abstract:
This work is financed by National Founds through FCT-Fundação para a Ciência e Tecnologia, in the
context of the project PTDC/CPE-CED/114362/2009- Students Engagement in Schools: Differentiation and Promotion, coordinated by Prof. Feliciano H. Veiga.Students’ Engagement in School has been the focus of debate concerning academic success and school dropout, and pointed out as a mean to address the problems affecting our schools and their students, not only for having value in itself, but also for being an important mediator between several
academic variables. This paper reviews the research and literature on this concept and its relations with personal and contextual variables, as well as with academic performance, with the aim of
summarizing the main relationships found. Literature presents a significant number of studies which sustain that personal variables, such as self-efficacy and self-concept, as well as contextual - peers,
school, family- are related with school engagement. The adoption of mastery goals, for instance, has a positive impact on school, as they are related with the use of cognitive and self-regulatory strategies
by students. Positive relationships with peers, teachers support and the quality of family relations are associated with higher levels of engagement and academic performance, while negative experiences,
such as bullying, are related with educational difficulties. Following this, we reflect about the relevance
of studying engagement in school, in the context of widespread financial crisis, and emphasize the need to rethink educational institutions considering the paradigmatic changes that currently occur.This work is financed by National Founds through FCT-Fundação para a Ciência e Tecnologia, in the
context of the project PTDC/CPE-CED/114362/2009- Students Engagement in Schools: Differentiation and Promotion, coordinated by Prof. Feliciano H. Veiga
summary: This paper reviews literature on student engagement in school, examining its connections with academic success, school dropout, and its role as a mediator between academic variables. The research synthesizes findings on personal variables (self-efficacy, self-concept) and contextual factors (peers, school, family) that influence engagement. Key findings indicate that mastery goals, positive peer relations, teacher support, and quality family relations positively impact engagement and academic performance, while negative experiences like bullying hinder it. The study emphasizes the importance of understanding engagement in education amidst financial crises and calls for rethinking educational institutions.

title: Kevin Ireland
summary: This work provides an overview of Kevin Ireland, a New Zealand poet, prose writer, and librettist. It traces his literary career from his early days in Auckland, through his time in London, and his prolific return to New Zealand. The summary highlights his diverse output, including 18 volumes of poetry, short stories, novels, memoirs, and non-fiction. It discusses his characteristic taut, pared-down style alongside longer, reflective poems, noting his use of reminiscence, satire, and wit to explore themes of mortality, the world's disorder, and historical failures. The analysis also touches on his precise formal control and distinctive reading style.

title: Aesthetic and Social Community: Multicultural Poetry and the Anthologizing of Poems
abstract: Scholars from various disciplines have explored the concept of multiculturalism from the perspectives of citizenship, recognition, representation, tokenism, constitutionalism, and other vantage points, with politics and education receiving most of the attention. I While many efforts have been made to explore these aspects of multiculturalism, its significance in poetry, particularly in poetry\u27s composition and critique, has not been duly taken into account. Multicultural poetry designates a critical abstraction in which poetry is classified by relation to a communal culture, history, or customs. In this definition, multicultural poetry is therefore inclusive of poetry written by ethnic minorities, women, non-mainstream religious practitioners, and members of other communities. To maintain a focus, this article delimits its discussion to poetry\u27s relationship with ethnicity and probes the interplay between aesthetic and ethnicity in three sections–Mainstream Poetry Anthologies: Tastes, Schools, and the Issue of History, Multicultural Poetry Anthologies: Situated Poetry and Group Poetics, and Ethnopoetics as a Choice
summary: This article explores multiculturalism's underexplored significance in poetry, particularly its composition and critique. Defining multicultural poetry as that classified by communal culture, history, or customs, it includes works by ethnic minorities, women, and other community members. Focusing on ethnicity, the paper probes the interplay between aesthetic and ethnicity across three sections: "Mainstream Poetry Anthologies: Tastes, Schools, and the Issue of History," "Multicultural Poetry Anthologies: Situated Poetry and Group Poetics," and "Ethnopoetics as a Choice." The initial sections analyze selection standards in notable poetry anthologies and show how alternative canon formation can occur.

title: The Cultural Translation of Battlers Poetry (Dagong shige)
abstract: Contemporary mainland-Chinese poetry displays a great deal of diversity and dynamism. Battlers poetry (dagong shige)—writing by members of the underclass of domestic migrant workers—is a relatively recent arrival. This essay delves into the discourse surrounding battlers poetry and its interactions with other poetry “departments,” particularly that of avant-garde poetry. It does so from the perspective of cultural translation. I argue that this is especially helpful for understanding the dynamics of battlers poetry, and of “poetry” at large as a discursive space in China today. The essay offers a discussion of translated people, texts in transit, commentary as conflict and battlers poetry’s representation outside China. In closing, it asks how this poetry might affect the genre’s habitual conceptualizations
fieldOfStudy: English, Poetry, Chinese Poetry, Cultural Translation
summary: This essay examines battlers poetry (dagong shige), a recent and dynamic form of contemporary mainland-Chinese poetry written by domestic migrant workers. Utilizing a cultural translation perspective, the study analyzes the discourse surrounding battlers poetry and its interactions with other poetic genres, particularly avant-garde poetry. Key methods involve discussing translated people, texts in transit, commentary as conflict, and the poetry's representation outside China. The main finding is that cultural translation is crucial for understanding the dynamics of battlers poetry and the broader discursive space of poetry in China, ultimately exploring how this genre might influence habitual conceptualizations of poetry.

title: Poetry
summary: This entry from the Humanistic Mathematics Network Journal features several poems by Lee Goldstein, exploring themes of mathematical research, personal struggle, mental states, and philosophical concepts. The collection includes reflections on the demanding yet inspiring nature of mentorship in research, moments of frustration and breakthrough, and deeper dives into ideas such as mentalism, psychosis, and noesis. The poems leverage abstract and philosophical language to connect personal experience with broader intellectual inquiries, offering a poetic lens on human cognition and the pursuit of knowledge. Keywords include humanistic mathematics, poetry, mentorship, mentalism, psychosis, noesis, and philosophy.

title: Quick Question
abstract: Poetry by Matt Del Busto. Winner in the 2018 Manuscripts Poetry Contest
summary: This abstract features "quick question" by Matt Del Busto, winner of the 2018 Manuscripts Poetry Contest. The poem uses vivid, often contrasting imagery: a neuron's journey, a dog and leash, deflating airbags, and spilling blood. It explores themes of longing, lost innocence, and the lingering echoes of childhood joy and unasked questions. The speaker grapples with self-worth, reflected in visceral metaphors of dissection, ultimately recalling a shared past filled with laughter and boundless opportunities. Key themes include memory, self-doubt, and the passage of time.

title: My Alcoholic Mother Died Last Week
abstract: Poetry by Ian Hunt. Third place in the 2019 Manuscripts Poetry Contest
summary: This poem, awarded third place in the 2019 Manuscripts Poetry Contest, explores a moment of destructive fantasy within a liquor store aisle. The speaker contemplates an act of chaotic release, imagining sweeping bottles from shelves, creating a flood of various spirits and broken glass. The narrative is infused with a sense of underlying tension and a poignant reference to the recent death of the speaker's alcoholic mother, suggesting themes of grief, rebellion, and the desire for emotional catharsis.

title: Out of Office Reply
abstract: Poetry by Tyler Wagner. Runner up in the 2018 Manuscripts Poetry Contest
summary: This poem by Tyler Wagner, a runner-up in the 2018 Manuscripts Poetry Contest, explores the fluctuating human experience through vivid imagery and metaphors. The speaker describes feeling like an incomplete sketch, a locked cart, or an assassin, and personifies migraines as lovers. Themes include identity, internal conflict, and the feeling of isolation within one's own mind. Keywords: poetry, human experience, identity, internal conflict, isolation, migraines.

title: Strong and Weak Interpretations in Translating Chinese Poetry
abstract: Are classical Chinese and modern Chinese one language, or two? Is translating classical Chinese poetry the same as or different from translating modern Chinese poetry? I have earlier argued that modern Chinese poetry is in some ways a translation of premodern Chinese poetics through the filter of international poetics—but if this is the case, then should translation of classical and modern poetry into English be more similar than they are? Looking at Lydia Liu’s notion of the “supersign” alongside my experiences translating contemporary poets Ouyang Jianghe and Xi Chuan as well as Tang dynasty poet Li Shangyin, I discuss what I call “weak interpretations” and “strong interpretations” and how they play out in the translational alignment of classical and modern Chinese poetry with poetry in English today
fieldOfStudy: English, Chinese Poetry, Translation Studies, Comparative Poetics
summary: This article explores the relationship between classical and modern Chinese poetry, particularly concerning their translation into English. The author examines whether modern Chinese poetry functions as a translation of premodern Chinese poetics through an international lens. Drawing on Lydia Liu's "supersign" concept and experiences translating poets like Ouyang Jianghe, Xi Chuan, and Li Shangyin, the paper introduces "weak interpretations" and "strong interpretations." It discusses how these interpretative approaches influence the alignment of classical and modern Chinese poetry when translated into English, offering insights into translation studies and comparative poetics.

title: From Cambridge to Brighton: Concrete poetry in Britain, an interview with Stephen Bann
abstract: Extensive interview with art historian, curator and concrete poet Stephen Bann by Gustavo Grandal Montero, focusing particularly on his curatorial, critical and artistic work of the 1960s, closely involved with the development of Concrete poetry in the UK. Associated at an early stage with Ian Hamilton Finlay, he co-organized the First International Exhibition of Concrete and Kinetic Poetry (Cambridge, 1964) and was Director of the Concrete Poetry Exhibition for the inaugural Brighton Festival in 1967, edited Concrete poetry: an international anthology 1967 and published several influential critical texts, while developing his own Concrete poetry practice
publisher: Impact Press at the Centre for Fine Print Research, UWE
fieldOfStudy: English Poetry, Art History, Concrete Poetry
summary: This extensive interview with art historian, curator, and concrete poet Stephen Bann by Gustavo Grandal Montero focuses on Bann's critical, artistic, and curatorial work during the 1960s, particularly his involvement with Concrete poetry in the UK. Key activities included co-organizing the First International Exhibition of Concrete and Kinetic Poetry (Cambridge, 1964), directing the Concrete Poetry Exhibition for the inaugural Brighton Festival (1967), editing an international anthology, and publishing influential critical texts alongside his own poetry practice. The discussion provides insights into the development and international exchanges within Concrete poetry.

title: Some development in Urdu poetry since 1936
abstract: This work is devoted to discuss the developments in Urdu poetry since 1936.A brief account of the developments in poetical language, various verse-forms and themes of Urdu poetry till Iqbal (1877-1938) has been given in the introductory chapter. The second chapter is on the poetical language of Urdu poetry. In it, the Influence of English language, the use of Hindi words and phrases and the employment of colloquial vocabulary in Urdu poetry of the last thirty years is discussed at some length. In the third chapter on metres, a general account of the use of metres in Urdu poetry is given. In addition, some recent attempts to write poetry with disregard to metres are discussed, a "relative frequency table of metres" is also prepared and Included in this chapter. The fourth chapter deals with various traditional and new verse-forms of Urdu poetry. They are both defined and distinguished from each other. In the fifth and sixth chapters, a number of themes of Urdu poetry since 1936, such as the influence of Communism, the Independence of the sub-Continent of India and Pakistan and its aftermath. Communal Riots of 1947, writings on social evils and customs and on peace and war, historical and allegorical themes, humorous and satirical poetry, the influence of religion, recent Indo-Pakistani War, and psychological themes Including sex, escapism, scepticism, an Individual’s predicaments, imprisonment of the present moment and so on are discussed at length The final chapter is that of the conclusion
summary: This work explores the developments in Urdu poetry since 1936, analyzing shifts in poetical language, verse-forms, and themes. It provides an introductory account of Urdu poetry's evolution until Iqbal (1877-1938), then delves into the influence of English and Hindi languages, and colloquial vocabulary in recent Urdu poetry. The study also discusses metrical usage, including attempts to disregard traditional metres and presents a "relative frequency table of metres." Furthermore, it defines and distinguishes traditional and new verse-forms. Key themes since 1936 are examined, such as the impact of Communism, the Independence of India and Pakistan, communal riots, social issues, peace and war, historical and allegorical narratives, humorous and satirical poetry, religious influences, and psychological themes including sex, escapism, scepticism, and individual predicaments.

title: [Review of] Bienvenido L. Lumbera. Tagalog Poetry: 1570-1898
abstract: Bienvenido Lumbera, in his Preface to this survey of Tagalog poetry, apologizes for the shortcomings of his book. Originally written twenty years ago as a doctoral dissertation, it does not take into account new information on Tagalog poetry and its discussion of precolonial poetry does not include new data on the oral poetry of contemporary Filipino groups.  I have bailed myself out,  say Lumbera,  by persuading myself that many scholarly sins could be forgiven under the rubric of \u27pioneering.\u27\u27\u27 And indeed these omissions can be forgiven for what the reader gains in return is a pioneering study describing and analyzing the development of Tagalog poetry
fieldOfStudy: English Asian American Studies South African History Music History
summary: This document features a review of Bienvenido Lumbera's survey of Tagalog poetry, acknowledging its pioneering nature despite being a twenty-year-old dissertation with some omissions regarding new data on oral and precolonial poetry. It also critiques "The Forbidden Stitch: An Asian American Women's Anthology," highlighting its comprehensive selection of prose, poetry, essays, and reviews by diverse Asian American writers, emphasizing their differences rather than homogenizing them. Additionally, it provides a brief overview of Miriam Makeba's autobiography, noting how her personal narrative intertwines with African history, particularly the struggle against prejudice in South Africa, and her use of music to advocate for her people.

title: My Perfect Picture: You
abstract: Poetry by Joplin Finfrock. Finalist in the 2018 Manuscripts Poetry Contest
summary: This poem, a finalist in the 2018 Manuscripts Poetry Contest, explores themes of creation, perception, and lasting impact through the metaphor of developing a photographic print. The speaker describes the darkroom process, likening an emerging image to a person or feeling, questioning its arrival and development. The poem concludes with the realization that the speaker's touch, a 'smudge of charcoal black,' permanently alters the perceived 'perfect picture,' highlighting the indelible mark of interaction and emotional imprint. Keywords: poetry contest, photography metaphor, emotional impact, perception, creation.

title: The child says nothing, but what it heard by the fire
abstract: Poetry by Tyrah Chery. Second place in the 2019 Manuscripts Poetry Contest
summary: This poem by Tyrah Chery, awarded second place in the 2019 Manuscripts Poetry Contest, explores a deep, ancestral relationship with death. The speaker personifies death, depicting it as a constant presence throughout the history of their ancestors, from the slave ships to moments of conflict and independence. Despite not having personally experienced death, the speaker acknowledges its intimate familiarity, suggesting an inherited knowledge and lingering presence within their matriarchal lineage. The work is a powerful reflection on legacy, suffering, and the pervasive influence of historical trauma.

title: The universality of poetry in Aristotle’s Poetics
abstract:
This paper considers three questions arising out of Aristotle's statement that poetry is concerned with the universal. First, what does it mean? Secondly, what constraints does it impose on the construction of (in particular) tragic plots? This question is considered with special reference to the possible role of chance in tragedy. Thirdly, why is poetry concerned with the universal— that is, why is poetry such that these constraints are appropriate?





In chapter 9 of the Poetics Aristotle states that poetry is concerned with the universal. In this paper I shall consider three questions arising out of this statement. First, what does it mean? Secondly, what constraints does it impose on the construction of (in particular) tragic plots? I shall consider this question with special reference to the possible role of chance in tragedy. Thirdly, why is poetry concerned with the universal—that is, why is poetry such that these constraints are appropriate
summary: This paper examines Aristotle's assertion in *Poetics* that poetry is concerned with the universal. It addresses three core questions: the meaning of Aristotle's statement, the constraints it imposes on constructing tragic plots (specifically regarding the role of chance), and the underlying reasons why poetry necessitates these universal constraints. The analysis delves into philosophical implications, particularly in relation to tragedy and other poetic genres like epic and comedy, arguing for the intrinsic superiority of universalizing genres.

title: Poetry's total scandal:Poets and postmen in Antonio Skármeta’s El cartero de Neruda
abstract: The argument put forward here takes Antonio Skármeta's short novel El cartero de Neruda (Con ardiente paciencia) as a theorization of the relationship between poetry and politics, by way of the concept-metaphors (Mieke Bal) that are deployed in the novel. Skármeta stages the public role of poetry through the telling of a story about the poet Pablo Neruda and his postman Mario Jiménez. The relationship between poetry and politics is analysed with reference to Hazard Adams' concept of «the offense of poetry» and Roland Barthes' reflections on the total scandal of language in his essay «Écrivains et écrivants» (1964), here adapted as «the total scandal of poetry». In contradistinction to Barthes, who argues that the total scandal of language is impossible because of the absorption of scandalous language by the literary institution, Skármeta's short novel suggests that the total scandal of poetry is indeed possible when, as in the case of Pablo Neruda, Mario Jiménez and Salvador Allende, poetry becomes a constitutive part of a political project, within which it functions as a reminder of dignity and as the touchstone for political integrity
summary: This article theorizes the intricate relationship between poetry and politics by analyzing Antonio Skármeta's novel *El cartero de Neruda*. It uses Mieke Bal's concept-metaphors to explore how Skármeta portrays poetry's public function through the story of Pablo Neruda and his postman, Mario Jiménez. The study references Hazard Adams' "offense of poetry" and Roland Barthes' "total scandal of language," adapting the latter to "the total scandal of poetry." Contrary to Barthes' view that literary institutions absorb scandalous language, the article posits that poetry can achieve a "total scandal" when it becomes integral to a political project, embodying dignity and political integrity, as exemplified by Neruda, Jiménez, and Salvador Allende.

title: Workshop Poetry
summary: This article, "Workshop Poetry," explores the significant influence of university writing workshops on poets published in the 1970s. The author, Alan Soldofsky, reflects on how apprentices learned by imitating their teachers, acquiring technical skills and aesthetic values that shaped their poetics. Soldofsky recounts assisting Robert Bly in editing a nature poetry anthology, highlighting the impact of figures like Daniel Halpern and influential anthologies. The piece also reviews various poetry collections, noting characteristics such as surrealism, “Language” poetry, evocative power, and unique rhythmic patterns, offering insights into contemporary poetic trends and literary influences.

title: Poetry, Gender and Teaching: Building Students’ Character through Multicultural Literature
abstract: This paper is aimed to explore the concern of gender in teaching poetry as an effort to build student’s character through multicultural literature. The students’ success in life is based on 80% of their soft skill. This is in line with the objective of teaching literature that focuses on developing the affective side of the students. Gender problem is one of the crucial and complicated issues in contemporary multicultural society. Gender issues cover various disciplines; literature and education are among them. These multicultural circumstances, including gender, are portrayed in poetry of multicultural poet’s background. This can be used as rich and inspiring resources for teaching poetry and is valuable for developing students’ character that gets weak from time to time. This weakening condition is caused by the teaching method focusing on developing more and more the cognitive side of the students. Poetry and literature in general, bears human soul that touches four elements of human being: intellectual, sense, imagination and emotion. Thus, teaching poetry can develop gender awareness of the students to prepare themselves be persons with strong character to live in contemporary life which are full of gender problems
fieldOfStudy: English Literature Education Multiculturalism Gender Studies
summary: This paper explores the role of gender in teaching poetry to foster student character through multicultural literature, highlighting that soft skills constitute 80% of life success and are central to literature education's affective goals. It argues that contemporary society's complex gender issues, as depicted in multicultural poetry, offer rich resources for developing students' character, which is often neglected by cognitive-focused teaching methods. By engaging with poetry's intellectual, sensory, imaginative, and emotional elements, students can cultivate gender awareness and build strong characters essential for navigating contemporary gender-related challenges.

title: Poetry Is Poetry Is Poetry
summary: This text reviews Joseph T. Thomas, Jr.'s "Poetry's Playground: The Culture of Contemporary American Children's Poetry," which explores children's poetry as a serious subfield of mainstream American poetry. Thomas's work aims to dissolve unproductive boundaries between children's literature and adult poetry scholarship, highlighting how both fields have overlooked significant connections. The review praises the book's groundbreaking approach to integrating diverse ideas and showing how American poetry is impoverished by categorical segregation. It argues for the book's potential as a foundational text for scholars of American poetry, emphasizing children's poetry's role as a living tradition.

title: Code of Best Practices in Fair Use for Poetry
abstract: Outlines best practices created by the poetry community for using copyrighted materials in parody and satire; "remixed" new works; education; criticism, comment, or illustration; poetry online; and literary performance. Lists principles and limitations
publisher: Center for Social Media at American University
fieldOfStudy: English, Poetry, Copyright Law, Fair Use, New Media
summary: This document outlines best practices for poets using copyrighted material under fair use principles, developed by the poetry community in collaboration with copyright experts. It addresses applications in parody, satire, remixed works, education, criticism, online poetry, and literary performance. The impetus for these guidelines stemmed from a broader conversation about poetry's place in new media, aiming to remove obstacles for poets publishing in both new and traditional formats. Key findings include principles and limitations for fair use, promoting broader access to poetry. This resource is valuable for poets, editors, and publishers navigating copyright in the digital age.

title: Poetry Department Line One Please! Poetry Department Line One!
summary: This document features a poem titled "Poetry Department Line One Please! Poetry Department Line One!" by Jeff Wills, originally published in Amaranthus, Vol. 1975, Issue 2. The poem explores themes of seeking authentic connection and beauty, described as "music for my eyes" and a love "not under covers or hidden behind enemy lines." It expresses dissatisfaction with superficiality, lamenting "grime between the lines" and "broken poetry panes," and a struggle to reach a higher plane of poetic expression. The text includes a table of contents or page references, indicating its publication as part of a larger collection.

It argues that contemporary teaching methods, which prioritize cognitive development, neglect the affective side crucial for soft skills and character. By utilizing poetry from multicultural backgrounds, educators can address gender inequality and foster stronger student character for living in a complex, multicultural society. The study emphasizes poetry's ability to engage intellect, sense, imagination, and emotion, preparing students to navigate pervasive gender-related issues.

title: Forms of World Literature and the Taipei Poetry Festival
abstract: In poetry anthologies and works of literary criticism, the authority to select which literature can become “world” literature often lies with a single editor or theorist. This essay contrasts those centralizations of authority with the more egalitarian structure of international poetry festivals. Using the 2016 Taipei Poetry Festival as an example, the essay reads the impact of the form of the festival on its audience’s experience of translation, the local in the transnational, and intercultural solidarity. The essay then argues that boredom is a formal flaw in contemporary festivals, and advocates that translations be performed in local vernaculars
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, Poetry, Literary Criticism, Translation Studies
summary: This essay critically examines the authority structures in establishing "world literature," contrasting the centralized nature of anthologies with the more egalitarian international poetry festival format. Using the 2016 Taipei Poetry Festival as a case study, it analyzes the festival's impact on audience experience regarding translation, local identity within transnational contexts, and intercultural solidarity. The author identifies boredom as a formal flaw in contemporary festivals and advocates for performing translations in local vernaculars, offering insights into world poetry, literary criticism, and translation studies.

title:
Squeezing, bleaching, and the victims’ fate:

wounds, geography, poetry, micrology
abstract: This article opens a dialogue between geohumanities and poetry—or, more broadly, creative writing—around the subject matters of violence and wounding. It considers what kinds of “poetry” might be usefully enrolled by the geoliterary critic, or even authored by the geographer-poet, in response to such subject matters. Difficult questions abound about what it means to author, hear, and read poetry that is engaged and enraged by instances of violence, trauma, and victimhood. One horizon for these questions is Adorno’s ([1966] 1973) claim that “there can be no more poetry after Auschwitz,” and more particularly his elaboration and partial retreat from this claim in Negative Dialectics. Here, wary of attempts “at squeezing any kind of sense, however bleached, out of the victims’ fate” (Adorno [1966] 1973, 361), he nonetheless concluded that “perennial suffering has as much right to expression as a tortured man to scream; hence it may be wrong to say that after Auschwitz you can no longer write poems” (363). This article explores Adorno’s position, chiefly pursuing his arguments about the need for poetry—and indeed philosophy—that strives not for “purity” but precisely to be “soiled” and “spoiled,” never comforting, always disconcerting, never idealistically “transcendent,” always materialistically “micrological.” Including reference to a short story by Borges and critique of poetry by the geographer Wreford Watson, the argument is further advanced by attending to Adorno’s claims about another poet, Heine, sometimes regarded as a particularly “geographical” poet. The article concludes with final notes on possible implications for recasting work on wounded geographies as a species of applied micrology
fieldOfStudy: English, Geohumanities, Poetry, Literary Criticism, Trauma Studies
summary: This article explores the intersection of geohumanities and poetry, specifically addressing the themes of violence and wounding. It examines what forms of poetry a geoliterary critic or geographer-poet might utilize in response to trauma, drawing on Adorno's evolving claim about "no more poetry after Auschwitz." The paper pursues Adorno's arguments for a "soiled" and "micrological" poetry that avoids comfort and idealism, referencing Borges and critiquing Wreford Watson. It also considers Heine as a "geographical" poet, concluding with implications for recasting wounded geographies as applied micrology.

title: When Poetry and Humor Get Hitched
abstract: Through humor, poetry explores the imagination and the mind just as it does through other means of expression. Comic poetry finds the truth in the illogical and in the absurd; it finds what unsettles us through its use of surprise; it finds delight and play in the unknown and uncertain. By its very nature, comic poetry clings to the edges of what we know, so pinpointing its characteristics is tricky. But the shared characteristic of all comic poetry is the permission the poet grants herself to disobey boundaries. The poet chooses not to fit her works within the reader’s expectations, the reader’s sense of logic, or the reader’s definitions of things in the world. Some of the boundaries crossed come out of breaking out of poetic custom. Many poems break boundaries of thought and expression; a comic poet uses one or more of these techniques to bring her funny poems to profound places. The result is always the exploration of unexplored or underexplored territory
summary: This thesis explores how humor functions in poetry, arguing that comic poetry, like other expressive forms, delves into imagination and the mind. It posits that comic verse reveals truth in the illogical and absurd, using surprise to unsettle readers and finding delight in uncertainty. The core characteristic of comic poetry is the poet's deliberate transgression of boundaries—reader expectations, logic, and definitions. By breaking poetic customs and challenging conventional thought, comic poets explore profound, often underexplored territories of human experience. This analysis offers insights into the unique expressive power and semantic search keywords for poetry, humor, literary theory, and comic verse.

title: Politics and contemporary poetry
abstract:
The paper is a Meditation (variant on the manner of Aurelius and

Descartes) concerning the immediate situation, in the United States, of

poetry as a discourse of political engagement. As such, the paper is

a highly personal one. It means to offer an account of the peculiar

limits within which contemporary poetry in the United States is forced

to get carried on, as well as an explanation of the context in which

those limits were defined. It also suggests possible ways to exploit

the special resources of contemporary poetry (formally and socially

conceived) for political discourse and social critique. The paper is

most centrally concerned to illuminate the special kinds of critical

reflection which contemporary poetry, by virtue of its marginal

position, makes available. The paper's two main sections involve

the author's own reflexive analysis of his encounters with certain

texts by Hans Magnus Enzensberger, Theodor Adorno, and Carolyn Forche
summary: This paper, presented as a personal meditation akin to Aurelius and Descartes, explores the contemporary state of poetry as a form of political engagement in the United States. It delineates the specific limitations imposed on modern American poetry and the historical context that shaped these constraints. The author proposes strategies to leverage the unique formal and social resources of contemporary poetry for political discourse and social critique. Primarily, the paper illuminates the critical reflections made possible by poetry's marginal position, drawing on the author's analyses of texts by Hans Magnus Enzensberger, Theodor Adorno, and Carolyn Forché.

title: Aesthetic Worlds: Rimbaud, Williams and Baroque Form
abstract: The sense of form that provides the modern poet with a unique experience of the literary object has been crucial to various attempts to compare poetry to other cultural activities. In maintaining similar conceptions of the relationship between poetry and painting, Arthur Rimbaud and W. C. Williams establish a common basis for interpreting their creative work. And yet their poetry is more crucially concerned with the sudden emergence of visible "worlds" containing verbal objects that integrate a new kind of literary text. This paper discusses the emergence of "aesthetic worlds" in the work of both poets and then examines how a common concern with Baroque form unites them  in the phenomenological task of overcoming Cartesian dualism
summary: This paper examines how Arthur Rimbaud and W. C. Williams establish a common basis for interpreting their creative work by maintaining similar conceptions of the relationship between poetry and painting. The study discusses the emergence of visible "worlds" containing verbal objects that integrate a new kind of literary text in their poetry. It explores how a shared concern with Baroque form unites them in the phenomenological task of overcoming Cartesian dualism, focusing on Rimbaud's Illuminations and Williams' Spring and All. This analysis challenges biases against Rimbaud in modern criticism.

title: “And it’s just when I think I’ve won the staring contest”: Viewing the World through Science and Poetry with Madhur Anand
abstract: In this interview, poet and ecologist Madhur Anand discusses her collection of poetry, A New Index for Predicting Catastrophes, with Alec Follett. She considers the poetic potential of scientific language as well as other topics related to her poetry and her research including field guides, biodiversity, and socio-ecological relationships
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, Poetry, Ecology, Critical and Cultural Studies
summary: This interview features poet and ecologist Madhur Anand discussing her poetry collection, "A New Index for Predicting Catastrophes," with Alec Follett. The discussion explores the intersection of scientific language and poetic expression, alongside themes prevalent in her work and research. Key topics include field guides, biodiversity, and complex socio-ecological relationships. The conversation highlights Anand's unique perspective on viewing the world through both scientific and poetic lenses, emphasizing how these seemingly disparate fields can converge to foster deeper understanding and connection.

title: My English poetry
abstract: Some of Professor Joseph Aquilina's poems in English have been published sporadically in various numbers ofThe Journal of the Faculty of Arts of the University of Malta and in the press, both during his lifetime and after. The present paper includes the text ofan unpublished lecture the author gave in the 1970s in which he spoke about his poetic works in English, how they were conceived, and about their place in Maltese literature and Commonwealth literature. Some of these poems are being reproducedfor the first time.peer-reviewe
summary: This paper presents an unpublished lecture by Professor Joseph Aquilina from the 1970s, discussing his English poetic works, their conceptualization, and their significance within both Maltese and Commonwealth literature. The lecture provides insight into Aquilina's creative process and the cultural context of his poetry. Some of these poems are reproduced for the first time, offering new access to his oeuvre. Keywords include Joseph Aquilina, Maltese poetry, Commonwealth literature, and English language poems.

title: Bohdan Boichuk’s Childhood Reveries: A Migrant’s Nostalgia, or, Documenting Pain in Poetry
abstract:
This paper examines Bohdan Boichuk’s poetry by looking into the role his childhood
          memories played in forming his poetic imagination. Displaced by World War II, the
          poet displays a unique capacity to transcend his traumatic experiences by engaging in creative writing. Eyewitnessing war atrocities perpetrated by the Nazis does not destroy his belief in the healing power of poetry; on the contrary, it makes him appreciate poetry as the only existentially worthy enterprise. Invoking Gaston Bachelard’s classic work The Poetics of Reveries: Childhood, Language, and the Cosmos, I argue that Boichuk’s vivid childhood memories, however painful they might be, helped him poetically recreate and reimagine fateful moments of his migrant life
summary: This paper analyzes Bohdan Boichuk's poetry, focusing on how his childhood memories, shaped by World War II displacement and trauma, influenced his poetic imagination. It argues that witnessing war atrocities did not destroy his belief in poetry's healing power; rather, it affirmed its existential value. Drawing on Gaston Bachelard's "The Poetics of Reveries," the study posits that Boichuk's vivid, though painful, childhood memories enabled him to poetically recreate and reimagine crucial moments of his migrant life. Key themes include war and poetry, childhood memories, migrant displacement, and the work of Bohdan Boichuk and Gaston Bachelard.

title: Poems for My Woofie The Story of Lt. Wilfred V. Michaud, 1st Parachute Battalion, 1st Marine Division
abstract: My senior capstone project is the creation of a book of investigative poetry. The subject of the work is my grandfather, Wilfred V. Michaud. He was a lieutenant in the United States Marine Corps during World War II. The poetry addresses the history of Michaud’s battalion and the battles it fought, as well as personal stories of Michaud’s life and experience in the service. Several secondary sources were used to gain historical context for the poetry. Additionally, primary sources were used to provide information about Michaud’s personal experiences. The combination of primary and secondary sources established the necessary background and inspiration for the project
summary: This senior capstone project presents a book of investigative poetry centered on Wilfred V. Michaud, a U.S. Marine Corps lieutenant during World War II. The work explores the history of his battalion, battles, and personal experiences, drawing on both primary and secondary sources to provide historical context and personal insights. The author, despite a background in actuarial mathematics and no formal poetry training, embarked on this creative endeavor to better understand her grandfather's life and ensure his stories endure through the poetic narrative. The project combines historical research with personal reflection to craft a unique biographical account.

title: Two Poems
abstract: Poetry by Dan MacIsaa
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, Critical and Cultural Studies, Nature and Society Relations, Place and Environment
summary: This article presents two poems by Dan MacIsaac: "Cheetah in 60 Seconds" and "Timing the Cheetah." The first poem vividly depicts a cheetah's hunt for a springbok across the veldt, focusing on the predator's speed, agility, and the brutal culmination of the chase. The second poem shifts focus to the existential struggle of the cheetah, linking its speed to a race against extinction and the challenges faced in a changing environment. Both poems explore themes of nature, survival, and environmental concerns through evocative imagery and rhythmic language, serving as poetic contributions to critical and cultural studies.

title: Liminal
abstract: Poetry by Jessica Benzing
summary: This poem by Jessica Benzing explores an unexpected moment of intimacy and vulnerability arising from a shared experience of poorly laid plans. The speaker confesses a profound, yet occasional, love for another person, likening it to the sensory experience of "rain boiling in the sky." The narrative reveals a surprising reciprocation of these feelings, highlighted by the other person's keen desire to understand the speaker deeply. The piece delves into themes of unexpected connection, emotional confession, and the surprising depth found in casual interactions.

title: Descent into Peargatory
abstract: Poetry Contest, Honorable Mentio
summary: This poetic work, an honorable mention in a poetry contest, presents a metaphorical exploration of a 'peargatory,' distinct from the traditional 'purgatory' associated with an 'original sin.' The poem uses the imagery of a pear—described as dappled, woman-like, fragile, and female—to evoke sensory experiences and suggest a unique form of descent. It alludes to literary figures like H.D., Gertrude Stein, and Ernest Hemingway, implying a broader cultural or literary commentary. Key themes include sensory perception, temptation, femininity, and a reinterpretation of classic narratives.

title: Golden Hour
abstract: Poetry by Tyrah Chery
summary: This poetic work by Tyrah Chery explores themes of ancestral wisdom, cultural memory, and the impact of the American Dream on personal identity. Through vivid imagery of a grandmother's blessings during 'golden hour' and the superstitions passed down through generations, the poem delves into the protagonist's relationship with their heritage. It highlights how prophecies and prayers are woven into their being, emphasizing the enduring nature of scars and the importance of remembering past injustices, even when others forget. Keywords include ancestral wisdom, cultural identity, memory, American Dream, poetry, and storytelling.

title: Lost Bobbies
abstract: Poetry by Viki Tomanov
summary: This abstract poetry piece, "Lost Bobbies" by Viki Tomanov, uses the metaphor of bobby pins as soldiers in a war to explore themes of rigidity, resilience, and eventual loss. The 'soldiers' initially stand at attention, performing their duty to secure hair, described with product-like qualities. However, their rigidity is ultimately unsustainable, leading to their disappearance. The poem evokes imagery of a losing battle and the transient nature of control, making it relevant for search queries on modern poetry, metaphorical language, and themes of transience.

title: water.under
abstract: Poetry by JR Carpente
fieldOfStudy: English, Critical and Cultural Studies, Literature in English North America, Nature and Society Relations, Place and Environment, Poetry
summary: This article presents J. R. Carpenter's experimental poem "water.under," published in The Goose. The poem explores themes of communication failure across disparate mediums, including land mammals, computers, and oceans. Carpenter's work involves an iterative and performative writing process, often incorporating digital and hypermedia narratives. A version of this text was performed during The South West Poetry Tour, highlighting its multimodal nature. The piece delves into the sonic and conceptual connections between water, sound transmission, and technological interaction, reflecting Carpenter's broader artistic practice in digital literature and performance.

title: Integrating multiple representations: fighting asthma
abstract: This paper seeks to engage debates about integrating pluralisms regarding multiple forms/representations and how they might function smoothly if they are closely aligned. This paper offers, narrative poetry with an artistic impression aimed at seeing how these might interact with each other. Like poetry, visual images are unique and can evoke particular kinds of emotional and visceral responses. By offering narrative poetry together with an artistic representation it is not meant to de-value the importance of either, but it is aimed at seeing how these arts-based methods and creative analytical practices might unite as a narrative to offer knew ways of ‘knowing’ and ‘seeing
fieldOfStudy: English, narrative poetry, narrative art, creative analytical practices
summary: This paper explores the integration of pluralisms across multiple forms and representations, focusing on how narrative poetry and artistic impressions can interact effectively. It proposes using arts-based methods and creative analytical practices, such as narrative poetry combined with visual art, to offer novel ways of 'knowing' and 'seeing'. The work aims to engage debates on smooth functioning alignment, emphasizing the unique emotional and visceral responses evoked by both poetry and visual images. This approach seeks to unify these distinct art forms into a cohesive narrative, facilitating deeper understanding and combating asthma.

title: Poetry Editorial: Audioecopoetics
abstract: Poetry Editorial by Camilla Nelso
fieldOfStudy: English, Critical and Cultural Studies, Literature in English North America, Nature and Society Relations, Place and Environment
summary: This poetry editorial, "Audioecopoetics" by Camilla Nelson, explores the concept of 'audioecopoetics' through a reflective and personal narrative, drawing inspiration from Timothy Morton's works, specifically "Ecology Without Nature" (2007) and "The Ecological Thought" (2010). The author encourages readers to engage with the auditory aspects of their environment, emphasizing the importance of listening to how the world forms. This piece advocates for a deeper sonic awareness of ecological systems and the relationship between sound and environment.

title: Can We Say an Ear of Cabbage : On Translating Wordplay in Xi Xi’s Poetry
abstract: This article reflects on the translation of wordplay in the poetry of Hong Kong author Xi Xi. Xi Xi is a highly imaginative poet: much of her poetry hinges upon specificities of the Chinese language, and one might well ask if this makes her work “untranslatable.” This article identifies various techniques for translating Xi Xi’s wordplay, detailing how I mine the potential of English for ways to recreate Xi Xi’s puns, puzzles, and playful subversion of language in a new linguistic and cultural environment. It encourages readers and translators to become unshackled from rules, assumptions, and conventions as they reflect on the malleability and potential of poetry and of language itself
fieldOfStudy: English, Poetry, Translation Studies, Chinese Literature
summary: This article explores techniques for translating wordplay in the poetry of Hong Kong author Xi Xi, whose imaginative work often relies on specificities of the Chinese language. It addresses the perceived "untranslatability" of such elements, detailing methods to leverage English's potential to recreate Xi Xi's puns, puzzles, and linguistic subversion within a new cultural context. The study encourages translators to challenge conventional rules and assumptions, reflecting on the malleability of poetry and language itself to maintain faithfulness to a playful source text, even if it means being "unfaithful" to literal semantic meanings.

title: ANALISIS GAYA DENGAN PENDEKATAN STILISTIKA PADA PUISI A VALEDICTION: FORBIDDING MOURNING KARYA JOHN DONNE
abstract: Stylistics as the study of style is a sort of approach which is rarely used. In this occasion, the writer would like to employ stylistics to analyze the style of A Valediction: Forbidding Mourning written by John Donne. The unsure of style in this poem, then, will be scrutinized to prove whether it is proper or not with the characteristics of metaphysical poetry which is designed by John Donne himself. Among three views which are developed in stylistics –monism, dualism, and pluralism-, the writer follows the monism one. This view is chosen because it is applicable to analyze poetry. Meanwhile, between two sorts of methods which are so possible to employ in operating stylistics –qualitative and quantitative-, the writer agrees with the qualitative one. This method is chosen due to its higher possibility to result in a comprehensive analysis. Related to the case of standpoint, the writer starts with the ground of appreciation to the poetry which is analyzed. Later on, the writer does multilevel approach to identify the unsure of style in A Valediction: Forbidding Mourning.  Based on the analysis of the poem, both hypotheses do work. Firstly, as the designer of metaphysical poetry, practically, the works of John Donne contain the characteristics of this sort of poetry. Secondly, applying stylistics, it can be seen how linguistics and literary study work in team
summary: This study employs stylistics, specifically the monism view and a qualitative multilevel approach, to analyze the style of John Donne's poem "A Valediction: Forbidding Mourning." The purpose is to determine if the poem's style aligns with the characteristics of metaphysical poetry, for which Donne is renowned. The analysis confirms two hypotheses: Donne's works indeed embody the traits of metaphysical poetry, and stylistics effectively demonstrates the interplay between linguistics and literary study. This research contributes to understanding poetic style and its categorization.

title: Law and Poetry
fieldOfStudy: English, Law and Poetry, Culture, Language
summary: This article explores the curious but intriguing relationship between law and poetry, arguing that they share significant commonalities as human creations of imagination and ingenuity, communicating through language to provide order and structure to daily life. Both reflect and reshape culture, offering insights into the human condition. The authors contend that understanding poetry is crucial for a deeper understanding of the cultural forces that influence law. This interdisciplinary approach, examining law's "underside" through cultural phenomena like poetry, can lead to new understandings of law's operation within culture and enhance the role of legal practitioners as "translators of law's meanings."

title: Summer People
abstract: Poetry by Claire Christoff
summary: This poem, "Summer People" by Claire Christoff, offers a critical perspective on individuals who embrace the summer season. The speaker describes them as people who shed warm clothing, expose themselves to the sun with SPF, and prefer iced coffee and stevia. They are depicted congregating at pools, laughing at parties, and enjoying grilled meat and cocktails, seemingly oblivious to the impending arrival of September. The poem uses vivid imagery and a somewhat sardonic tone to portray these 'summer people' and their seasonal habits.

title:
On the coexistence and complementarity of Chinese translation

methods of English metrical poetry
abstract:
The Chinese translation of English metrical poetry has a history of more than one

hundred years, but it is still controversial on how to translate English metrical poetry into

Chinese. Chinese translators have hitherto devised three methods to render English

metrical poetry: sinolization, liberalization, and poetic form transplantation. Translators

practicing the methods of sinolization and liberalization belong to the group in favor of

spiritual resemblance. Translators who follow the method of poetic form transplantation

belong to the group in favor of formal resemblance. It is quite obvious that the two

groups have disagreement on the translation standard or guiding principle. Actually the

translation standards of the two groups can coexist, and the translation methods under the

guidance of these different translation standards can coexist and complement each other.

It is impractical and impossible to use one Chinese translation method or standard to

guide all the Chinese translation practice, and the diverse Chinese translation methods of

English metrical poetry can coexist and complement each other in the foreseeable future
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, Translation Studies, Chinese Poetry
summary: This paper examines the century-long debate surrounding the Chinese translation of English metrical poetry, identifying three principal methods: sinolization, liberalization, and poetic form transplantation. Translators are categorized into groups prioritizing spiritual resemblance (sinolization, liberalization) or formal resemblance (poetic form transplantation). The study argues that these diverse translation standards and methods are not mutually exclusive but can coexist and complement each other, suggesting that it is impractical to enforce a single translation approach. Key concepts include translation standards, guiding principles, spiritual resemblance, and formal resemblance in poetry translation.

title: Reading poetry and its paratexts model users’ rights: Mary Dalton’s Hooking, cento poetics, and copyright law
abstract:
This draft paper focuses on Newfoundland poet Mary Dalton's 2013 book Hooking -- a collection of centos (poems composed only of lines from other poems) -- in order to propose a method for reading the exercise of users' rights in Canadian poetry by attending to poetry books' paratexts (front and end matter that acknowledges permissions or cites sources). This talk moves from an introductory discussion of users' rights enshrined in Canadian copyright law (e.g. fair dealing, the public domain) to a survey of poetry books, including Dalton's, and how their paratexts frame these books' transformative use of other works. The talk aims to promote a more widespread and robust exercise of users' rights in the service of cultural production and expressive freedom by showing the extent to which published authors, no less than users or readers, need fair dealing too.
(Posted for open review, this is a preliminary draft of a talk to be given at a workshop on cento poetry, held at the University of Bochum, Germany, in November 2020.
summary: This paper proposes a method for analyzing users' rights in Canadian poetry by examining paratexts, specifically focusing on Mary Dalton's 2013 book "Hooking." The study discusses Canadian copyright law, including fair dealing and public domain, and surveys how poetry book paratexts frame the transformative use of other works. It aims to encourage a broader exercise of users' rights for cultural production and expressive freedom, arguing that published authors also benefit from fair dealing. The research highlights Dalton's cento procedure, where each line is from a different poem, relating it to traditional Newfoundland rug-hooking as a metaphor for combining diverse materials. Key concepts include users' rights, Canadian copyright, cento poetry, paratexts, and transformative use.

title: The impact of the Netherlandish landscape tradition on poetry and painting in early modern England
abstract: Copyright © 2013 The University of Chicago Press.The relationship between poetry and painting has been one of the most debated issues in the history of criticism. The present article explores this problematic relationship in the context of sixteenth- and seventeenth-century England, taking into account theories of rhetoric, visual perception, and art. It analyzes a rare case in which a specific school of painting directly inspired poetry: in particular, the ways in which the Netherlandish landscape tradition influenced natural descriptions in the poem Poly-Olbion (1612, 1622) by Michael Drayton (1563–1631). Drayton — under the influence of the artistic principles of landscape depiction as explained in Henry Peacham’s art manuals, as well as of direct observation of Dutch and Flemish landscape prints and paintings — successfully managed to render pictorial landscapes into poetry. Through practical examples, this essay will thoroughly demonstrate that rhetoric is capable of emulating pictorial styles in a way that presupposes specialized art-historical knowledge, and that pictorialism can be the complex product as much of poetry and rhetoric as of painting and art-theoretical vocabulary
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, Art History, Renaissance Studies, Rhetoric
summary: This article explores the debated relationship between poetry and painting in sixteenth- and seventeenth-century England, focusing on the direct inspiration of Netherlandish landscape painting on Michael Drayton's poem "Poly-Olbion." It analyzes how Drayton, influenced by art manuals like Henry Peacham's and direct observation of Dutch and Flemish landscape prints, successfully translated pictorial landscapes into poetry. The essay demonstrates that rhetoric can emulate pictorial styles, necessitating art-historical knowledge, and that pictorialism is a complex product of poetry, rhetoric, painting, and art-theoretical vocabulary, challenging traditional views on the interplay of visual and literary arts.

title: Interlude of Ice Cubes
abstract: Poetry by Madeline Lucchetti
summary: This abstract features a poem by Madeline Lucchetti, titled "Interlude of Ice Cubes," which vividly describes a jazz club atmosphere. The poem uses sensory details to evoke the setting, from the sweaty brow under lamplight and the sounds of instruments to the grit in the keys and dust in the mufflers. It touches upon themes of music, illicit substances, and the raw, unpolished beauty of the scene, with imagery of soul sliding and secrets escaping a saxophone.

title: Emily in Plato\u27s Cave
abstract: Poetry Contest, First Plac
summary: This text, likely an excerpt from a creative work, combines a narrative about a dropped screw falling into a vat of zinc, a material said to be a creature's weakness, with a poem titled "Emily in Plato's Cave." The narrative features a character named Jimmy and Charley, a foreman, and hints at a fantastical element of a talking cap screw. The poem uses imagery from Plato's Allegory of the Cave, relating it to the pursuit of truth and the gradual nature of enlightenment, referencing Emily Dickinson. Keywords: poetry, narrative, fantasy, Plato's Cave, Emily Dickinson, zinc, truth, enlightenment.

title: Escargatoire
abstract: Poetry by Simon Orpan
summary: This article presents "Escargatoire," a poem by Simon Orpana, which uses the imagery of snails to explore themes of navigation, home, mysticism, and retreat. The poem describes snails' "supple skill" in navigating lavender, their spiral path as a "signature of pilgrims," and their ability to "secrete infinity." It highlights their collective behavior, their studious attention to nature, and their defensive retreat. Key concepts include natural movement, resilience, slow living, and collective identity, offering insights into human existence through the lens of the natural world.

title: Petrocan
abstract: Poetry by Madelaine Longma
fieldOfStudy: English, Literature in English, Critical and Cultural Studies, Nature and Society Relations, Place and Environment, Poetry
summary: This article presents "Petrocan," a poem by Madelaine C. Longman. The poem uses vivid imagery to explore themes of modern existence, self-perception, and the subtle discomforts of mundane environments like gas station bathrooms and urban landscapes. It employs sensory details, such as the taste of soap, the feel of sanitized air, and the visual distortion of pavement, to evoke a sense of detachment and observation. The work concludes with an appeal to listen to a more ancient, wordless speech, suggesting a deeper connection to nature amidst the urban sprawl. Keywords: poetry, modern existence, urban landscape, sensory imagery.

title: Sharp
abstract: Poetry by Kasey Kirchner
summary: This poem, "Sharp" by Kasey Kirchner, explores the internal conflict of a speaker who perceives themselves as a dangerous, weapon-like entity, despite denying their own sharpness. Through vivid imagery of blades, thorns, and serrated hands, the speaker describes inadvertently causing harm, cutting and piercing their surroundings. The poem delves into themes of inherent nature versus perceived intent, the burden of an uncontrollable destructive self, and the desperate plea for self-reassurance. Keywords: poetry, self-perception, internal conflict, destructive nature, imagery, modern poetry.

title: To Kathy
abstract: Poetry Contest, Honorable Mentio
summary: This poetry abstract includes an honorable mention and two poems. The first, "MANUSCRIPTS 19," explores themes of foresight, aloofness, grief, and a plea for forgiveness from a mother, possibly reflecting on lost potential or personal sorrow. The second poem, "TO KATHY," humorously depicts a man seeking loopholes in the Bible to enter Heaven with a sack of rum, suggesting a playful critique of religious dogmatism. Roy Marz's work is praised for its "loving attention to" the qualities of things, emphasizing the essential role of love in a poet's craft. Keywords: poetry, grief, spirituality, religious satire, love, aesthetic experience.

title: New Exhibit at the Zoo
abstract: Poetry by Matthew Del Busto
summary: This poem by Matthew Del Busto, titled "New Exhibit at the Zoo," explores themes of alienation and self-perception, likening the speaker's experience to that of a strange, non-human entity in a zoo exhibit. The speaker expresses a desire to be an inanimate object, like a pickled egg, but ultimately embraces their "prehensile tail" and "unwieldily opposable thumbs." The poem delves into feelings of being observed and judged, questioning identity, and the distance between oneself and others, using vivid imagery of a zoo setting.

title: I Won\u27t Turn Off the T.V.
abstract: Poetry, First Plac
summary: This text presents two distinct pieces: a narrative excerpt and a poem. The narrative, featuring characters Harve and Bif, describes a hunting encounter and a familial bond, hinting at themes of rural life and mentorship. The accompanying poem, "I Won't Turn Off The T.V." by Bruce Braden, explores themes of loneliness, companionship found in television, and the repetitive nature of human relationships, likening them to changing roles in shows. Keywords include poetry, narrative, loneliness, mentorship, and rural life.

title: Fairy Letters
abstract: Poetry by Brittan Semler
summary: This poetic piece, "Fairy Letters," explores the narrator's childhood belief in fairies, fostered by her mother's secret notes. It describes the vivid imagination of a child, the magic of discovery, and the bittersweet moment of realizing the truth behind the enchantment. The narrative reflects on the fading of childhood wonder, the subsequent sense of loss, and a later appreciation for the enduring love that created the fantasy. Keywords: childhood, imagination, fairies, poetry, mother-daughter relationship, nostalgia.

title: Two Poems
abstract: Poetry by Nicholas Bradle
fieldOfStudy: English Literature in English, North America, Poetry, Critical and Cultural Studies, Nature and Society Relations, Place and Environment
summary: This document presents two poems by Nicholas Bradley, exploring themes of environmental decline, human impact on nature, and the resilience of various species. Through vivid imagery and reflective language, the poems touch upon topics such as the plight of Puget Sound's killer whales, the absurdity of human existence in the face of ecological challenges, and the admiration for birds' unwavering behavior. The work offers a contemplative look at the interconnectedness of life and the environment, using literary devices to evoke a sense of urgency and wonder. Keywords: contemporary poetry, environmentalism, nature, wildlife, human-nature relations, ecopoetry, Nicholas Bradley.

title: A Graph of the Wind
abstract: Poetry by Sid Marty
summary: This poetry collection, "A Graph of the Wind" by Sid Marty, explores the profound and persistent forces of nature, particularly wind, as they sculpt the landscape and influence human perception. Through vivid imagery, the poems describe how elements like a bull pine tree are shaped by the wind's fury, likening its movement to an old woman or a drawing on the sky. The work delves into themes of natural power, time, memory, and the intricate connection between humans and their environment, reflecting on ancient influences and the enduring impact of natural phenomena. Sid Marty is known for his work as a writer, poet, and environmental activist.

title: Cranberry Picking Season
abstract: Poetry by Lois Beardsle
summary: This poem, "Cranberry Picking Season" by Lois Beardslee, explores themes of nurturing, generational burdens, and the passage of time through the metaphor of a "Folded-over Woman." She misses cranberry picking to cradle "mountains" (likely representing children or burdens), experiencing seasons of both hardship and brief respite. The work delves into the intersection of personal struggle, Indigenous perspectives, and the relentless cycle of nature and human experience, highlighting resilience and the weight of inherited responsibilities.

title: CPR Crash Course
abstract: Poetry by Aylin Malcolm
summary: This article presents "CPR Crash Course," a poem by Aylin Malcolm, which explores themes of interconnectedness, memory, and humanity's relationship with nature and industrialization. Through vivid imagery, the poem reflects on trains as metaphors for life's continuous movement, generational legacies within a railway family, and the enduring impact of human activity on the environment. It delves into the fragmentation of the universe, the oxygenation of cells, and the search for stillness amidst motion, ultimately questioning how to restore what has been broken. Key concepts include interconnectedness, industrialization, nature, memory, and restoration.

title: Bell in the Rain
abstract: Poetry by Annabel Bank
summary: This poem, "Bell in the Rain" by Annabel Banks, explores themes of environmental change and the loss of traditional ways of life, drawing intertextually on William Carlos Williams' "The Red Wheelbarrow" and Bronwyn Preece's "Isabel's Wheelbarrow." The work uses vivid imagery of wet landscapes, small-island living, and the impact of industrialization (engines taking copper, water from guiding channels) to convey a sense of decline and remembrance. It contrasts past beliefs in shelter and sustenance (chickens being fed) with a present reality of barrenness and unending pour of change, highlighting ecological and societal shifts.

title: The Essence of Hemlocks
abstract: Poetry by Haley Huelsman
summary: This poem by Haley Huelsman explores themes of pain, vulnerability, and a longing for release, using vivid imagery of nature. The speaker describes struggling through a harsh landscape, experiencing humiliation and a desire to escape a male figure. The imagery of 'hemlocks' and 'massive rocks' creates a sense of foreboding and entrapment, while the act of stripping seedlings and scratching against rocks emphasizes the speaker's anguish. Ultimately, the poem culminates in a plea for the figure to leave, allowing the speaker to 'wither' like the damaged hemlocks, before a final, cold address to 'listen.'

title: Blank Five
abstract: Poetry by Elizabeth Godwi
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, Poetry, Critical and Cultural Studies, Nature and Society Relations
summary: This article presents "Blank Five," a poem by Elizabeth Anne Godwin, published in The Goose. The poem evokes natural imagery, describing rain, flowers, snails, birds, and butterflies, using sensory details to create a vivid landscape. It explores themes of nature, observation, and perhaps transience, reflecting on how natural elements interact and change. The author, Elizabeth Jardine Godwin, is known for her creative and critical work focusing on the effects of landscape, building, and memory, and their influence on our relationship with built and unbuilt environments, with water and light being key elements in her research.

title: The plus nines of climate change
abstract: Poetry by Lucy Burnet
fieldOfStudy: English, Literature in English, Critical and Cultural Studies, Poetry
summary: This article presents a poem titled "The plus nines of climate change" by Lucy Burnett, which explores themes related to climate change through an experimental literary technique. Inspired by the OULIPO group, the author applies an "N+9 procedure," replacing every noun in an initial climate change-focused text with the noun nine places further in the dictionary. This method aims to generate new patterns and structures for approaching climatic change, offering a unique perspective on environmental concerns and the human response to them, integrating poetry with critical and cultural studies.

title: Counteredpoint
abstract: Poetry by Gary Barwi
fieldOfStudy: English, Literature in English, North America, Poetry
summary: This article presents "Counteredpoint," an audiopoem by Gary Barwin, which explores the anthropocene within a conceptual ecology, asserting the co-creation of human and non-human entities. The work investigates how our understanding of the world is shaped by both human and non-human agency, questioning the clear distinction between them. The audiopoem employs digitally processed text, voice synthesis, and audio elements derived from original sources, such as percussion sounds generated from textual data manipulation. This piece contributes to discussions in poetry, environmental humanities, and digital art.

title: Cramps
abstract: Poetry by Jessica Martorano
summary: This poem by Jessica Martorano uses the experience of menstrual pain as a metaphor for humanity's destructive relationship with Earth. The speaker describes intense physical suffering, contrasting it with the societal notion of childbirth as a "magical gift." This personal anguish is then paralleled with the Earth's slow poisoning by human actions, specifically oil pollution. The poem concludes by emphasizing the interconnectedness of humanity and nature, suggesting that harming the Earth is a form of self-destruction. Keywords: poetry, menstrual pain, environmentalism, metaphor, interconnectedness.

title: Regret
abstract: Poetry by Rachel Worley
summary: This poetry collection, primarily by Rachel Worley, explores themes of emotional aftermath and the struggles of moving on from past pain. The poems delve into the quietude following intense turmoil, the inner battles that persist despite external calm, and the difficulty of feigning happiness while grieving. Key concepts include regret, the persistence of memories, the challenge of reconciling past joy with present sadness, and the torment of looking back. The collection highlights the internal conflict inherent in emotional recovery and the passage of time.

title: Fever Palm
abstract: Poetry by Carol A. Alexander
summary: This poetry piece, "Fever Palm" by Carol A. Alexander, explores themes of ancient reckoning, desert imagery, environmental degradation, and the human condition in the face of harsh realities. Through vivid metaphors such as "fever palm" and "fins that Helios charred," the poem evokes a sense of thirst, suffering, and the passage of epochs. It delves into the interplay between mythical pasts and present struggles for survival, questioning how to live amidst adversity. The work culminates in a contemplation of resilience, contrasting the inevitability of decay with the will to endure. Key themes include environmentalism, mythology, human struggle, and the power of language.

title: Three Poems
abstract: Poetry by Scott Tarbuc
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, Poetry, Critical and Cultural Studies, Nature and Society Relations, Place and Environment
summary: This collection presents three poems by Scott T. Starbuck: "The Goose," "Blind Spot," and "Ant." The poems explore themes of personal experience, societal issues, and the natural world, often through vivid imagery and introspective narrative.
