"The Goose" metaphorically depicts a search for lost identity, while "Blind Spot" delves into the disturbing dynamics of domestic violence and denial. "Ant" offers a contemplative view on existence and perception. These works reflect Starbuck's broader engagement with eco-activist poetry and critical social commentary, inviting readers to consider profound human and environmental dilemmas.

title: Prayer
abstract: Poetry Contest, First Priz
summary: This poem, titled "Prayer" by Ed Shacklee, explores themes of grief, resilience, and finding new purpose after profound loss. The speaker, referencing Dylan Thomas's call to "rage against the dying of the light," expresses sorrow over murdered loved ones and a sense of duty to fight against such darkness. The second stanza uses the metaphor of a flower ravaged by a caterpillar to signify a new, unburdened heart, and a plea for actions of justice and gentle touch, likening the wind's lack of a cradle to the vulnerability of petals to frost. Keywords: poetry, grief, resilience, loss, existential, fighting darkness, new heart, justice.

title: My Resume Entry
abstract: Poetry by Justina Kaiser
summary: This abstract poem by Justina Kaiser uses vivid, fragmented imagery to explore themes of daily life, struggle, and human experience. It depicts actions like cleaning, climbing, navigating, and observing, often with a sense of underlying effort or futility. The verses touch upon mundane tasks, significant life events, and spiritual reflection, suggesting a cyclical nature of human endeavor and a search for meaning amidst chaos. Key elements include domestic scenes, natural landscapes, and existential ponderings, highlighting the poet's unique stylistic approach.

title: Prairie Surreal--A Digital-Poetic Road Trip
abstract: Poetry by Mari-Lou Rowle
fieldOfStudy: Literature in English, North America, Creative Writing, Critical and Cultural Studies, Nature and Society Relations, Place and Environment
summary: This article, "Prairie Surreal--A Digital-Poetic Road Trip" by Mari-Lou Rowley, explores the concepts of poetic ferality and prairie surrealism as compelling notions for a writer and poet, particularly after returning to Saskatchewan. The work combines creative writing, critical and cultural studies, and examines literature, nature-society relations, and place-environment themes. It serves as a digital-poetic journey, reflecting on the author's experiences and influences, and likely includes elements of ecopoetics and new media. The piece contributes to discussions on contemporary poetry and its engagement with landscape and digital platforms.

title: Mixing It Up: Poetry for The Goose
abstract: Poetry Editorial by Camilla Nelso
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, Poetry, Ecopoetics, Audiopoetics, Sound Poetry
summary: This poetry editorial by Camilla Nelson for "The Goose" discusses a multi-modal approach to selecting poetry, encouraging the submission of works that explore language as an environment, specifically through echopoetics, audiopoetics, and sound poetries. Nelson, a poet and researcher, expresses her enthusiasm for fostering submissions in audio(eco)poetics, drawing inspiration from the Flow and Fracture Ecopoetry Lab. She invites writers to submit mp3 poetries or written texts investigating the sonic aspects of their shared spaces, highlighting her role as the new poetry editor and her commitment to innovative poetic expression.

title: Poetry by Lachlan Brown in Translation
abstract: As a result of Lachalns Brown’s visit to the Centre d’Estudis Australians – Australian Studies Centre - at the Universitat de Barcelona Bill Phillips translated some of his work into Catalan, Laura López into Spanish and Victoria Dimitrova into Bulgarian. As always the poetry is presented in bi-lingual format. The translators, guest editor Carles Serra and the Centre would like to thank Lachlan for his generosity to us all
summary: This document presents a selection of poetry by Lachlan Brown, translated into multiple languages. Stemming from Brown's visit to the Australian Studies Centre at the Universitat de Barcelona, his work was translated by Bill Phillips into Catalan, Laura López into Spanish, and Victoria Dimitrova into Bulgarian. The collection maintains a bi-lingual format, showcasing the original English alongside its translations. The publication features various poems including "Disbelief" and "Response," exploring themes of skepticism, reason, memory, and the search for meaning in darkness. This compilation serves to disseminate Brown's poetic voice across different linguistic and cultural contexts.

title: POETIC LANGUAGE IN NAZARETH’S “LOVE HURTS”
abstract:
This study is concerned with how language is poetically used in one of Nazareth’s song lyrics,

“Love Hurts”. The language encompasses a series of figures of speech. This study was

performed as an alternative practice in teaching English poetry. Figures of speech intrinsically

compose English poetry. Because the figures of speech contain implied meaning, they might not

be easily meaningful to a reader of the lyric. This study is intended to describe the figures of

speech so that the language becomes more understandable to the reader. This study applies a

textual analysis, and it adopts Leech’s linguistic guide to English poetry. The linguistic guide

includes absurdity in the language of poetry; transference of meaning; and over and counter

statement. The discussion works on each of the lyric’s lines, and it results in the series of figures

of speech, comprising oxymoron, paradox, synecdoche, metaphor, metonymy, hyperbole, litotes,

and irony. The figures of speech indicate that the language is arranged to sweetly sound a

melody. Besides that, the figures of speech indicate that the language is also used figuratively to

contain the meaning. In other words, in the lyric, the language was used not only to be sung

melodically, but it was also used to be written poetically
summary: This study analyzes the poetic language in Nazareth's song lyric "Love Hurts," focusing on its figures of speech as an alternative method for teaching English poetry. Employing a textual analysis and Leech's linguistic guide, the research describes various figures, including oxymoron, paradox, synecdoche, metaphor, metonymy, hyperbole, litotes, and irony. The findings indicate that these figures contribute to both the melodic arrangement and the figurative meaning of the language, making the lyric understandable and poetically rich. The study aims to help readers interpret the implied meanings within the text.

title: The Wilds of Poetry: Adventures in Mind and Landscape by David Hinton
abstract: Review of David Hinton’s The Wilds of Poetry: Adventure’s in Mind and Landscape
fieldOfStudy: English, Literature, Poetry Studies, Critical and Cultural Studies
summary: This review analyzes David Hinton's "The Wilds of Poetry: Adventures in Mind and Landscape," a book exploring twentieth-century poetry. The review highlights Hinton's generous sampling of poets' works and its appeal to readers interested in the intersections of Taoism, Zen Buddhism, environmentalism, and poetry. It posits that Hinton's work offers a valuable message of depth and delight for young poets, their audience, and teachers, especially amidst declining contemporary poetry standards focused on transient goals like prizes and grants. Key themes include consciousness, contact, mind, and landscape in poetry.

title: On Voice in Poetry: The Work of Animation by David Nowell Smith
abstract: A review of On Voice In Poetry: The Work of Animation, by David Nowell Smith
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, Critical and Cultural Studies, Poetry
summary: This article reviews David Nowell Smith's "On Voice in Poetry: The Work of Animation," defending the concept of "voice" in poetry and exploring its intricate relationship with soundworlds and performance. The review highlights Smith's eloquent analysis of tonal ambiguity, particularly in the context of poetry that is not literally vocalized, and discusses how music might mimic these ambiguities. It further examines the temporal aspects of divine speech and human voice in devotional poetry, referencing figures like Hopkins and St. Augustine to explore the challenges of addressing timelessness through bounded temporal expression.

title: Ossian and James Macpherson
abstract: Discussion of the Ossianic poetry translated by James Macpherson
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, Scottish Literature, Folklore, Romanticism, Poetry
summary: This document, "Ossian and James Macpherson" by Valentina Bold (2005), delves into the Ossianic poetry translated by James Macpherson. Published within "Alba Literaria: A History of Scottish Literature," the work likely examines the literary, cultural, and historical impact of Macpherson's controversial adaptations of ancient Gaelic poetry. Key themes would include the authenticity debate, the influence of Ossian on Romanticism, and Macpherson's role in Scottish literary history. The text provides bibliographic details for further research on Macpherson, Ossian, and their reception in various literary and folklore studies.

title: Spatial Engagement with Poetry by Heather H. Yeung
abstract: Review of Spatial Engagement with Poetry by Heather H. Yeung
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, Critical and Cultural Studies, Environmental Studies, Reading and Language
summary: This article reviews Heather H. Yeung's book, "Spatial Engagement with Poetry," which explores the intersection of spatial theory and poetic analysis. The review by Deborah C. Bowen critiques the book's ambitious scope, noting its sometimes gratuitous references to critical theorists like Heidegger and Derrida, and its inconsistent engagement with various fields such as psychoanalysis and feminist theory. Despite these criticisms, Bowen commends Yeung's original readings of specific poets and acknowledges the book's potential as an early exploration in a developing field concerning spatiality and poetry. Key themes include spatial criticism, poetic analysis, and interdisciplinary approaches to literature.

title: Better Citizens through Poetry
abstract: State poet Rick Benjamin shares how poetry teaches us about citizenship as part of the Mary Tefft White Cultural Center: Talking in the Library Series
summary: Rick Benjamin, the Rhode Island state poet, argues that poetry can be a powerful medium for fostering a sense of citizenship and obligation to community and the environment. Appointed in 2012, Benjamin aims to illuminate Rhode Island's history through poetic lenses and educates on arts, humanities, and environmental studies. He emphasizes poetry's role in conveying wisdom and circulating instructions for living, exemplified by Mary Oliver's 'In Blackwater Woods,' which reflects on life, loss, and acceptance. This discussion was part of the Mary Tefft White Cultural Center's 'Talking in the Library' series at Roger Williams University, focusing on the vibrant exchange of ideas.

title: Jonathan\u27s House
abstract: This poem placed first in the 1929 Butler Literary Contest, Poetry Division
summary: This poem, titled "Jonathan's House" by Marguerite Young, won the 1929 Butler Literary Contest, Poetry Division. It describes a woman's poignant reflection on a dream house she planned with Jonathan, a house full of delicate, beautiful details like a cloistered garden, blue-tiled fireplace, and a secret escape door. After Jonathan's departure and apparent death, she finds herself in a house arranged by Thomas, which outwardly resembles her dream but lacks the intended secret panel. The poem explores themes of memory, loss, dreams versus reality, and the enduring presence of a loved one. Keywords: poetry, loss, dreams, memory, architecture, unfulfilled dreams, contest winner.

title: [Review of] Diana Der Hovanessian. About Time
abstract: As Armenian American literature matures, the impact of the massacres and dispersion of the Armenians in the Ottoman Empire in 1915 widens in meaning and relevance. A recently published collection of poetry by Diana Der Hovanessian suggests how issues raised by those long-ago events permeate the imagination of contempory [contemporary] Armenian American writers, giving poignant focus to their work. Diana Der Hovanessian, the foremost translator of Armenian poetry into English, demonstrated this most memorably in her Anthology of Armenian Poetry. Her first volume, How to Choose Your Past (1978, Ararat Press) displayed her wit and concern with the transmission of the Armenian language in a land where it is vulnerable to extinction. The second volume of her own work, About Time includes many poems which again showcase her strengths: short, epigrammatic pieces which tease the imagination and ironic poems that echo long after the first reading. Though many of these poems deal with non-Armenian subjects, those that weave together the volume once more express the poet\u27s love for the Armenian language and poets killed at the beginnings of the massacres
summary: This document explores how the 1915 Armenian massacres and dispersion continue to influence contemporary Armenian American literature, focusing on Diana Der Hovanessian's poetry. Her collections, including "How to Choose Your Past" and "About Time," poignantly address issues like the transmission of the Armenian language and the legacy of martyred poets. Der Hovanessian, a prominent translator, uses short, epigrammatic, and ironic pieces to express her love for Armenian culture and language, even when dealing with non-Armenian subjects. The analysis highlights how her work, through symbolic imagery and thematic exploration, reasserts the enduring power of a shared language to carry history and feeling across generations despite immense tragedy.

title: Logological Poetry: An Editorial
abstract: It was Dmitri Borgmann who put the word  logology  into circulation. Before Language on Vacation, his first book, was published, he wrote to me:  I don\u27t believe the word \u27logology\u27 has ever appeared in a book devoted to words or puzzles. I dug it out of the unabridged Oxford while searching for a suitable name for my activity
fieldOfStudy: English Language Studies, Logology, Wordplay, Linguistics
summary: This article explores the term "logology," tracing its origins and usage, particularly by Dmitri Borgmann in his book "Language on Vacation." It details Borgmann's meticulous research into the word's presence in various dictionaries, revealing its rarity and the different definitions it held, from the doctrine of the Logos to the science of words. The author emphasizes Borgmann's intention to find a unique, unclaimed term for the study of words and puzzles, distinguishing it from "word play." The text also includes a section on palindromic expressions and a list of such examples.

title: Tuwim’s Dialogues with Banality
abstract: The article examines the relation between Tuwim’s poetry and modern colloquial language. The avant-garde artists for whom in the beginning of the 20th-century art was an elite occupation, treated every-day speech as a mass form of communication. Tuwim’s poetry was frequently criticised for banality. Matywiecki presents the poet as a hero fighting with the demon of commonness. The crucial thesis of the article is that banality which is modified in a creative way says more about the epoch than elitist visions. In his poetry, satire and cabaret work Tuwim transformed triviality into dialog and a common human being into a creative person. Transition of the street talk into original speech is the defence against reducing individual being to cliché which means the fear of 20th-century killing ideologies.Zadanie „Stworzenie anglojęzycznych wersji wydawanych publikacji”  finansowane w ramach umowy nr 948/P-DUN/2016 ze środków Ministra Nauki i Szkolnictwa Wyższego przeznaczonych na działalność upowszechniającą naukę
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, Poetry, 20th Century Literature, Avant-Garde
summary: This article explores the relationship between Julian Tuwim's poetry and modern colloquial language, contrasting his approach with avant-garde artists who viewed everyday speech as a mass form of communication. Despite criticism for banality, the article argues that Tuwim creatively modified banality to reveal more about his epoch than elitist visions. Through his poetry, satire, and cabaret work, Tuwim transformed triviality into dialogue and elevated common individuals, defending against the reduction of individuality to cliché and the fear of 20th-century killing ideologies. Key concepts include Tuwim's poetry, banality, avant-garde, 20th-century literature, and the transformation of language.

title: Tilt
abstract: Poetry by Kate Lilley, Department of English, University of Sydney, Australia
summary: This text presents a poem titled "Tilt" by Kate Lilley, published in "Cultural Studies Review." The poem reflects on historical events and personal experiences, intertwining memories of Fonzies Fantasyland, a leisure center established by Alan Saffron, with tragic events like the Ghost Train fire at Luna Park and the murder of a woman in Prospect. It also touches upon cultural landmarks like the Academy Twin cinema and references figures such as Juanita Nielsen, creating a vivid narrative that explores themes of memory, crime, and urban landscape.

title: Elegiac adaptations : resisting the closure of mourning in Elizabeth Robinson's Three Novels
abstract: textElizabeth Robinson's Three Novels (2011) is a lyric re-exploration of three Victorian novels: Wilkie Collins's The Moonstone (1868) and The Woman in White (1859-60), and George Gissing's Eve's Ransom (1895). Robinson ostensibly wrote the poems as an elegy for her father; however, Three Novels also unearths elegiac aspects of its source novels that have been previously unexamined by critics. Each of the Victorian source novels narrates a movement from an initial loss toward an eventual resolution, mirroring the traditional structure of an elegy: mourning is ultimately completed by the acceptance of a compensatory substitute for the loss. While the poetry in Three Novels emphasizes the presence of elegy in its sources, the poems themselves fracture the practice of normative mourning by rewriting these novels in the style of Jahan Ramazani's melancholic "anti-elegy" which forecloses the possibility of loss resolution. Because the loss is not neatly resolved, it becomes an object of focus. Reading the anti-elegy manifest in Three Novels creates a space to mourn the losses incurred by each novel, thereby recuperating the overlooked figures of the female, the landscape, and the self that had been diminished by the narrative's drive to resolution.Englis
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, Poetry, Victorian Novels, Elegy, Melancholy, Literary Criticism
summary: This report examines Elizabeth Robinson's "Three Novels" (2011), a poetic re-exploration of Victorian novels like Wilkie Collins's "The Moonstone" and "The Woman in White," and George Gissing's "Eve's Ransom." Ostensibly an elegy for her father, Robinson's work also unearths previously unexamined elegiac aspects within these source novels, which traditionally move from loss to resolution. However, "Three Novels" fractures normative mourning practices by adopting a melancholic "anti-elegy" style, foreclosing resolution and foregrounding unresolved loss. This approach recuperates overlooked figures such as the female, the landscape, and the self, which were diminished by the original narratives' drive for closure.

title: Striving for autonomy : representative female characters in the detective novels of P. D. James : a thesis presented in partial fulfilment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Arts in English at Massey University, Palmerston North, New Zealand
abstract: Representative female characters from several of P D James's detective novels are used to exemplify the changes in women's position in society during the four decades (from the early 1960s to the late 1990s) which span James's publishing career and which coincide with the period known as the second wave of feminism. Women characters have always taken a prominent place in P D James's detective fiction, and since the 1970s her books have increasingly foregrounded the problems that women have when working in male-dominated professions, revealing their increasing autonomy but also disclosing the continuing limitations of that autonomy. Her novels are acknowledged as becoming increasingly literary. In her early novels James followed the formula of the classic detective fiction genre quite closely. During the 1970s she experimented with novels that on the surface read as detective novels, while functioning subtextually in relation to myths and metaphors. In her most recent works she transcends the genre, using the detective formula simply as a framework for her novels of literary realism
fieldOfStudy: English, Literary Criticism, Women's Studies, Detective Fiction
summary: This thesis examines representative female characters in P.D. James's detective novels to exemplify changes in women's societal position from the 1960s to the 1990s, coinciding with second-wave feminism. It investigates how James's work, particularly from the 1970s onwards, increasingly foregrounds the challenges women face in male-dominated professions, showcasing their growing autonomy alongside its enduring limitations. The study traces James's evolving literary style, from closely following classic detective fiction formulas in early novels to experimenting with mythical subtexts and transcending the genre for literary realism in later works.

title: Errata to the Stanisław Czernik’s Biography: 1949
abstract: The subject of this paper is the writing activity of Stanisław Czernik in 1949. Czernik was an esteemed writer but concurrently he worked as censor in The Ministry of Culture and Art. He reviewed novels of many writers in the same department of Ministry where his novels were reviewed too. This paper discusses a number reviews wrote by Czernik and some reviews of Czernik’ books wrote by another censors of The Ministry
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, Polish Literature, Censorship Studies, Cultural History
summary:
This paper examines the writing activities of Stanis
0142aw Czernik in 1949, focusing on his dual role as an esteemed writer and a censor within the Ministry of Culture and Art. Czernik reviewed novels by numerous authors in the same department where his own works were also subject to censorship. The study discusses specific reviews authored by Czernik, alongside evaluations of his books conducted by other Ministry censors. This research illuminates the complexities of literary life and censorship in post-1945 Poland, highlighting Czernik's involvement in literary criticism and the institutional mechanisms of cultural control.

title: Transcending Borders: Imagined/Real and Primitive/Civilised Communities in the Novels of E.L. Grant Watson
abstract: Questions of myth, landscape and self constituting a sense of place have played a significant role in much literature written in and about Australia and continue to do so; from the folkloric works of Henry Lawson and “Banjo” Patterson in the 1890’s to the novels of Katharine Prichard, Patrick White and Tim Winton, for example. Perhaps surprisingly, the novels of English Biologist, amateur anthropologist and psychologist, metaphysician and colonialist E.L. Grant Watson (1885-1970) belong to this tradition
summary: This paper examines the novels of E.L. Grant Watson, an English biologist and anthropologist, placing them within the Australian literary tradition that explores myth, landscape, and the self to constitute a sense of place. It considers how Watson's work, surprisingly, aligns with Australian authors from Henry Lawson to Tim Winton in addressing themes of imagined/real and primitive/civilized communities, transcending conventional borders in its exploration of identity and environment. Key themes include colonial perspectives, Australian literature, and sense of place.

title: Annotated Bibliography: Clean Graphic Novels
summary: This annotated bibliography addresses the challenge of finding appropriate graphic novels for young readers amidst a prevalence of adult-oriented comics featuring excessive violence and sexualized content. It provides a curated list of "clean" graphic novels, making it a valuable resource for librarians, parents, and educators seeking suitable options for children. The bibliography includes diverse examples, such as adaptations of classic literature, historical narratives, and humor-driven stories, aiming to guide readers toward engaging and age-appropriate content. Keywords: graphic novels, children's literature, clean comics, bibliography, collection development.

title: wild life
abstract: Poetry by Jordan Abel. This poem is composed from 91 public domain Western novels that are freely available on Project Gutenberg. In total, the source text is over 10,000 pages long and is authored by 20 different writers. When all of the novels were searched simultaneously, there were 41 instances of the phrase  wild life.  The resulting poem provides a contextual space where the language of a single word or phrase can be read
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, Indigenous Studies, Poetry, North American Literature, Environmental Humanities
summary: This poem, "wild life" by Jordan Abel, is meticulously crafted from 91 public domain Western novels, totaling over 10,000 pages by 20 different authors. By searching for the phrase "wild life" across all source texts, the poem creates a contextual space for linguistic exploration. The work delves into themes of Indigenous studies, literature, nature, and environment, juxtaposing concepts like 'Indianized' identity, freedom, and the 'wild blood' against notions of 'civilized life.' This unique method offers a novel approach to textual recombination and meaning-making in poetry.

title: The Polish Trial of Kafka. On the Reception of Franz Kafka and So-Called “Dark Literature” by the Censorship Board
abstract: The article discusses the reception of Franz Kafka’s novels and the so-called “dark literature”, popular after 1956, by the censorship board. It presents the discussions around Kafka’s work and various interpretational strategies used to secure this literature a place in the culture of People’s Republic of Poland. The article presents analyses of the censors’ reviews of Kafka’s (but also Sartre’s or Faulkner’s) novels and offers insight into the censorship process and the literary life of the late 1950s in general
summary: This article examines the censorship board's reception of Franz Kafka's novels and other "dark literature" (including works by Camus, Sartre, and Faulkner) in the People's Republic of Poland after 1956. It analyzes archival reviews of these works to reveal the mechanisms of censorship and interpretational strategies employed to integrate such literature into Polish culture. The study provides insight into the literary life and censorship processes of the late 1950s, using the historical category of "dark literature" as a lens despite its perceived cognitive vapidity today. Keywords include Franz Kafka, censorship, and Polish literary life.

title: Mystery as a theological theme in the writings of Marilynne Robinson
abstract: The novels of Marilynne Robinson have been seen as the primary source of insight into her theological reflections. The purpose of this study is to challenge this assumption by claiming that her essays are an essential theological companion to her novels. The study explores the theme of mystery in Robinson’s essays and selects three episodes from the Gilead trilogy to show how the same theme emerges in the novels. The study also claims that Robinson employs contrasting methods of discourse to express a common theology across the two genres. A conceptual model developed by Rowan Williams in his book The Edge of Words is used as a framework to demonstrate this claim. Finally, the study suggests that Robinson’s open approach to religious thought has the potential to appeal beyond the confines of Christian orthodoxy. In summary, by offering a unified approach to Robinson’s theology across both genres, the study seeks to provide an innovative perspective on her overall work
summary: This study challenges the assumption that Marilynne Robinson's novels are the sole source of insight into her theological reflections, asserting her essays are an essential theological companion. It explores the theme of mystery in Robinson's essays and demonstrates its emergence in three episodes from the Gilead trilogy. The research claims Robinson uses contrasting discourse methods to express a common theology across genres, utilizing Rowan Williams's conceptual model from "The Edge of Words" as a framework. Ultimately, the study suggests Robinson's open religious thought appeals beyond Christian orthodoxy, offering an innovative, unified perspective on her overall work, focusing on theology, mystery, and genre.

title: The Reformasi of Ayu Utami; Attacking the Monopoly of the Great Religions
abstract: In eight novels, Ayu Utami has presented critical attacks on doctrines and practices of the major religions in Indonesia. The two books, that describe the spiritual struggle of the Catholic priest Saman (1998–2002), call for a religion that is more active in the political arena, but leaves sexual rules to the individual people. The novel Bilangan Fu (2008) condemns the monopoly of the great religions in favour of local and individual spirituality. This is developed in a series of novels of which two more have already appeared. A third cycle of three more or less autobiographic novels (2003–2013) sketch her personal quest from atheism towards a critical but positive spirituality condemning a clerical and monopolist trend in Catholicism. Utami's criticism of the great religions is external (more players in the field should be recognised) and internal (religious leaders should have more modest claims towards their faithful and leave more space for personal choice)
summary: This article analyzes Ayu Utami's critical perspective on major Indonesian religions as expressed in her novels. Through works like "Saman" and "Bilangan Fu," Utami advocates for politically active religion while emphasizing individual sexual autonomy and condemning religious monopolies in favor of local spirituality. Her autobiographical novels trace a personal journey from atheism to a critical yet positive spirituality, challenging clerical and monopolistic tendencies within Catholicism. Utami's critique targets both external (recognizing more spiritual players) and internal (promoting modesty among religious leaders and personal choice) aspects of religious practice, offering insights into religious reform, Indonesian literature, and spirituality.

title: Deeper Understanding through Novels and Biographies
fieldOfStudy: English, Religious Thought, Theology and Philosophy of Religion, Literary Studies, Cultural Studies
summary: This article explores how reading novels and biographies can foster deeper understanding and empathy among diverse urban Canadians living in multifaith neighborhoods. It addresses the challenges of making assumptions about other cultures and faiths, and the reluctance to engage due to differences. The author argues that literature offers a safe and accessible means to learn about the experiences and perspectives of others, particularly new immigrants, without direct intrusion. By engaging with these narratives, readers can gain insight into various subcultures and backgrounds, ultimately enriching their understanding of Canada's diverse population and encouraging more meaningful interactions.

title: Garden paths and blind spots
abstract: A critical review of Sarah Waters's The Little Stranger: 'she is a commensurate storyteller whose...novels are akin to a gorgeous meal'
publisher: Welsh Books Council / Aberystwyh University Department of English and Creative Writing
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, Literary Criticism, Queer Studies
summary: This critical review examines Sarah Waters's novel, "The Little Stranger," analyzing its departure from her usual lesbian historical fiction. Set in post-WWII rural Warwickshire, the novel notably lacks overt lesbian characters, in contrast to Waters's previous works. The review discusses how the setting and historical context, particularly the societal pressures on women and the advent of the NHS, inform the character of Caroline Ayres's struggle for independence and her rejection of conventional heterosexual marriage. It explores the concept of 'queer' in the novel as signifying an absence of lesbianism rather than its presence, highlighting the challenges for lesbian identity in post-war Britain.

title: Middle Passage to Freedom: Black Atlantic Consciousness in Charles Johnson\u27s Middle Passage and S. I. Martin\u27s Incomparable World
abstract: Charles Johnson\u27s novel, Middle Passage, and S.I. Martin\u27s novel, Incomparable World, illustrate through mobile, culturally hybrid protagonists Paul Gilroy\u27s notion of Black Atlantic consciousness, which is based on cultural hybridity and physical mobility across the Atlantic between Europe and Africa, America and the Caribbean. I argue that both novels blur the line between freedom and slavery, between oppressed and oppressor, and disrupt the links between blackness and slavery, between mobility and freedom. In both novels the diasporic Black Atlantic experiences privilege masculinity, since neither novel includes black women who can experience the mobility that the male protagonists do
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, Black Atlantic Studies, Postcolonial Studies, Gender Studies
summary: This study analyzes Charles Johnson's "Middle Passage" and S.I. Martin's "Incomparable World" through the lens of Paul Gilroy's Black Atlantic consciousness, focusing on culturally hybrid, mobile protagonists. The article argues that both novels blur the lines between freedom and slavery, and between oppressed and oppressor, challenging traditional links between blackness and servitude, and mobility and liberty. It also highlights how these Black Atlantic experiences privilege masculinity, as black women characters do not experience the same mobility as their male counterparts. Key concepts include Black Atlantic consciousness, cultural hybridity, and diasporic experiences.

title: Practical Christianity: Religion in Jane Austen\u27s Novels
abstract: A beloved English novelist of the late eighteenth century, Jane Austen captures the attention and emotion of readers through timeless insights into the inner workings of the human heart as characters navigate society, family life, and love. Her novels’ attention to practical morality but reticence toward explicitly religious subject matter raises conjecture concerning the religion behind her values; however, Austen’s Christian upbringing, Anglican practice, and Christian values suggest a foundation of faith from which the morality in her novels emanates. In Sense and Sensibility, Pride and Prejudice, and Mansfield Park, Austen demonstrates her eighteenth-century Anglican worldview in the lives of her characters as they grow in virtue and good character
summary: This thesis explores the underlying religious values in Jane Austen's novels, addressing the conjecture surrounding her characters' practical morality despite a lack of explicit religious discourse. It argues that Austen's Christian upbringing, Anglican practice, and Christian values form the foundation for the morality depicted. Through an analysis of "Sense and Sensibility," "Pride and Prejudice," and "Mansfield Park," the work demonstrates how Austen's eighteenth-century Anglican worldview influenced her characters' development of virtue and good character, offering insights into religious themes, moral philosophy, and literary criticism within her works.

title: Barbauld's Richardson and the canonisation of personal character
abstract: In The Correspondence of Samuel Richardson (1804), Anna Letitia Barbauld set out to assure readers that the novelist’s personal character (as displayed in his letters) corresponded to his authorial moral character (as inferred through his novels) in order to present him as an appropriate father of the modern British novel – a process I call the “canonisation of private character.” To that end, Barbauld’s editorial work presented Richardson as a benevolent patriarchal figure whose moral authority over the domestic life of his extended family guaranteed the morality of his novels and of his personal character. As my case study of Richardson’s correspondence with Sarah Wescomb shows, Barbauld’s interventions accordingly muted challenges to Richardson’s authority on questions of paternal control or filial obedience. Life writing, textual criticism, and literary history were therefore so intimately intertwined in Barbauld’s treatment of Richardson and his writings that they mutually constituted and sustained each other. Her contributions to the elevation and institution of novels as a national literary genre – in the Correspondence as well as in her later prefaces to The British Novelists (1810) – accordingly should be read in conjunction with her biographical elevation and canonisation of Richardson as the first properly moral, modern novelist
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, Literary History, Editorial Studies, 18th-century Novel
summary: This article examines Anna Letitia Barbauld's editorial work on *The Correspondence of Samuel Richardson* (1804), arguing that she aimed to align Richardson's personal and authorial moral character to establish him as the "father of the modern British novel." Barbauld presented Richardson as a benevolent patriarch whose moral authority underpinned his novels and character, muting challenges to his paternal control. The study uses Richardson's correspondence with Sarah Wescomb as a case study to demonstrate how Barbauld's interventions intertwined life writing, textual criticism, and literary history, collectively constituting Richardson's biographical and literary canonization within the British novel genre.

title:
What Level of Quality can Neural Machine Translation Attain on Literary
  Text?
abstract:
Given the rise of a new approach to MT, Neural MT (NMT), and its promising
performance on different text types, we assess the translation quality it can
attain on what is perceived to be the greatest challenge for MT: literary text.
Specifically, we target novels, arguably the most popular type of literary
text. We build a literary-adapted NMT system for the English-to-Catalan
translation direction and evaluate it against a system pertaining to the
previous dominant paradigm in MT: statistical phrase-based MT (PBSMT). To this
end, for the first time we train MT systems, both NMT and PBSMT, on large
amounts of literary text (over 100 million words) and evaluate them on a set of
twelve widely known novels spanning from the the 1920s to the present day.
According to the BLEU automatic evaluation metric, NMT is significantly better
than PBSMT (p < 0.01) on all the novels considered. Overall, NMT results in a
11% relative improvement (3 points absolute) over PBSMT. A complementary human
evaluation on three of the books shows that between 17% and 34% of the
translations, depending on the book, produced by NMT (versus 8% and 20% with
PBSMT) are perceived by native speakers of the target language to be of
equivalent quality to translations produced by a professional human translator.Comment: Chapter for the forthcoming book "Translation Quality Assessment:
  From Principles to Practice" (Springer
fieldOfStudy: English, Machine Translation, Neural Machine Translation, Statistical Machine Translation
summary: This paper assesses the translation quality of Neural Machine Translation (NMT) on literary texts, specifically novels, comparing it to statistical phrase-based MT (PBSMT). Researchers trained both NMT and PBSMT systems on over 100 million words of literary text for English-to-Catalan translation and evaluated them on twelve novels from the 1920s to the present. Using the BLEU metric, NMT significantly outperformed PBSMT, showing an 11% relative improvement. A human evaluation further indicated that NMT produced translations of equivalent quality to professional human translators for 17% to 34% of the text, significantly higher than PBSMT.

title: Shakespeare Burlesque and the Performing Self
abstract: This paper argues that Victorian Shakespeare burlesques reveal an alternate literary history: a movement away from private, novelistic consciousness toward collaborative performance. Many materialist scholars fault post-Romantic critics for casting Shakespeare as a psychological realist and reading his plays as if they were novels. The burlesque treatment of Hamlet’s soliloquies, however, suggests a contrary trajectory, challenging the equation of Shakespearean character with psychological reflection. Rather than inaugurating a tradition of interiority, Hamlet’s soliloquies generate social speech in works like Gilbert’s Rosencrantz and Guildenstern, inviting audience participation. The burlesque imperative also inflects novels like Dickens’s Great Expectations, turning the internal debate of the canonical literary self into the public dispute of populist entertainment
fieldOfStudy: English, Dramatic Literature, Criticism and Theory, Theatre History
summary: This paper argues that Victorian Shakespeare burlesques reveal an alternate literary history, shifting from private, novelistic consciousness to collaborative performance. Challenging the post-Romantic view of Shakespeare as a psychological realist, the burlesque treatment of Hamlet’s soliloquies, particularly in works like Gilbert’s Rosencrantz and Guildenstern, suggests a trajectory toward social speech and audience participation. This burlesque imperative also influenced novels such as Dickens’s Great Expectations, transforming internal literary debate into public, populist entertainment. The study explores Victorian literary history, Shakespearean criticism, performance studies, and the evolution of character representation from interiority to public discourse.

title: Literature in Transition : European aesthetics and the early American novel
abstract: This paper seeks to account for the strangely double nature of the early American novel. For twenty-first-century readers, novels such as Hugh Henry Brackenridge's Modem Chivalry, Susanna Rowson's Charlotte Temple or Charles Brockden Brown's Wieland seem firmly embedded in a premodern culture that subordinates the rights of art under those of religion, morality, and education. In their persistent didacticism, their claims to truthfulness and social utility, and their long authorial digressions, these texts perform those kinds of heteronomous functions Romantic theorizing and literary practice of the early nineteenth century would seek to reject in their quest for literary autonomy. Yet a closer look at early American novels also reveals elements of modern artistic practice that exist side by side with premodern residues. Brackenridge, for instance, repeatedly insists that his work is but an exercise in style devoid of ideas, praises originality and the figure of the genius, consistently privileges form over subject matter, and ridicules the excessive didacticism of his contemporaries. In such passages, we can see a modern consciousness at work. Tensions between these modern impulses and a premodern sensibility pervade both early novels and aesthetics, another invention of the eighteenth century. This paper discusses those tensions from a systems-theoretical perspective
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, American Studies, Literary Theory
summary: This paper examines the dual nature of early American novels, which exhibit both premodern didacticism and emerging modern artistic elements. Focusing on works like Brackenridge's "Modern Chivalry" and Brown's "Wieland," the study identifies tensions between their subordination to religion, morality, and education, and simultaneous assertions of stylistic originality, form over content, and critiques of excessive didacticism. The paper discusses these modern impulses alongside premodern sensibilities within early novels and 18th-century aesthetics, utilizing a systems-theoretical perspective. Key concepts include literary autonomy, romantic theory, and the evolution of artistic practice in early American literature.

title: Written in blood: Family, sex and violence in Wuthering Heights and Jane Eyre
abstract: This essay is an examination of the themes of family, sex, and violence, and the inter-relationships between them, in two of the best-known novels of the nineteenth century
summary: This essay examines the interconnected themes of family, sex, and violence in two seminal 19th-century novels, "Wuthering Heights" and "Jane Eyre." Drawing on Michel Foucault's "History of Sexuality," the author explores how Emily and Charlotte Brontë's narratives, despite common notions of Victorian repression, are deeply reliant on these elements. The analysis delves into the intricate relationships and dramatic events within these works, highlighting their enduring relevance and the authors' complex portrayal of human passions and societal constraints. Keywords: Wuthering Heights, Jane Eyre, Victorian literature, family, sex, violence, Michel Foucault.

title: The A B C’s of Graphic Novels
abstract: I have highlighted twenty-five concerns that I address when talking about the graphic novel in the many recent presentations I have conducted on this topic
summary: This article, "The A B C’s of Graphic Novels" by Gail de Vos, addresses twenty-five common concerns related to the graphic novel. It serves as a comprehensive resource for educators, librarians, and enthusiasts navigating discussions around this medium. The publication aims to inform and guide conversations, highlighting key considerations and arguments for its inclusion in various contexts. The work is particularly relevant for those involved in library science and information studies, offering insights into the evolving landscape of literature and educational resources. Keywords: graphic novels, concerns, education, libraries, information science, literature.

title: Sex, the Body, and Human Subjectivity in Luis Gotyisolo\u27s Erotic Novel  Escalera Hacia el Cielo
abstract: Best known for his tetralogy Antagonía, Luis Goytisolo began his literary career under the Franco dictatorship and soon developed a reputation as an intellectual\u27s writer. His intricate and sinewy prose challenged readers to follow his narrators down labyrinthine paths of extended metaphors, embedded clauses and erudite references. Interestingly enough, the novels of Goytisolo published in the last decade lack the narrative complexity and structural experimentalism characteristic of his earlier works. These 90s novels include: Estatua con palomas (1992), Mzungo (1996), Placer licuante (1997), and Escalera hacia el cielo (1999). Some might feel that his change to a more traditional narrative style indicates a compromise of his intellectual project and wonder if he has succumbed to the pressures created by the commercialization of Spanish fiction
fieldOfStudy: English, Spanish and Portuguese Language and Literature, Feminist, Gender, and Sexuality Studies
summary: This article examines the evolution of Luis Goytisolo's narrative style, contrasting his earlier, complex works like Antagonía with his simpler novels from the 1990s, including *Estatua con palomas*, *Mzungo*, *Placer licuante*, and *Escalera hacia el cielo*. It specifically analyzes "Sex, the Body, and Human Subjectivity in Luis Goytisolo's Erotic Novel 'Escalera Hacia el Cielo'" by Terri Carney. The study investigates whether this shift toward a more traditional style compromises his intellectual project or reflects the commercialization pressures in Spanish fiction. Key themes include literary evolution, narrative complexity, and intellectual compromise in Goytisolo's works.

title: Teaching Cartography with Comics: Some Examples from BeccoGiallo\u2019s Graphic Novel Series
abstract: This article suggests the use of comics, particularly of graphic novels, as valuable instructional tools for teaching cartography. Of particular interest is the idea that comics can be used to develop students\u2019 geographical competencies, their ability to think actively about cartographical issues, and their capacity to interact with \u201cmaps as mappings\u201d (Dodge, Kitchin and Perkins, 2009). The theoretical references used to conduct the deep interdisciplinary proposal and analysis include: the growing field of literary cartography, recent post-representational theories in cartography, and the emerging field of \u201ccomic book geography\u201d (Dittmer, 2014). The article reads comics as maps and analyzes their map-like features to demonstrate that both maps and comics ask the reader-user to be actively engaged to decipher, orient, and practice them. Proposing to read \u201cmaps as comics\u201d, \u201cmaps of comics\u201d, \u201cmaps and mappings in comics\u201d, and \u201ccomics as maps and mappings\u201d, the article suggests the possible practical employment of comics in cartography classes. Furthermore, this study uses examples from BeccoGiallo\u2019s comic series to demonstrate that graphic novels may help students become more aware map readers and users, by being involved in an active spatial practice. Finally, this article focuses on the unexplored educational potential of graphic novels by exploring the improvement of students\u2019 understanding of post-representational cartographical approaches through comic use
fieldOfStudy: English, Cartography, Comic Book Geography, Graphic Novels
summary: This article proposes using comics, especially graphic novels, as instructional tools for teaching cartography. It explores how comics can enhance students' geographical competencies, critical thinking about cartographical issues, and interaction with 'maps as mappings'. Drawing on literary cartography, post-representational cartography theories, and 'comic book geography', the study analyzes comics' map-like features and suggests practical applications in cartography classes. Using examples from BeccoGiallo's series, it demonstrates how graphic novels promote active spatial practice and improve understanding of post-representational cartographical approaches, highlighting their unexplored educational potential.

title: Demand Distribution Dynamics in Creative Industries: the Market for Books in Italy
abstract: We study the distribution dynamics of the demand for books in Italy. We find that for each of three broad sub-markets in which the book publishing industry can be classified Italian novels, foreign novels and essays sales over a three-year sample can be adequately fitted by a power law distribution. Our results can be plausibly interpreted in terms of a model of interactions among buyers exchanging information on the books they buy.Book publishing industry; Information transmission; Power law distribution.
fieldOfStudy: English, Book publishing industry, Information transmission, Power law distribution, Creative industries, Economics
summary: This study investigates the distribution dynamics of book demand in Italy across Italian novels, foreign novels, and essays. The authors found that sales over a three-year period for these sub-markets can be effectively described by a power law distribution. These results are interpreted through a model where interactions among buyers, who exchange information about their book purchases, influence demand. Key concepts include book publishing industry, information transmission, and power law distribution, which are important for semantic search.

title:
POLA-POLA KEKERASAN TERHADAP PEREMPUAN DALAM RUMAH TANGGA DALAM NOVEL INDONESIA DALAM PERSPEKTIF PENGARANG PEREMPUAN DAN LAKI-LAKI: KAJIAN KRITIK SASTRA FEMINIS DAN 

 SOSIOLOGI SASTRA
abstract:
This study had a purpose to describe violence in the household forms that reflected in Indonesian novels, the violence in the household object’s in Indonesian novels, violence in the household agent,s in Indonesian novels, factors that formed the background of the violence in the household occurrence in Indonesian novels, the perspective of the writer of the woman and the man against violence in the household in his work novel.

 The study showed that there is three violence in the household forms that reflected in eight novels that were studied, that is the psychological violence, the physiological violence, an the sexual violence. The three shapes of this violence generally happen together or the bearing was connected. The physiological violence took the form of the action that caused was sick and the wound physically to himself object. The sexual violence took the form of sexual insulting and the rape that caused object psychological and physiological. Object violence in the household were the daughter, the wife, the nephew, the grandchild, and the brother. They became object violence because of having familial relations or remaining at one house with the agent. The agent violence were the mother, the father, the husband, the uncle, the grandmother, and the older brother. They were people that familial relations or remained at one house with the object. The violence in the household cause could be categorised to two matters, that is the social background of the culture that patriarchy and the psychological deviation the perpetrators. There were two perspectives from the men of letters against violence in the household . They are considered violence in the household must be opposed, both through words, the attitude, and the action. This view apparently in the work of Abdul Muis, Pramudya Ananta Toer, Eka Kurniawan, Nh. Dhini, Djenar Maesa Ayu, and Abidah El-Khalieqy. Only Budi Darma that had the view that violence in the household happened because of his agent experienced the spirit's deviation, so as impossible to be able to oppose him. In this case did not have the difference of the perspective between between the female man of letters and the man in seeing violence in the household.

 Key word: violence in the household, Indonesian novels

 FBS, 2008 (PEND. BHS & SASTRA INDONESIA
summary: This study analyzes violence in Indonesian novels, identifying psychological, physiological, and sexual forms, often co-occurring. It examines the objects (daughters, wives) and agents (mothers, fathers) of domestic violence, noting familial ties. Factors contributing to violence include patriarchal social culture and perpetrator psychological deviation. The research also explores writers' perspectives, with most authors advocating opposition to violence, unlike Budi Darma who attributes it to spiritual deviation. This highlights diverse narrative approaches to domestic violence in Indonesian literature. Key concepts include domestic violence, Indonesian novels, and literary criticism.

title: Streams in the Wilderness
abstract: Miranda Beale analyzes two award-winning novels by Marilynne Robinson, Gilead (2004) and Home (2008), identifying their major themes as the necessity of balancing parental responsibility and God\u27s loving guidance and redemptive power in raising children
fieldOfStudy: English, American Literature, Child Psychology, Counseling, Literature in English, North America, ethnic and minority
summary: Miranda Beale analyzes Marilynne Robinson's novels, "Gilead" (2004) and "Home" (2008), focusing on the intricate balance between parental responsibility and divine guidance in child-rearing. The study explores how characters like Jack, Ames, and Glory navigate the challenges of providing for and nurturing children, ultimately concluding that human effort alone is insufficient without God's providence. The novels convey the theme that parents must entrust their children to a higher power, even amidst their weighty obligations. This analysis offers insights into themes of family heritage, redemption, and faith in American literature.

title: Susan F. Russell, Associate Professor of Theatre Arts
abstract: In this new Next Page column, Susan F. Russell, Associate Professor of Theatre Arts, shares plays she recommends for anyone interested in reading plays for the first time and where Amish romance novels fit into her reading repertoire
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: English Language and Literature, Library and Information Science
summary:
This column features Susan F. Russell, Associate Professor of Theatre Arts, who provides recommendations for individuals new to reading plays. She suggests classics like Oscar Wilde's "The Importance of Being Earnest," Lorraine Hansberry's "A Raisin in the Sun," and Athol Fugard's "Master Harold

and the Boys." Russell also discusses her personal reading habits, including her enjoyment of Amish romance novels. The piece offers insights into play reading and highlights specific works that are engaging and thought-provoking for new readers.

title: Women between mirrors : the female body and sexuality in portuguese literature for young adults
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, Young Adult Literature, Portuguese Literature, Literary Criticism, Sociology of Literature
summary: This chapter examines the representation of the female body and sexuality in Portuguese young adult literature, emphasizing its role as a significant socialization tool. The authors analyze how these narratives influence young readers' perceptions of the world and interpersonal relationships, particularly regarding beauty standards and female identity. The study draws upon critical connections between literature and its production contexts, highlighting the impact of authors' and societal views on formative learning stages. It explores themes such as body image, self-perception, and evolving sexual identities as depicted in various Portuguese young adult novels.

title: A Data-Oriented Model of Literary Language
abstract:
We consider the task of predicting how literary a text is, with a gold
standard from human ratings. Aside from a standard bigram baseline, we apply
rich syntactic tree fragments, mined from the training set, and a series of
hand-picked features. Our model is the first to distinguish degrees of highly
and less literary novels using a variety of lexical and syntactic features, and
explains 76.0 % of the variation in literary ratings.Comment: To be published in EACL 2017, 11 page
summary: This paper presents a data-oriented model for predicting the literariness of a text, using human ratings as a gold standard. The authors employed a combination of a standard bigram baseline, rich syntactic tree fragments mined from a training set, and a series of hand-picked features. Their model is the first to effectively distinguish between degrees of highly and less literary novels, leveraging a variety of lexical and syntactic features. The approach explains 76.0% of the variation observed in human literary ratings, offering valuable insights into the quantifiable linguistic properties that define literary language.

title: “Dead cities, crows, the rain and their ripper, the Yorkshire ripper”: The red riding novels (1974, 1977, 1980, 1983) of David Peace as Lieux d’horreur
abstract: This article explores the role and importance of place in the Red Riding novels of David Peace. Drawing on Nora’s (1989) concept of Lieux de mémoire and Rejinders’ (2010) development of this work in relation to the imaginary world of the TV detective and engaging with a body of literature on the city, it examines the way in which the bleak Yorkshire countryside and the city of Leeds in the North of England, in particular, is central to the narrative of Peace’s work and the locations described are reflective of the violence, corruption and immorality at work in the storylines. While Nora (1984) and Rejinders (2010) describe places as sites of memory negotiated through the remorse of horrific events, the authors agree that Peace’s work can be read as describing L’ieux d’horreur; a recalling of past events with the violence and horror left in
summary:
This article investigates the crucial role of 'place' in David Peace's Red Riding novels. Employing Nora's 'Lieux de m
critiques in literary studies. It concludes that Peace's work vividly portrays 'Lieux d
horreur', leaving the violence and horror of past events intact for the reader.

title: Critical Reception since 1900
summary: This chapter examines the critical reception of Samuel Richardson's works since 1900, tracing how early 20th-century critics like Clara Linklater Thomson and Austin Dobson initially acknowledged his importance while noting his novels were no longer widely read due to their length. It highlights a recurring theme of the 19th and early 20th centuries: Richardson as a significant but neglected author. The analysis also explores how later critics re-evaluated Richardson, recognizing his unique strength in portraying the human heart's secrets, a quality that resonated with his first readers. This review provides insights into literary criticism, 18th-century literature, and the evolution of novel reading.

title: Making Ordinary: Recuperating the Everyday in Post-2005 Beirut Novels
abstract: I argue that young Lebanese novelists like Sahar Mandour and Hilal Chouman mobilize the ordinary as a way to 'write out' of the literary legacy of war and trauma writing that have characterized Lebanese fiction, without denying or suppressing Lebanon's violent past. I go on to argue that this discursive move of ‘making ordinary’ allows these writers to focus on pressing contemporary issues, such as a rising sense of economic and urban precarity in Beirut. In doing so, I bring the literary into conversation with the sociopolitical and the urban. I also make the case that this ‘descent into the ordinary’ compels us, as readers, towards a more nuanced understanding of such interventions by Lebanese youth into the multiple temporalities and shifting landscapes of Lebanon’s postwar period
fieldOfStudy: English, Lebanese literature, contemporary Arabic fiction, trauma studies, urban studies
summary: This article argues that young Lebanese novelists, specifically Sahar Mandour and Hilal Chouman, utilize the theme of the ordinary to break free from the prevalent literary tradition of war and trauma writing in Lebanese fiction. By focusing on everyday life, these authors address contemporary issues such as economic and urban precarity in Beirut, thus connecting literature with sociopolitical and urban concerns. The study suggests that this 'descent into the ordinary' offers readers a more nuanced understanding of how Lebanese youth engage with the complex temporalities and evolving landscapes of postwar Lebanon.

title: America Abandoned: German-Jewish Visions of American Poverty in Serialized Novels by Joseph Roth, Sholem Asch, and Michael Gold
abstract: In 1930, Hungarian- born Jewish author Arthur Holitscher’s book Wiedersehn mit Amerika: Die Verwandlung der U.S.A. (Reunion with America: The Trans-formation of the U.S.A.) was reviewed by one J. Raphael in the German- Jewish Orthodox weekly newspaper, Der Israelit. This reviewer concluded: “Despite its good reputation, America is a strange country. And Holitscher, whose relationship to Judaism is not explicit, but direct, has determined that to be the case for American Jews as well.” The reviewer’s use of the word “strange” (komisch) offers powerful insight into the complex perceptions of America held by many German- speaking Jews, which in 1930 were at best mixed and ambivalent. An earlier travel book by Arthur Holitscher (1869– 1941) from 1912 depicts America more favorably, though it is widely believed to have provided inspiration for Franz Kafka’s unfinished novel, Amerika: Der Verschollene (Amerika or The Man who Disappeared, published posthumously in 1927), which famously opens with a description of the Statue of Liberty holding aloft a sword rather than a torch. [excerpt
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: English, American Literature, German Language and Literature, Yiddish Language and Literature
summary: This study examines German-Jewish perceptions of America, particularly focusing on the ambivalence and negativity expressed in the 1930 review of Arthur Holitscher's "Wiedersehn mit Amerika." It contrasts this with Holitscher's earlier, more favorable 1912 travel book, which influenced Franz Kafka's "Amerika." The paper explores serialized novels by Joseph Roth, Sholem Asch, and Michael Gold to reveal recurring themes of American poverty and disillusionment among German-speaking Jews, challenging the 'New World' ideal. Keywords: German-Jewish literature, American perceptions, Arthur Holitscher, Franz Kafka, Joseph Roth, Sholem Asch, Michael Gold, serialized novels, poverty, immigration.

title: A day’s time: the one-day novel and the temporality of the everyday
abstract: This essay presents an investigation of the one-day-ness of the one-day novel—to ask what the effects of this temporal frame, in literary form, might be. I approach this question largely through the developing critical field of everyday life studies, in particular on literature and the everyday. There is a surprising paucity of literary criticism focused specifically on the narrative of the single day, and in this essay I launch further discussions of the form, particularly insofar as instances of the one-day novel can also (paradoxically) be read as novels of the everyday. In particular, I argue the one-day novel offers a model for a narrative that operates at a graspably human scale, having a particular capacity to reveal, attend to, and explore the apparently nonproductive or passive elements of everyday life; and that the form also interrogates on the capacity (or otherwise) for individuals to assert agency therein. Finally, I explore the paradoxical future orientation of the apparently bounded and closed single-day narrative structure
summary: This essay investigates the effects of the one-day temporal frame in novels, approaching the question through everyday life studies and literature. It addresses the surprising scarcity of literary criticism on single-day narratives, arguing that the one-day novel provides a model for narrative operating at a graspably human scale. The form reveals nonproductive or passive elements of everyday life, interrogates individual agency, and paradoxically exhibits a future orientation despite its bounded structure. This work aims to launch further discussions on the one-day novel and its relationship to the everyday, contributing to literary criticism and narrative theory.

title: Fractal Power Law in Literary English
abstract:
We present in this paper a numerical investigation of literary texts by
various well-known English writers, covering the first half of the twentieth
century, based upon the results obtained through corpus analysis of the texts.
A fractal power law is obtained for the lexical wealth defined as the ratio
between the number of different words and the total number of words of a given
text. By considering as a signature of each author the exponent and the
amplitude of the power law, and the standard deviation of the lexical wealth,
it is possible to discriminate works of different genres and writers and show
that each writer has a very distinct signature, either considered among other
literary writers or compared with writers of non-literary texts. It is also
shown that, for a given author, the signature is able to discriminate between
short stories and novels.Comment: 27 pages, 10 tables,15 figures. Revised version accepted in Physica
fieldOfStudy: English, Literary English, Statistical Mechanics, Lexical Wealth, Fractal Power Law
summary: This paper numerically investigates literary texts from well-known English writers of the first half of the twentieth century using corpus analysis. It establishes a fractal power law for lexical wealth (ratio of unique words to total words). By utilizing the exponent and amplitude of this power law, alongside the standard deviation of lexical wealth as an author's signature, the study successfully discriminates between different genres and writers, even distinguishing between short stories and novels by the same author. This method provides a distinct statistical signature for individual authors.

title: Mexican Indigenismo, Choctaw Self-Determination, And Todd Downing's Detective Novels
abstract: Englis
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, American Indian Literature, Cultural Studies
summary: This article examines Todd Downing's detective novels, particularly his refiguration of Mexican indigenismo. Downing, a prolific but neglected American Indian writer, used his experiences as a tour guide in postrevolutionary Mexico to critique the official celebration of Mexico's indigenous history and culture. The study reveals how Downing's work exposes the modern indigenous people obscured by indigenismo discourse. It highlights his unique contribution to American Indian literature by appropriating and transforming prevailing cultural narratives, offering insights into early 20th-century indigenous representation and self-determination within detective fiction.

title: Time, tide and narrative: adapting chronology in Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World
abstract: This paper is concerned with the 2003 film Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World, and with the book – or more accurately – books from which it is adapted. The film’s source material comes from novelist Patrick O’Brian who, between 1969 and his death in 2000, wrote 20 completed novels, plus one unfinished work. While no single text manifests a glaring temporal anomaly, taken as a whole it is apparent that numerous factors including the age of characters, aspects of their backstory, and especially the cumulative duration of several epic sea journeys do not cohere. It is not the object of this paper to treat this distortion as a failure. Rather, it is to focus on how the single screen adaptation engages with this aspect of its literary predecessors
publisher: U.S. National Maritime Museum - Mystic Seaport
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, Film Adaptation, Narrative Studies
summary: This paper examines the 2003 film "Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World" and its adaptation of Patrick O'Brian's 20-volume Aubrey/Maturin novel series. The study focuses on the chronological fluidity within O'Brian's literary canon, where character ages, backstories, and cumulative durations of sea journeys exhibit temporal inconsistencies when viewed as a whole, despite individual texts lacking glaring anomalies. The paper analyzes how the single screen adaptation engages with and navigates these chronological distortions present in its literary predecessors, highlighting the challenges and strategies in adapting a sprawling historical fiction series for film.

title: Film Adaption and Transnational Cultures or Production: The Case of Guillermo Arriaga
abstract: The circulation of Latin American cinema in a transnational context has widened the options that actors and directors from the region have regarding their involvement in the different aspects of film production. In order to analyze Guillermo Arriaga’s transnational career as a writer of novels and screenplays I contrast his work with that of other writers and filmmakers who have participated in both the cinematic and literary fields. The fact that Arriaga has crossed the lines between writing, adapting, and directing his own works in Spanish and English leads me to review the current relations of film and literature in general. Finally, by comparing Arriaga’s novels and films, I propose that the contemporary practice of film adaptation contributes to the “flexibilization” in the roles writers, actors, and directors play in filmmaking and in the circulation of cultural capital between film and literature in the current media markets
publisher: University of New Hampshire Scholars\u27 Repository
fieldOfStudy: English, Film Adaptation, Latin American Cinema, Transnational Culture, Guillermo Arriaga
summary:
This study analyzes Guillermo Arriaga



’s transnational career as a writer of novels and screenplays, contrasting his work with other writers and filmmakers in cinematic and literary fields. The research reviews current relations between film and literature, focusing on Arriaga



’s practice of writing, adapting, and directing his own works in both Spanish and English. It proposes that contemporary film adaptation contributes to the “flexibilization” of roles for writers, actors, and directors, and influences the circulation of cultural capital between film and literature in contemporary media markets, focusing on Latin American cinema.

title: Permeable borders, possible worlds: history and identity in the novels of Michèle Roberts
abstract: Since the publication of her first novel, A Piece of the Night, in 1978, Michele Roberts’ fiction has continually returned to epiphanic moments which elide divisions in time and space. Roberts uses her own experience as a woman of two cultures (English and French), as well as fictionalised histories of other women, to inform narratives in which the borders of history, culture and identity are figured as complex palimpsests. From the quasi-autobiographical narratives in A Piece of the Night and The Visitation (1983), Roberts moved on to rewrite biblical biographies of Mrs Noah (The Book of Mrs Noah, 1987) and Mary Magdalene (The Wild Girl, 1984). In In the Red Kitchen (1990) five female narrators ‘speak’ to each other, creating a textual dialogue in which conclusions are not fixed and time never stands still. Flesh and Blood (1994) offers a series of dovetailed narratives and withholds any sense of closure. With reference to feminist work on time and space, this essay examines the extent to which Roberts’ fiction engages with contemporary debates about the fragmentation and reconstruction of feminine identity. White argues that siting such discussion within narrative fiction offers a logical and accessible location for theorizing the (im)possible
summary:
This essay explores how Mich
ics fiction, from her first novel in 1978, consistently uses epiphanic moments to bridge temporal and spatial divides. Drawing on her bicultural background and fictionalized female histories, Roberts creates narratives where borders of history, culture, and identity are depicted as complex palimpsests. The study examines how Roberts' work, including "A Piece of the Night" and "The Wild Girl," engages with contemporary feminist debates on the fragmentation and reconstruction of feminine identity, arguing that narrative fiction provides an accessible platform for theorizing these concepts. Key themes include permeable borders, possible worlds, history, and feminine identity.

title: Religion and modernity in Spain: religious experience in the novels of Ramón Pérez de Ayala
abstract: While Ramón Pérez de Ayala is widely regarded as a leading liberal with strong anti-Catholic and indeed anti-religious views, a close examination of his novels reveals a more ambivalent attitude to religious experience. Indeed, his liberalism could be said to embrace religion in its spiritual, as distinct from its temporal, dimensions. This article examines a number of Pérez de Ayala's major novels and discusses his views on, among other things, his knowledge of biblical criticism, his views on transcendence, pantheism, education, Church and State, scholasticism, neo-Thomist aesthetics, sexuality, women and marriage. Perez de Ayala makes extensive use of the Bible and religious texts in his works and, in his advocacy of a return to the values of early Christianity, could be said to show affinities with religious or theological modernism, which is conventionally held not to have any impact within Spain
fieldOfStudy: English, Spanish Literature, Religious Studies, Modernism
summary:
This article examines the nuanced religious attitudes of Ram

P

rez de Ayala, conventionally seen as a staunch anti-Catholic liberal. Through a close analysis of his major novels, the study reveals his ambivalent embrace of religion's spiritual dimensions, distinct from its temporal aspects. It explores his engagement with biblical criticism, transcendence, pantheism, education, Church and State, scholasticism, neo-Thomist aesthetics, sexuality, women, and marriage. By demonstrating P

Perez de Ayala's extensive use of religious texts and advocacy for early Christian values, the author suggests affinities with religious modernism, challenging the notion of its absence in Spain and re-evaluating the perceived Manichean divide between liberalism and religion in fin-de-si

glo Spain. This reinterpretation positions P

Perez de Ayala as a modern homo religiosus, whose work anticipates liberal strands in post-Vatican II Catholicism.

title: BOOK REVIEW OF JONATHAN STROUD’S LOCKWOOD & CO.: THE SCREAMING STAIRCASE
abstract: Literature is an artwork from the expression of human's feeling and mind. One example for that artwork is novel. There are many novels that human has produced. With different theme, style and storyline, novel becomes a material reading in human world, especially for entertainment. In Theory of Literature, Wellek and Warren state, “Literature cannot be ‘studied' at all. We can only read, enjoy and appreciate it. Overall, we can only accumulate all kinds of information about literature” (1948:15). With that many themes of the novels that human has made, one of the themes that are interesting is horror. Horror usually has connection with mysterious things. With those mysteries, people will get the atmosphere, the feeling and the thought of the story. Sometimes, they will get the terror of the horror itself and make them shudder. They will try to solve the case while reading it as well. Even though, some unexpected accidents that happen will break the assumptions they have made as they read the novel
summary: This study presents a book review of Jonathan Stroud's novel, "Lockwood & Co.: The Screaming Staircase." It explores horror as a literary theme, emphasizing its connection to mysterious elements that evoke terror and challenge reader assumptions. The review aims to analyze the novel's effectiveness in delivering an entertaining and immersive reading experience, highlighting its blend of ghost stories, humor, and mysteries. This work contributes to literary analysis by focusing on the mechanics of horror in fiction and its impact on the reader's engagement.

title: From the national context to its margins : when the world used literature to respond to the Great War
abstract:
By shedding light on some original responses to the Great War that are today hardly known, and by asking the
same questions of many works written in contexts which were radically different, this STTCL special issue
advocates for a genuinely comparative approach to this literature. Born in a context of nationalist withdrawal,
these cultural objects also had a paradoxically wide circulation (due to early translations, commentaries,
literary reactions, and so on), which is why study of these apparently isolated writers is so valuable
