fieldOfStudy: English, Film and Media Studies, French and Francophone Literature, German Literature, Latin American Literature, Modern Literature, Spanish Literature
summary: This special issue advocates for a comparative approach to the literature of the Great War, highlighting original and lesser-known responses. Despite originating in nationalist contexts, these cultural objects achieved wide circulation through early translations and literary reactions. The study emphasizes the value of examining these seemingly isolated writers to understand the broader impact of the Great War on global literature. Key themes include national responses, literary circulation, and comparative literary studies of 20th and 21st-century literature related to WWI.

title: Faulkner\u27s Subject: A Cosmos No One Owns
abstract: Faulkner\u27s Subject offers a reading of William Faulkner for our time, and does so by rethinking his masterpieces through the lenses of current critical theory. The book attends equally to the power of his work and to the current theoretical issues that would call that power into question. Drawing on poststructuralist, ideological, and gender theory, Weinstein examines the harrowing process of becoming oneself at the heart of these novels. This self is always male, and it achieves focus only through strategically mystifying or marginalizing women and blacks. The cosmos he called his own--the textual world he produced, of which he would be sole owner and proprietor--merges as a cosmos no one owns, a verbal territory also generated (and biased) by the larger culture\u27s discourses of gender and race. Like personal identity itself, it is a cosmos no one owns
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, Critical Theory, Gender Studies
summary: This book reinterprets William Faulkner's masterpieces through the lens of contemporary critical theory, examining how his narratives construct male identity while often marginalizing women and Black characters. Drawing on poststructuralist, ideological, and gender theory, the author analyzes the complex process of self-formation within Faulkner's novels. It argues that Faulkner's textual world, initially conceived as his sole possession, ultimately emerges as a "cosmos no one owns," shaped by broader cultural discourses of gender and race. The study concludes by exploring a reconfigured notion of subjectivity—a contested, emergent self—instead of the traditional autonomous individual, finding Faulkner's work uniquely suited to delineate this disturbed but valuable figure.

title: Bridget Jones, Prince Charming, and Happily Ever Afters: Chick Lit as an Extension of the Fairy Tale in a Postfeminist Society
abstract: unpublishednot peer reviewe
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, Chick Lit, Fairy Tales, Postfeminism
summary: This senior thesis investigates chick lit as a contemporary extension of the fairy tale within a postfeminist societal context. The study aims to analyze how chick lit heroines like Bridget Jones embody traditional fairy tale tropes, such as the quest for a 'happily ever after,' while navigating modern challenges. It explores the genre's conventions, character archetypes, and its often-undeserved reputation, drawing parallels between the 'everywoman' protagonist's journey and classic narratives of self-discovery and romantic fulfillment. The work argues for the genre's significance in reflecting women's feelings and experiences in contemporary fiction, challenging dismissive critical perspectives.

title: El discurso subversivo de Rulfo o la autoridad de la palabra alienada
fieldOfStudy: English, Fiction, Latin American Literature, Modern Literature, Poetry, Literary Criticism, Mexican Literature
summary: This article examines the portrayal of women, violence, and sacrifice in Juan Rulfo's "Pedro P\u00e1ramo" (1955) and Carlos Fuentes' "La muerte de Artemio Cruz" (1962). It challenges initial interpretations that cast female characters as solely responsible for the male protagonists' misfortunes, instead exploring the complex dynamics of their relationships. The analysis delves into themes like unrequited love, the pursuit of success as compensation for loss, and the incestuous undertones, particularly in "Pedro P\u00e1ramo." Key concepts include female victimhood, male agency, literary criticism, and Mexican literature.

title: Singing in a new world: Scotland - hopeless schizophrenic or cosmopolitan post nation?
abstract:
Rival views of Scotland at the beginning of the twenty-first century see the nation as either, hopelessly schizophrenic, mired in its own bedevilled tartanry and forever salvaging the present through historic erasure or as a cosmopolitan postnation at ease with its contradictory legacies and able to tap its inherent multiplicities for a contemporary self image. These contentions are being interrogated in public debates and  political contexts as well as in literature in Scotland. The process of re-imagining or re-visioning Scotland began much earlier than 1999 when the Scottish Parliament, last adjourned in 1707, was reconvened. Contemporary authors have long been reconsidering issues of identity and how this could and should be represented in their writing.



This paper will examine how the underlying forces of insistent Scottish identity-making now seem to be moving in the direction of synthesis rather than fragmentation within literature, permitting multiple perspectives and a plurality of approaches through different genres, recognising other people’s rights to perceive or imagine Scotland differently. Anne Forbes’ novels Dragonfire,(2006) The Wings of Ruksh (2007) and The Underground City (2008), fully post-modern fantasy novels, will be used as examples of  ‘fusion’ texts introducing an optimistic new notion of ‘belonging’ transcending the cultural fatalism of the so-called ‘clash of civilisations’ hypothesis and building positively on the politics of difference. They represent a form of literary cosmopolitanism entirely consonant with the way Scottish society currently aspires to progress, offering the right set of circumstances for developing new forms of syncretistic myth-making and storytelling across and between communities
summary: This paper examines contemporary Scottish identity in literature, moving towards synthesis rather than fragmentation. It challenges rival views of Scotland as either "schizophrenic" or a "cosmopolitan postnation." Using Anne Forbes' postmodern fantasy novels—Dragonfire (2006), The Wings of Ruksh (2007), and The Underground City (2008)—as examples of "fusion" texts, the study introduces an optimistic notion of "belonging." It transcends cultural fatalism, builds on the politics of difference, and represents a literary cosmopolitanism aligned with Scotland's societal aspirations. The research highlights the development of new syncretistic myth-making and storytelling across communities, exploring how identity is accommodated within individual self-fashioning and shared socialization.

title: Why are the Children Dying?:  Mixed-Race Children in Chang-rae Lee’s First Five Novels
abstract: The mixed-race children in each of Lee’s first five novels constitute an overarching set of symbols, reflecting, at first, society’s intolerance of miscegenation and its resulting mixed offspring, as demonstrated in the dysfunctional behaviors of the parent(s) (or society) and the death or disappearance of the mixed-race child. Then, later in the novel, a second mixed-race child’s birth, or its impending birth, signifies an acquired racial awareness on the part of the parent(s) and an overcoming of trauma that leads to hope for a more tolerant and understanding social environment for the mixed-race child
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, Ethnic American Literature, Asian American Literature, Literary Criticism, Race and Ethnicity Studies
summary: This study examines the symbolic role of mixed-race children in Chang-rae Lee's first five novels, arguing that their initial portrayal reflects societal intolerance of miscegenation, often leading to tragic outcomes for the children. Later in the narratives, a subsequent mixed-race birth signifies the parent(s)' acquired racial awareness and a triumph over trauma, fostering hope for a more tolerant social environment. The research explores how these characters highlight the contemporary struggle for recognition by mixed-race people, particularly in the context of racial identification issues in the U.S. and the challenges of developing a mixed-race group identity, drawing on literary analysis and critical race theory.

title: Review of: Emily Petermann, The Musical Novel. Imitation of Musical Structure, Performance, and Reception in Contemporary Fiction, Camden House, 2014,
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, Philosophy of Art, Musicology
summary: This review examines Emily Petermann's "The Musical Novel," a book significant for both literary scholars and philosophers of art. Petermann explores the "musical novel" subgenre, defined by its formal imitation of musical structures rather than content. The work prompts a re-evaluation of classical problems such as the essence of music, boundaries of art forms, and the relationship between music and language through these unique textual artworks. The review highlights that Petermann emphasizes textual imitation over intersemiotic juxtaposition for achieving musical presence in novels, rigorously clarifying that a "musical" novel does not aspire to be music itself.

title: Place, paradox, and transcendental connection in three of E. M. Forster's novels : a thesis presented in partial fulfilment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Arts in English at Massey University
abstract: E. M. Forster's fiction reflects his own concern with the spirit of place and his seemingly fruitless search for a spiritual reconciliation between people and places. Three novels, Where Angels Fear to Tread, Howards End and A Passage to India, set out how place functions in Forster's fiction. In these, Forster poses what appears to be an insoluble question for the reader, and proves himself reluctant to achieve closure. This reluctance to provide answers to the theme of place is a reflection of the philosophical uncertainty which pervades his fiction. Readers are encouraged to arrive at their own conclusions and to negotiate the ambivalence of his novels in order to find their own answers to the baffling nature of life and relationships. Place, in Forster's fiction, contains an unseen force that is almost tangible. It determines the movement of the characters and guides them towards their intended destinations. The characters in his novels are transformed and manipulated by the device of genius loci; yet their changes never enable them to achieve permanent attachments with others nor with places. Although Forster's fiction shows no final harmonious home where ancestry and roots are established, the eponymous house in Howards End offers us a window. In it, the sisters achieve an affinity with place; however, there is still no space in which all of humanity can connect, and paradoxically, exclusion is essential to the final scene of reconciliation. Contradiction and opposition inform all of Forster's fiction. In each novel there are localities which represent the socially-controlled space on the one hand, and on the other, the unfettered region. Although Forster shows a Modernist tendency to nostalgically idealise the past, he continues to search for that delicate equilibrium between people and place. But just as he criticises and praises culture, he sees that the rural regions have their own contradictory attributes. This thesis traces Forster's treatment of place through personal, social, cultural, and spiritual sites, and the search for an esoteric home and transcendental reconciliation, becoming as it does an increasingly tentative and paradoxical theme
summary: This thesis explores E. M. Forster's concern with the "spirit of place" and his quest for spiritual reconciliation between people and places in his novels, specifically *Where Angels Fear to Tread*, *Howards End*, and *A Passage to India*. Forster's fiction presents place as an almost tangible, unseen force guiding characters, yet permanent attachments remain elusive. The study examines how contradiction and opposition, such as socially-controlled versus unfettered regions, inform his narratives. It traces Forster's treatment of place through personal, social, cultural, and spiritual sites, ultimately revealing a tentative and paradoxical search for an esoteric home and transcendental connection. Keywords: E. M. Forster, spirit of place, novels, literary criticism, transcendentalism, English literature.

title: Jumpstarting the future with Fredric Jameson: Reflections on capitalism, science fiction and Utopia
abstract: This paper turns around the key concern that it has become almost impossible to imagine a form of the future that is neither a prolongation of what already exists nor its apocalyptic demise. In trying to find ways of reconceiving the future in a more productive fashion, the paper relies heavily on Fredric Jameson?s work. Jameson worries that the traditional realist novel, which has featured so prominently in discussions of ?literature? in the field of organization studies, has committed itself far too readily to what he terms ?ontological realism?: the deliberate confusion of that which is meaningful with that which exists. He therefore explores the potential of Science Fiction (SF), and in particular radical SF from the 1960s and 1970s, for figuring a break with a hollowed-out present. This is achieved, for example, by transforming our own present into the past of something yet to come. It is as if Walter Benjamin?s angel of history would stand in an imaginary future with its face turned back towards our present. Such revelatory time-slips find their clearest expression in the novels of Philip K Dick, and it is to them that this paper will turn when working through some concrete examples
summary: This paper addresses the difficulty of imagining future forms beyond existing prolongations or apocalyptic ends, drawing on Fredric Jameson's work. It critiques the realist novel's "ontological realism" in organization studies, which confuses meaning with existence. The paper explores Science Fiction (SF), particularly radical SF from the 1960s and 1970s, as a means to break from the present by transforming it into the past of a future yet to come. It references Walter Benjamin's angel of history and examines concrete examples in Philip K. Dick's novels to illustrate revelatory time-slips and reconceive the future productively, with keywords including capitalism, ideology, Jameson, novel, PK Dick, science fiction, and utopia.

title: Using \u27The Autobiography of Malcolm X\u27 to Teach Introductory Sociology
abstract: In this chapter, we make the case for using The Autobiography of Malcolm X to teach introductory sociology classes. While The Autobiography of Malcolm X is an autobiography and not a novel, we summarize the literature on using novels in sociology and compare this literature to our own experiences using autobiographies in the classroom. We then describe how autobiographies are particularly helpful for introducing students to the concept of the ‘‘sociological imagination’’ before highlighting this with an in-class exercise. Finally, we discuss student feedback and some of the drawbacks to using autobiographies and the extent to which these drawbacks can be mitigated. [excerpt
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: English, Curriculum and Instruction, Educational Methods, Educational Sociology, Higher Education
summary: This chapter argues for using "The Autobiography of Malcolm X" in introductory sociology classes. It synthesizes existing literature on employing novels in sociology education and compares this with experiences using autobiographies. The authors detail how autobiographies effectively introduce students to the 'sociological imagination,' illustrated with an in-class exercise. The discussion also covers student feedback, addressing potential drawbacks and mitigation strategies for using autobiographies in teaching sociology.

title: Rewriting truth: The End o f TheNarrative Act in Two Southern Cone Detective Novels
summary: This article rereads two Southern Cone detective novels to analyze the concept of "rewriting truth" and the conclusion of the narrative act. It examines how these texts, unlike those that exhaust themselves in a single reading, encourage rereading and new interpretive approaches. The study delves into the narrative strategies that suggest a truer story might exist beyond the initial solution presented, thereby challenging conventional interpretations of detective fiction. Key themes include narrativity, reading concepts, and the metaphysical detective story.

title: Introduction
abstract: This chapter outlines the scope of the book, discusses Rose Macaulay's life and writing, and summarises the other chapters in the book, making connections to their coherence as a unified argument that Macaulay was a writer of modernity in British literary culture of the twentieth century
summary: This introduction outlines the scope of a book focusing on Rose Macaulay, a prolific British novelist and woman of letters (1881-1958). It discusses Macaulay's life and writing, summarizing subsequent chapters to argue for her significance as a writer of modernity in twentieth-century British literary culture. The collection of essays explores Macaulay's work, establishing connections between modernism and the middlebrow, and examining how her writing mediates these two modes. It also focuses on gender and genre, using key texts to illustrate how Macaulay navigated modernist modes and middlebrow concerns, bridging a perceived divide in literary criticism. This work highlights her unique position within British literary culture.

title: Women in Thomas Hardy's novels : an interpretative study : a thesis presented in partial fulfilment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Arts in English at Massey University
abstract: When one begins a study of the women in Hardy's novels one discovers critical views of great diversity. There are features of Hardy's work which received favourable comment then as now; his descriptions of nature for instance, and his rustic characters have appealed to most critics over the years. But his philosophical and social comment have drawn criticism ranging from the virulent to the scornful. In particular his attitude to and treatment of love and marriage relationships have been widely argued, and it is the women concerned who have been assessed in the most surprising and contradictory manner. The first critic of stature was Lionel Johnson¹Lionel Johnson, The Art of Thomas Hardy (1894). London, 1923, p.193. best known as a poet. In 1894 he wrote of Hardy's women: 'I cannot think that any of them is so powerfully conceived and drawn as are the best of the men;' but he adds that they provoke an 'amazed awe of their infinite ingenuities,' and quotes a remark of Swift's about the pleasure that a few words 'spoken plain by a parrot will give.' [FROM INTRODUCTION
summary: This interpretive study examines the diverse critical views surrounding women in Thomas Hardy's novels, exploring aspects of his work that have garnered both praise and criticism, particularly his philosophical and social commentary, and his treatment of love and marriage. The thesis analyzes how female characters have been assessed in contradictory ways, referencing early critics like Lionel Johnson. Chapters delve into plot and character, women and nature, class, morality, love and marriage, and divorce, aiming to understand the complex portrayal of women and their roles within Hardy's narratives.

title: Martha Ostenso, literary history, and the Scandinavian diaspora
abstract: Through a case study of Martha Ostenso, this essay explores the exclusionary practices of literary history, and the ability of migrant writers to destabilise constructs of nation and region. Ostenso's career has been presented in strikingly different ways by Canadian and American literary historians, and she is inscribed into a variety of incompatible narratives of immigrant assimilation or regional literary development. Neither American nor Canadian critics, however, pay attention to Ostenso's use of Scandinavian material, perhaps because the Scandinavian diaspora disrupts nationalist literary histories by crossing political and cultural boundaries between America and Canada. This essay revises accepted views of Ostenso's reputation by concentrating on her multiple ethnic, national and regional identification, and it also initiates critical recuperation of some of Ostenso's neglected novels, The Young May Moon (1929), The White Reef (1934) and Prologue To Love (1932)
summary: This essay examines the exclusionary practices within literary history through a case study of Martha Ostenso, a migrant writer. It highlights how Ostenso's career is interpreted differently by Canadian and American literary historians, often without acknowledging her Scandinavian heritage. The study argues that the Scandinavian diaspora challenges nationalist literary narratives by transcending political and cultural borders between America and Canada. The research revises existing perceptions of Ostenso's reputation by focusing on her multiple ethnic, national, and regional identifications, and initiates critical recuperation of her neglected novels: 'The Young May Moon', 'The White Reef', and 'Prologue To Love'.

title: [Review of] Simon Gikandi. Reading the African Novel
abstract: Gikandi, has added an excellent critical work to his earlier volumes on new African writers. Employing the techniques of modern criticism, he analyzes significant works of eleven African writers including, among others, Wole Soyinka, Chinua Achebe, Ferdinand Oyono, and Ayi Kwei Armah. He is concerned with the form-content relationship in the novels examined, as well as the part played by centers of consciousness of main characters. As he states, he set out to  show how ... life and consciousness  move from external reality of the novel to  interiority
summary: This critical work by Simon Gikandi analyzes significant novels from eleven African writers, including Wole Soyinka and Chinua Achebe, focusing on the form-content relationship and the role of character consciousness. Gikandi explores how life and consciousness transition from external reality to interiority within these narratives, particularly addressing post-colonial themes of national and personal identity. The study is considered essential for understanding the African novel and may serve as a foundational text for future critical analyses in this literary field.

title: Everyman with fangs: The acceptance of the modern vampire
abstract: The vampire, an enduring demon from the European middle ages has through the course of the 20th century undergone a journey of transformation. The journey of the beast describes a circle, starting and ending with the depiction of the vampire as a soulless, evil killing machine. From the Middle Ages, moving into the 18th century the vampire slowly becomes more sophisticated, becoming first Varney, then Dracula, then in the last quarter of the 20th century as the accepted and understood Vampires Louis and Lestat. From there the vampire is found in television, theatre and cinema in such films as Fright Night, Blade, and The Lost Boys. Finally with the appearance of Buffy the Vampire Slayer, the vampire becomes once again everyman with fangs and the circular journey began in the European Middle Ages has been completed
publisher: Massey University. Department of Management and International Business
summary: This paper examines the 20th-century transformation of the vampire mythos, tracing its evolution from a soulless, evil entity in the Middle Ages to more sophisticated figures like Varney and Dracula, and later, the "accepted and understood" vampires such as Louis and Lestat. It discusses the vampire's portrayal in various media, including television and cinema (e.g., Fright Night, Blade, The Lost Boys), concluding with its depiction in Buffy the Vampire Slayer, which completes a cyclical journey back to the "everyman with fangs." Key concepts include vampire evolution, cultural acceptance, and media representation.

title: Gender, conflict, continuity: Anne Brontë's 'The Tenant of Wildfell Hall' (1848) and Sarah Grand's 'The Heavenly Twins' (1893)
abstract: This is the author's accepted manuscript. The final published article is available from the link below. Copyright @ 2010 W. S. Maney & Son Ltd.The New Woman fiction of the fin de siècle brought into conflict patriarchal and feminist ideologies, challenging widely held assumptions about gender roles and the position of women. Sarah Grand's The Heavenly Twins is an important contribution to the genre, and engages with a number of the key issues that concerned feminists at the end of the nineteenth century, including marriage, the education of women, the double standard, male licentiousness, and the wider issue of social purity. These are also key themes in Anne Brontë's The Tenant of Wildfell Hall — published nearly fifty years before Grand's seminal New Woman text. In this essay, I consider Anne Brontë's text as a forerunner to the New Woman fiction of the fin de siècle, through a comparative examination of The Tenant of Wildfell Hall and The Heavenly Twins
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, New Woman Fiction, Victorian Sensation Fiction, Feminism, Brontë Studies
summary: This essay comparatively examines Anne Brontë’s *The Tenant of Wildfell Hall* and Sarah Grand’s *The Heavenly Twins*, positioning Brontë's work as a precursor to fin de siècle New Woman fiction. It explores how both novels challenge patriarchal and feminist ideologies, focusing on themes such as gender roles, marriage, women's education, the double standard, male licentiousness, and social purity. This analysis highlights continuities in feminist concerns across nearly fifty years of nineteenth-century English literature, emphasizing the genre's engagement with societal assumptions about women's position.

title: Reading (in/and) Miranda
abstract:
"Australian fiction, like that of all nations, is written, published,
received and read in the context of a literary canon, both national and
transnational. In regards to women's fiction in Australia, this canon is
predominantly composed of writers from two particular eras: authors of the
nineteenth and early twentieth centuries (like Henry Handel Richardson, Miles
Franklin, Katharine Susannah Prichard and Christina Stead) and women writers
who came to prominence during the 1980s (like Helen Garner, Kate Grenville,
Elizabeth Jolley, Barbara Hanrahan, Jessica Anderson and Beverley Farmer ... The second-wave feminist movement was responsible for the creation of this
dual canon: in the first case, due to a desire to recover and reclaim women
writers of the past, and in the second, due to a desire to celebrate and explore
contemporary Australian women's fiction. Indeed, it is the preoccupation of
second-wave feminism with uncovering and celebrating women's occluded
stories that underlies the current critical focus on realist and experiential aspects
of Australian women's fiction ... Among those whose work has been occluded by the critical attention given to the canonical figures of Australian women's writing, Wendy Scarfe is indicative
in various ways.
summary: This study examines the national and transnational literary canon of Australian women's fiction, particularly focusing on how second-wave feminism shaped its dual composition. The canon primarily includes nineteenth/early twentieth-century authors like Henry Handel Richardson and Christina Stead, and 1980s writers such as Helen Garner and Kate Grenville. The purpose of this framework was to recover past women writers and celebrate contemporary Australian women's fiction, emphasizing realist and experiential aspects. The analysis highlights figures like Wendy Scarfe, whose work has been overlooked due to this critical focus on canonical authors. Keywords: Australian women's fiction, literary canon, second-wave feminism, Wendy Scarfe, literary criticism.

title: Where the Evidence Leads: Teaching Gothic Novels and the Law
summary: This essay outlines a pedagogical approach for teaching British gothic novels through the lens of late eighteenth and early nineteenth-century legal issues. The author, Diane Hoeveler, integrates formalist, historicist, ideological, and psychoanalytic theoretical frameworks, emphasizing the role of law as a significant historical and ideological element. It explores how gothic literature addresses contested legal concepts, critiques the evolving legal system's biases, and reflects a nostalgia for premodern providential justice. The approach aims to help students understand the dynamic interaction between literature and the law, and how novels contributed to public debates on rights and legal evolution.

title:
Course Materials for 'Understanding Screenwriting' - FA/FILM 4501 12.0,

2002-2003
abstract: Overview, Outline, Readings and Guidelines (for students) with the Schedule of Lectures and Screenings (for private use of EWC) for an extraordinary double-weighted full-year course for advanced students of screenwriting, meeting for six hours weekly with each term of work constituting a full six-credit course, that the author was permitted to teach within the Graduate Programme of the Department of Film & Video, Faculty of Fine Arts, York University during the academic years 2001-2002 and 2002-2003
summary: This document outlines 'Understanding Screenwriting,' an advanced, double-weighted full-year course offered within the Graduate Programme of the Department of Film & Video at York University during the academic years 2001-2003. Taught by Professor Emeritus Evan Wm. Cameron, the course met for six hours weekly, providing an in-depth exploration of screenwriting's historical evolution and practical constraints. It offered advanced students a unique opportunity to understand prior achievements in screenwriting and analyze various films, including 'Distant Voices, Still Lives,' 'Betrayed,' 'Monsieur Hire,' and 'Four Weddings and a Funeral,' focusing on screenwriting techniques across different eras.

title: Levinas’ notion of neighbor as an approach to understand Pío Baroja, otherness and modern Spain.
abstract: The Cold War era touched Spain only subtly. Because of the geopolitical situation of Europe during the second half of the 20th century, Spain remained almost isolated from macro politics, attempting impossible alliances with Italian and German fascism. For instance, whilst the rest of the world witnesses the beginning of the Cold War in 1947 and the Space Race, Spain’s history is marked by the death of a “matador”, Manuel Laureano Rodriguez “Manolete”, who copes the newspapers’ front pages for days and is followed by popular grief and controversy. Four decades before, Miguel de Unamuno already coins this ancestral voice of the Spaniard consciousness as “casticismo” and “intrahistoria”. However, in literary terms, Iberian literature showed clear signs of modernity, and sometimes, even of hybridity. The Iron Curtain did not cover the shame of a dictatorship regime in Spain, and yet, authors like Baroja describe that atmosphere at a great extent, even, as this paper wants to show, anticipates the Cold War psycho-social atmosphere. Authors like Levinas, on the other hand, provide a philosophical and theoretical frame to understand better both the Cold War period and the literary experimentation of Iberian authors towards the concept of the Other. In this piece, I discuss the proximity of the notion of the Other in Levinas and Baroja, and contrast this approach with the canonical vision of Baroja in Iberian literature
summary: This paper examines Spain's subtle engagement with the Cold War era, highlighting its historical isolation from macro politics despite impossible alliances. It contrasts this geopolitical situation with the vibrant modernity and hybridity observed in Iberian literature. The study specifically anticipates the Cold War's psycho-social atmosphere through the works of author Baroja and employs Levinas's philosophical framework to understand the concept of the Other within this period's literary experimentation. The authors discuss the proximity of Levinas's and Baroja's notions of the Other, offering a fresh perspective that challenges canonical interpretations of Baroja in Iberian literature.

title: Laurant Ropa and Paul Achard : second thoughts on colonial encroachments
abstract: Laurent Ropa’s The Song of the Noria (1932) and Paul Achard’s Man from the Sea (1931) are twin novels which deal with the Maltese community that settled in Algeria under French rule. Today, in hindsight, the reader realizes that the Arabs and Berbers, who in colonial literature are treated with paternalism, were later on in 1962 to ‘turn the tables on’ the European community. In this paper, I intend to dwell on a double insularity, that is, on islanders who in the long run turn out to belong to a besieged community.peer-reviewe
publisher: University of Malta. Department of History
summary: This paper analyzes Laurent Ropa's "The Song of the Noria" (1932) and Paul Achard's "Man from the Sea" (1931), two novels depicting the Maltese community in French-ruled Algeria. The study re-evaluates colonial literature, particularly the paternalistic portrayal of Arabs and Berbers, in light of Algeria's 1962 independence. The author explores the concept of "double insularity," where islanders become a besieged community. It considers how French colonization created a cosmopolitan society and examines the Maltese contribution while noting the distinct character traits from their defiant archipelago. The analysis highlights the importance of time and space in Algerianist literature, broadening insularity's meaning to include ideological isolation.

title: Tyranny of Sentimental Form: Wollstonecraft’s \u3cem\u3eMary\u3c/em\u3e and the Gendering of Anxiety
summary: This paper examines the "Tyranny of Sentimental Form" in Mary Wollstonecraft's novel "Mary," focusing on how the culture of sensibility, despite its radical promise, failed to transform gender relations. It argues that sensibility, often associated with female virtues, inadvertently highlighted women's perceived weaknesses and confinement to the private sphere, contrasting with the male-privileged realm of 'Sense,' reason, and public discourse. The study analyzes Wollstonecraft's conflicted view of sensibility and its impact on the gendering of anxiety, suggesting that without external threats or social purpose, female sensibility risked becoming self-indulgent. Key entities include Mary Wollstonecraft, G. J. Barker-Benfield, and Mary.

title: Body Language: Reading the Corpse in Forensic Crime Fiction .
abstract: Our purpose in this article is to explore the fascination, over the last decade, with crime narratives that centre on the figure of the forensic pathologist. Principally this involves a reading of Cornwellâ��s Scarpetta series, but we also discuss a growing number of other novels that confront readers with the â��realityâ�� of the dead body. In some cases (for example, Kathy Reichs and Priscilla Masters) writers use, as Cornwell does, the figure of the forensic pathologist; in other instances, such as Nicci Frenchâ��s The Red Room (2001) and Jan Burkeâ��s Bones (1999), the female protagonistâ��s reading of the crime is determined by alternative forms of first-hand access to the â��underworldâ�� of the grave or autopsy room, such as that of the crime journalist or criminal psychologist. In contrast to the kind of police procedural novel that gives centre-stage to the psyche of the serial killer, the forensic pathology novel aims instead to evoke the â��appalling human messinessâ�� of actual crime through a perspective nearer to that of the victim. By providing readers with not only a body of experts but an expert on the body the novelist allows them to listen to the voices of the dead
summary: This article explores the growing fascination with crime narratives featuring forensic pathologists, particularly Patricia Cornwell's Scarpetta series, alongside other novels by authors like Kathy Reichs and Priscilla Masters. It contrasts these works, which often use crime journalists or criminal psychologists, with traditional police procedurals. The authors argue that forensic pathology novels aim to convey the "appalling human messiness" of crime by adopting a victim-centric perspective, allowing readers to engage directly with the "voices of the dead" through the expert on the body rather than focusing on the serial killer's psyche.

title: Menorah Review (No. 41, Fall, 1997)
abstract: The Jewish Image in American Fiction -- An Endless Journey? -- A Summer\u27s Game -- The Exilic Home of Jewish Literature -- Book Listing -- Book Briefing
fieldOfStudy: English, History of Religion, Religious Thought, Theology and Philosophy of Religion, Jewish Studies
summary: This issue of Menorah Review explores the portrayal of Jewish identity in American fiction, examining how these literary images reflect the viability of American Jewry as a people and a religion. Dr. Richard E. Sherwin's lecture analyzes literary and popular novels from the 1950s to the 1990s to uncover these representations. Additionally, the issue includes discussions on Erich Fromm's philosophy of "being" versus "having," Dennis Prager's essays on contemporary American problems and ethical monotheism, and a Holocaust survival narrative. The collection offers insights into Jewish thought, identity, and resilience.

title: Vindicating \u3cem\u3eNorthanger Abbey\u3c/em\u3e: Wollstonecraft, Austen, and Gothic Feminism
fieldOfStudy: English, Literary Criticism, Feminist Theory, Gothic Literature
summary: This article, "Vindicating Northanger Abbey: Wollstonecraft, Austen, and Gothic Feminism," explores the intersection of literary criticism, feminist thought, and the Gothic genre in Jane Austen's novel. It examines how Austen's work, particularly *Northanger Abbey*, engages with the ideas of Mary Wollstonecraft and challenges traditional gender roles through its narrative structure and themes. The study delves into the concept of "gothic feminism" and analyzes how female characters navigate societal expectations, control, and information management, drawing parallels with anthropological studies on gossip and its social functions.

title: Naipaul's Women.
abstract: V.S. Naipaul's three novels of the 1970s (In a Free State, Guerrillas and A Bend in the River) earned him a reputation as a misogynist. The only sustained critical examination of women in his fiction came in the late seventies and eighties as a reaction to these novels. In this paper I attempt a survey of female characters in Naipaul's fiction across his whole career to establish to what extent this reputation is justified, and whether his harsh treatment of some female characters is matched by equally critical attitudes to male characters. While early conditioning has given Naipaul a traditional view of women’s roles, he cannot be said to show a consistent dislike of women, as his female characters range from the admirable to the repugnant in the same way as his male characters do. Much of the misogyny identified by critics is, on closer examination, attributable to characters rather than Naipaul himself
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, Literary Criticism, Gender Studies
summary: This paper surveys female characters across V.S. Naipaul's entire fiction career to assess the justification of his misogynist reputation, particularly in response to his 1970s novels. The study examines whether his harsh treatment of some female characters is balanced by equally critical attitudes towards male characters. The findings indicate that while Naipaul holds traditional views of women's roles due to early conditioning, he does not exhibit consistent misogyny, as his female characters range from admirable to repugnant, mirroring his male characters. Much of the perceived misogyny is attributed to characters within his narratives rather than Naipaul himself.

title: "So many people going the other way" : an examination of the moral strategy of language usage in five novels by Janet Frame : a thesis presented in partial fulfilment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Arts in English at Massey University
abstract: The title quotation is from Janet Frame's novel, Living in the Maniototo (72). Abbreviations and editions of the five primary sources referred to in the text are as follows: EA The Edge of the Alphabets London: W.H. Allen & Co., 1962. SG Scented Gardens for the Blind. London: The Women's Press Ltd., 1982. SS A State of Siege. London: Sirius, 1989. LM Living in the Maniototo. London: The Women's Press Ltd., 1981. CP The Carpathians. London: Century Hutchinson Ltd., 1988. Some of the ideas developed in the chapter on Living in the Maniototo were first sketched out in a paper on that novel (39.498) written in 1990. I wish to thank my supervisor, Dr William Broughton, for his influence and patient guidance in the preparation of this thesis. Sincere thanks also to my husband, Geoff, and our children Mark and Bronwyn for their enthusiastic support
summary: This thesis examines the moral strategy of language usage in five novels by Janet Frame: "The Edge of the Alphabet," "Scented Gardens for the Blind," "A State of Siege," "Living in the Maniototo," and "The Carpathians." The study analyzes how Frame manipulates narrative elements, character fates, and reader expectations through techniques like confusing character appearances, black humor, and challenging concepts such as the Gravity Star and Memory Flower. It aims to reveal Frame's sovereignty as an author and her use of a theological paradigm where salvation is reserved for an elite few who meet her criteria for language usage. The research explores the creative process of writing fiction and its supreme value to Frame, providing insights into her unique narrative demands on the reader.

title: The Wide Reach of Salvation: Christian Universalism in the Novels of Denise Giardina
summary: This article examines the theme of Christian universalism in the novels of Denise Giardina, arguing that her work, beyond her well-known Appalachian novels like *Storming Heaven* and *The Unquiet Earth*, merits broader academic attention. It critiques the tendency to pigeonhole Giardina as a regionalist, asserting that her lesser-known works also explore profound theological and ethical questions. The analysis seeks to highlight the consistent presence of universalist perspectives on salvation across her diverse literary output, suggesting a deeper engagement with Christian theology than often recognized. Key methods involve close textual analysis of her various novels to identify and interpret these theological undercurrents.

title: On Alan Goldman’s  Philosophy And The Novel
summary: This work critiques Alan Goldman's "Philosophy and the Novel," appreciating his methodological stance while offering three critical thoughts. The author, Richard Eldridge, explores how specific novels achieve their philosophical insights and discusses the role of reading experiences in character formation. Eldridge also emphasizes the importance of authorial stances, characterized by heightened attentiveness and horror, as objects of readerly engagement. The text suggests that the formal and thematic achievements of novels can symbolize and stand for alternative ways of life, even amid bleak subject matter. Keywords: Alan Goldman, Philosophy and the Novel, literary criticism, authorial stance, readerly engagement, character formation, literary philosophy.

title: Communication and mass media in delillo’s white noise and pynchon’s the crying of lot 49
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, Mass Media, Communication Studies
summary: This study examines Don DeLillo's 'White Noise' and Thomas Pynchon's 'The Crying of Lot 49' as seminal examples of "Image Fiction" novels, exploring how these works make visible the profound influence of television and mass media on modern society and individual communication. It investigates the thematic and ideological resources employed by these authors to depict a generation born into a televisual culture, where perceived reality is often mediated by cameras. The analysis highlights how media impacts authority and alters characters' communication styles, further connecting these themes to the role of drugs. This research contributes to understanding modern literature's engagement with technology and media studies.

title: The Transformation of the Mother-Daughter Relationship in Amy Tan’s The Joy Luck Club and The Bonesetter’s Daughter
abstract:
The mother/daughter bond is the central subject of Amy Tan’s two powerful books, The Joy
Luck Club and The Bonesetter’s Daughter. Tensions that arise in the novels between a Chinese
mother and her Chinese-American daughter are often described by the critics as being the
result of two important factors. One is based on the misunderstandings caused by the
generational gap, while the other comes from the cultural gap. For a Chinese-born mother the
American reality instigates various confusions, as she still views her life with the eyes of her
traditional Chinese upbringing. On the other hand, her daughter lacks any profound
knowledge about her Chinese ethnicity, which makes her unable to recognize the influences of
her mother’s Chinese past over their relationship. But in her novels Tan portrays also the
relationship between the Chinese immigrant mother and her mother in China. Their
relationship, which grew up exclusively on the grounds of the Chinese culture, is
characterized by empathy and appreciation. In this paper I am going to discuss the change
that occurred to the mother-daughter relationship after it has been replanted into a different
cultural context. The line of argument will reveal in what ways the mother-daughter
relationship underwent a significant transformation
publisher: Department of Studies in Drama and Pre-1800 English Literature, University of Łódź
summary: This paper analyzes the transformation of the mother-daughter relationship in Amy Tan's novels, "The Joy Luck Club" and "The Bonesetter's Daughter." It explores how tensions arise from generational and cultural gaps between Chinese mothers and their Chinese-American daughters. While Chinese immigrant mothers maintain traditional views, their American-born daughters often lack understanding of their heritage, leading to misunderstandings. In contrast, relationships between mothers and grandmothers within a purely Chinese cultural context are characterized by empathy. The study examines how these relationships change when transplanted into a different cultural environment.

title: Fantastical conversations with the other in the self: Dorothy L. Sayers (1893–1957) and her Peter Wimsey as Animus
abstract: Dorothy L. Sayers created in her fictional character Lord Peter Wimsey a “contrasexual” figure in her own imagination, with whom she carried on an extended dialogue over many years. C.G. Jung's concept of the contrasexual archetype, the anima (in men) or the animus (in women), can provide a very useful tool for investigating the presence of this transgendered voice within the self. Specifically in relation to Sayers and her Wimsey, Jung's theory can uncover the successful conversion of a potentially “bad animus” into a positive one, or, in other words, Sayers's successful creation in herself of her own “masculine” voice to replace the harmful voice of the patriarchy. Not unlike Hélène Cixous's concept of the “other bisexuality,” the contrasexual element in Sayers provides a model too for her readers to “speak woman” in a full or rounded way
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, Jungian Psychology, Gender Studies
summary: This essay investigates Dorothy L. Sayers's creation of Lord Peter Wimsey as a "contrasexual" figure, utilizing C.G. Jung's concept of the animus. It explores how Sayers's extended dialogue with Wimsey can be understood as the successful conversion of a potentially negative animus into a positive, internal "masculine" voice, replacing patriarchal influences. The study suggests that Sayers's contrasexual element, akin to Hélène Cixous's "other bisexuality," offers a model for readers to embrace a more complete feminine voice. Key themes include Jungian psychology, literary analysis, gender identity, and feminist theory.

title: Colonial Trauma in Márquez and Rushdie’s Magical Realism
abstract: Gabriel García Márquez’s One Hundred Years of Solitude and Salman Rushdie’s Midnight’s Children are hallmarks of the genre of magical realism. A typically problematic genre in terms of classification, this article looks at magical realism from a Freudian perspective, with particular reference to Freud’s notion of The Uncanny. Freud’s notion of uncanniness deals in displacement; it is uncomfortable, haunting and cyclical. The dominant presence of such uncanny effects in magical realist literature, I argue, reveals the haunting presence of colonial trauma within the current postcolonial psyche
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, Literary Criticism, Postcolonial Studies
summary: This article examines magical realism in Gabriel García Márquez’s *One Hundred Years of Solitude* and Salman Rushdie’s *Midnight’s Children*. It applies a Freudian perspective, specifically the notion of "The Uncanny," to analyze the genre. The author argues that the pervasive uncanny effects in magical realist literature reveal the persistent influence of colonial trauma within the postcolonial psyche. This study contributes to understanding magical realism, Freudian psychoanalysis, postcolonial literature, and colonial trauma.

title: More Gothic Gold: The Sadleir-Black Chapbook Collection at the University of Virginia Library
summary: This article, "More Gothic Gold," explores the Sadleir-Black Chapbook Collection of Gothic Fiction at the University of Virginia Library. Following Fred Frank's earlier work, the author surveys the collection, including books donated by Nancy Frank from Fred's core Gothic collection. The study aims to highlight the collection's significance for understanding Gothic literature and its historical context, particularly chapbook gothic romances. Key themes include the evolution of Gothic novels, literary scholarship, and the preservation of historical texts. The research methods involve archival research and textual analysis.

title: The Beauty and the Barrister: Gender Roles, Madness, and the Basis for Identity in Lady Audley\u27s Secret
abstract: This thesis examines the concept of identity in the novel Lady Audley’s Secret by Mary Elizabeth Braddon. In the mid to late Victorian period, self-definition was strongly tied to gender roles. Men were expected to be mentally active, physical strong, and morally guiding leaders of society, and women were to be their passive, pious, domestically minded followers. These expectations for behavior were so strong that those breaking them were in danger of being considered insane. In Braddon’s novel, the behavior of most characters does not align with the expectations for their gender. The exception is Lady Audley, the apparently ideal woman whose beauty and charm mask a vicious and criminal nature. Her plea of insanity, while it may offer an excuse for her unfeminine behavior, does not pardon her crimes. However, hero Robert Audley’s behavior is absolutely effeminate, but he has a strong moral sense and total devotion to his loved ones. Their deviation from or adherence to gender-appropriate behaviors does not change their essential natures. In Lady Audley’s Secret, Braddon uses gender roles and the theme of insanity to critique the Victorian conception of identity
summary: This thesis critically examines the concept of identity in Mary Elizabeth Braddon's novel, Lady Audley's Secret, focusing on Victorian gender roles and the theme of insanity. It explores how societal expectations for men and women's behavior were deeply intertwined with self-definition, and how deviations could lead to accusations of madness. The study analyzes characters like Lady Audley, whose apparent feminine ideal masks criminality, and Robert Audley, whose 'effeminate' behavior contradicts Victorian norms yet is coupled with strong morals. The central claim is that Braddon uses these character portrayals to critique Victorian identity conceptions, highlighting that essential natures transcend gender-appropriate behaviors. Key themes include Victorian literature, gender roles, identity, and insanity.

title: The middle years of Martin Amis
abstract: This essay was commissioned by Rod Mengham and Philip Tew for their volume British Fiction Today (London and New York: Continuum, 2006). Essays for this volume were specifically requested to focus on writers’ work since 1990. Thus the essay does not pretend to be a detailed account of Amis’s entire career, only to describe, contextualize and assess one stretch of it. The essay was written in summer 2005; hence the last major Amis work referred to here is Yellow Dog (2003). The system of referencing also reflects the specifications given the editors. British Fiction Today appeared in autumn 2006. In that printed version of the essay, the editors have made certain alterations. The version here, for what it’s worth, is all my own work
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, British Fiction, Martin Amis
summary: This essay, commissioned for "British Fiction Today," describes, contextualizes, and assesses Martin Amis's literary output specifically from 1990 to 2003, with his novel "Yellow Dog" (2003) being the latest work referenced. It focuses on Amis's transition from a promising newcomer in the 1970s and a defining voice in the 1980s, to a leading figure in British fiction by the 1990s. The article provides insight into a significant period of Amis's career, contributing to the broader study of contemporary British literature.

title: Maya Theme s in U. S . Latino/Chicano Literature
fieldOfStudy: English Literature Indigenous Studies Chicano Studies
summary: This paper examines the integration of indigenous themes, specifically Maya themes, in U.S. Latino and Chicano literature. It explores how U.S. Chicano literature, particularly in its early stages (1960s-early 1970s), used Aztec imagery to forge a native-to-this-continent identity, linking to the mythical Aztlán. The study then expands to discuss Maya themes and influences appearing in contemporary U.S. Latino texts, including works by Sandra Benítez, Ana Castillo, and Juan Felipe Herrera. It also references Latin American authors translated into English and films that incorporate Maya narratives, highlighting the persistent cultural identification with indigenous heritage in these literary and cinematic expressions.

title: Adam Bede, realism, the past, and readers in 1859
abstract: This article gives an account of the immediate publication context of George Eliot’s first novel, Adam Bede, in terms of competing opportunities for leisure, anxieties about the reading of fiction, the publishing industry, and the social and political context of February 1859. It examines the way in which the novel engages with its first readers, specifically through its treatment of the experience of reading fiction, and the ways in which Adam Bede differs from readers’ previous experiences. The article argues that the novel’s impact is determined by its engagement with the past of its setting, and by the ways it which it encourages a historically-nuanced appreciation in its readers, and that these factors are integral to Eliot’s articulating a new form of realist fiction
summary: This article explores the immediate publication context of George Eliot's first novel, "Adam Bede," in February 1859, considering factors like competing leisure, anxieties about fiction reading, and the publishing industry. It analyzes how the novel engaged with its initial readers, particularly concerning their experience of reading fiction and how "Adam Bede" diverged from previous literary encounters. The core argument is that the novel's impact stems from its engagement with its historical setting and its promotion of a historically-nuanced appreciation among readers, which were crucial to Eliot's development of a new form of realist fiction. Keywords: George Eliot, Adam Bede, realism, 1859, Victorian literature, literary reception.

title: Jane Austen fan fiction and the situated fantext: the example of Pamela Aidan's Fitzwilliam darcy, gentleman
abstract: Building on recent findings in the field of fan fiction studies, I claim that Pamela Aidan’s Fitzwilliam Darcy, Gentleman is indirectly influenced by three cultural phenomena which centre around Jane Austen and her work. Aidan’s fan fiction text stays close to the spirit of Austen’s Pride and Prejudice because she “reimagines” the novel according to the interpretive conventions of the Republic of Pemberley, a fan community. These conventions demand respect for Austen and her novels because they are shaped by the broader, cultural conventions of Janeitism and Austen criticism. Similarly, Aidan’s text is more individualistic and “Harlequinesque” than Austen’s novel, because the Republic allows writers to reproduce the cultural reading which underlies BBC / A&E’s adaptation of Austen’s novel
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, Fan Fiction Studies, Jane Austen Studies
summary: This study claims that Pamela Aidan's fan fiction novel, "Fitzwilliam Darcy, Gentleman," is influenced by three cultural phenomena centered on Jane Austen and her work. The text maintains fidelity to Austen's "Pride and Prejudice" by adhering to the interpretive conventions of the Republic of Pemberley, a fan community. These conventions, shaped by broader cultural norms of Janeitism and Austen criticism, demand respect for Austen's novels. The analysis also finds Aidan's text more individualistic and "Harlequinesque," as the Republic of Pemberley permits writers to reproduce the cultural reading inherent in the BBC / A&E adaptation of Austen's novel.

title: "It's just one of the wonders of the world": James Donaghue in Under the Net
abstract: Analyis of the central character of Iris Murdoch's Under the Net as picaresque
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, Picaresque Novel, Iris Murdoch
summary: This study analyzes the central character, Jake Donaghue, in Iris Murdoch's novel "Under the Net" (1954) through the lens of picaresque literature. It explores how Donaghue's journey and interactions align with the conventions of the picaresque novel, characterized by a roguish hero's episodic adventures in society. The research examines thematic elements and narrative structures, contributing to a deeper understanding of Murdoch's early work and its literary classifications. Key findings reveal Donaghue's embodiment of picaresque traits, influencing interpretations of morality and inward/outward activity in the novel.

title: Suzanne Flynn, Associate Professor of English
abstract: In this new Next Page column, Suzanne Flynn, Associate Professor of English, confesses which of the “classics” she hasn’t read, shares which Victorian poets and novelists are among her favorites, and explains how her students connect with literature from the 19th century
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: English Language and Literature, Library and Information Science, reading, books, interview
summary: This "Next Page" column features an interview with Suzanne Flynn, Associate Professor of English, where she discusses her unread "classics," favorite Victorian poets and novelists, and how her students engage with 19th-century literature. Flynn also shares her personal reading habits, including contemporary fiction, and a list of books she plans to read, encompassing historical fiction and acclaimed novels. The column provides insights into an English professor's literary world, student engagement with classic texts, and personal reading preferences.

title:
Reading Social Criticism of Tuk Drama in Richard Schechner’s

Ac Diagram Perspective
abstract:
The main problem of this research is social criticism in the drama written in New Order era which was

in repressive, authoritarian, and corruptive social political conditions. This research aims at finding out

the elements of social criticism revealed by Bambang Widoyo SP in Tuk drama and the social historical condition influencing the creation of social criticism of the drama. This research used AC diagram theory which  is  one  of  variances  of  art  anthropology  theory  from  Richard  Schechner.  Social  criticism  in Tuk drama is related to development policy of New Order which prioritized economic growth and collusion between New Order ruler and conglomerates. The social historical condition of New Order regime which was authoritarian, repressive, corruptive (social drama) has influenced the creation of Tuk drama (aesthetic drama).



Keywords: Authoritarian, repressive, and corruptiv
summary: This research investigates social criticism in New Order era drama, specifically focusing on Bambang Widoyo SP's "Tuk." It aims to identify elements of social criticism and the socio-historical conditions influencing its creation. Using Richard Schechner's AC diagram theory (a variant of art anthropology), the study reveals that "Tuk" criticizes the New Order's development policies, prioritizing economic growth, and the collusion between rulers and conglomerates. The authoritarian, repressive, and corruptive socio-historical context of the New Order regime significantly impacted the drama's aesthetic expression. Keywords: social criticism, New Order, authoritarianism, repressive, corruptive, art anthropology.

title: Theatre of the Mind: Hardy the Dynasts and the Question of Form
abstract: This essay analyzes Hardy’s rarely discussed epic-drama, The Dynasts, especially in relation to trends in the early twentieth-century drama. Hardy’s work is a hybrid of epic, drama, and lyric and was, at the time, thought to be unstageable
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: English Language and Literature, Theatre and Performance Studies, The Dynasts, Napoleonic Wars, Thomas Hardy
summary: This essay analyzes Thomas Hardy's epic-drama, "The Dynasts," focusing on its relationship with early twentieth-century drama trends. The work is described as a hybrid of epic, drama, and lyric forms, and was initially considered unstageable. The study explores the formal characteristics of "The Dynasts," highlighting its unique structure and contribution to the theatrical landscape of its time. Key entities include The Dynasts, Napoleonic Wars, and Thomas Hardy, useful for understanding turn-of-the-century theatre and literary form.

title: PEMBELAJARAN SENI TARI DRAMA DI SEKOLAH DASAR
abstract:
In Elementary Education Curriculum of 1994, Artistry Education in Elementary School referred as subject of Handicraft and Artistry. Artistry Education in Elementary School comprises the fine arts, artistic of music, and dance art. That third of item coverage have to be mastered and taught by a teacher of Elementary School. In consequence, a teacher of elementary school at least knowing and comprehending three things of related to study of Artistic drama dance, (2) learning of artistic drama dance as education media in elementary school, and (3) the learning function of artistic drama dance in elementary school.



     The congeniality of artistic drama dance is the beauty, which has been expressed by body rhythmic movements in a room, having storied, player, author and audience elements. There are two basically matter in learning of artistic drama dance in elementary school that is (1) to become the actor candidate and (2) for the maturation of student, constructing growth esthetics, and (3) assisting the life completion.



 



     Keywords : learning, artistic, dance, drama, and elementary school
fieldOfStudy: English, drama, elementary education, art education, dance, music
summary: This article examines the role and significance of Artistry Education, specifically artistic drama dance, within the 1994 Elementary Education Curriculum. It highlights that elementary school teachers must master and teach fine arts, music, and dance. The study focuses on understanding artistic drama dance, its use as an educational medium, and its learning functions in elementary schools. It emphasizes the beauty of rhythmic body movements in dramatic storytelling and outlines two primary goals for learning artistic drama dance: developing actor candidates and fostering student maturation, aesthetic growth, and life completion. Keywords: learning, artistic, dance, drama, elementary school.

title: Moving tales, exploring narrative strategies for scalable locative audio drama.
abstract: This paper reports on a recent collaboration between the Lansdown Centre for Electronic Arts at Middlesex University and the BBC Radio Drama Department, which was designed to investigate the narrative possibilities of locative media in a drama context. The locative drama Scratch is the first outcome of an ongoing research project, Locating Drama, whose aim is to investigate and develop narrative strategies that take full advantage of the current generation of GPS enabled portable computing devices for audio drama. In particular, we are exploring content and modes of interaction, which, while based on location awareness are not in any way site-specific allowing users to experience the drama in a location of their choice. We will refer to this approach as translocational as it allows the translation of locative media experiences to a wide variety of spaces. The translocational approach is of particular interest to broadcasters as it is more scalable than a site-specific paradigm, opening the possibility of downloadable location-aware podcasts featuring professionally authored content for a wide audience
fieldOfStudy: English, Drama, Locative Media, Audio Drama
summary: This paper details a collaboration between Middlesex University and the BBC Radio Drama Department to explore narrative possibilities of locative media in drama. The ongoing "Locating Drama" project investigates and develops narrative strategies for GPS-enabled portable computing devices in audio drama. Specifically, it examines content and interaction modes that are location-aware but not site-specific, termed "translocational," allowing users to experience drama in chosen locations. This approach, exemplified by the locative drama "Scratch," is scalable and offers broadcasters opportunities for downloadable, location-aware podcasts with professional content for a wide audience, thus expanding location-aware media experiences.

title: Acting on behalf of the concept
abstract: This paper discusses how drama process and techniques are providing alternative approaches to product concept generation. An investigation that used drama techniques for concept generation sessions observed that there appears to be an implicit response among designers to investigate functionality before, or instead of form. However, it was proposed that through practice the approach of ‘concept-acting’ would provide support for the designer’s kinaesthetic needs for touch, feel and positional experience. It was also observed that whilst an increasing number of people in the US are actively embracing this type of approach, through a variety of techniques, UK designers appear somewhat more sceptical of the value of drama to their design processes
summary: This paper explores the application of drama processes and techniques as alternative methods for product concept generation. An investigation observed that designers implicitly prioritize functionality over form when using drama techniques. The concept of 'concept-acting' is proposed to support designers' kinaesthetic needs for touch, feel, and positional experience, suggesting that practice can shift focus to aesthetic detailing and product character. While this approach is gaining traction in the US, UK designers appear more skeptical. The study highlights the potential of physical investigation and expression for conceptualizing product design, complementing traditional perspectives of designer, client, and user.

title: The Implementation of Intertextuality Approach to Develop Students' Criti-cal Thinking in Understanding Literature
abstract:
This paper promotes the teaching technique that can be used as a means of developing learners' critical thinking in understanding literature. The promoted technique is conducted through the implementation of intertextuality approach that may require some supported materials; short stories, drama script, and poems as the exemplification materials in the EFL classroom.
Keywords: Intertextuality approach, short stories, drama, literary texts
summary: This paper proposes a teaching technique to enhance critical thinking in literature among EFL students. The method involves implementing an intertextuality approach, utilizing various supported materials such as short stories, drama scripts, and poems as exemplification. It aims to address the common difficulty students face in structuring their ideas and opinions when engaging with literary texts. The technique is expected to foster an active classroom environment, enabling students to develop critical responses and connect author-reader experiences, leading to fresh interpretations.

title: Have you ever considered a career in total revolution?: drama and the corporate reform of higher education.
abstract: This paper examines the corporate reform of UK higher education and its implications for drama. The paper first sets out the background to this reform and its ideological reference points. It then outlines the discourse surrounding the foundation of drama in British Universities and relates this to the discourse developed several decades later by performance studies. In mapping out these areas, the paper draws attention to drama academics’ professed emphasis on rejecting commodification in favour of multiple and/or wide-ranging practices, progressive and democratic principles and a concern with the complexity of human beings. The paper argues that corporate discourse cuts at the joints of drama’s identity as a discipline because what constitute many of the ‘professed’ principles and modes of practice within drama and performance studies are antithetical to the models of commodification promoted by corporate thinking. The paper also engages with the ethical issues raised by corporate reform. As a wide range of critics point out, allowing corporate discourse and practices to dominate higher education is problematic because of the extent to which these practices do violence to the human and promote antidemocratic, antisocial, dehumanising and alienating modes of governance. The paper notes that, while drama’s ‘old’ discourses may seem contradictory, problematic or even to collude with élitism/corporatism, they can nevertheless help us clarify our understanding of the institutional place of drama in contemporary higher education, as remembering the democratic and progressive in drama’s past - as well as acknowledging where it has colluded with the corporate agenda - provides us with a means both to contextualize policy reform and engage critically with its implications
publisher: 'American Association on Intellectual and Developmental Disabilities (AAIDD)'
summary: This paper analyzes the corporate reform of UK higher education and its impact on drama studies. It outlines the historical discourse surrounding drama's foundation in British universities and its evolution into performance studies, emphasizing academics' rejection of commodification in favor of progressive and democratic practices. The paper argues that corporate discourse conflicts with drama's core identity and ethical principles, promoting dehumanizing and anti-democratic modes. It concludes that while drama's historical discourses may appear contradictory, they offer crucial context for critically engaging with contemporary policy reforms and understanding drama's institutional role. Keywords: UK drama, higher education reform, neoliberalism, performance studies.

title: Negotiating the Spaces: Relational Pedagogy and Power in Drama Teaching
abstract: While there is a growing body of literature on relational pedagogy as a concept, less attention is given to the details of just how relational pedagogy manifests in classroom practice. Similarly, while issues of power, democracy and co-constructed learning feature in contemporary research, the details of how power relationships can be effectively altered between teachers and children warrants closer scrutiny. This paper explores how pedagogy is enhanced when spaces are negotiated between teachers and children in the real and fictional worlds of drama. The findings emerge from a two year collaborative research project between generalist elementary teachers and university researchers. Salient issues of trust, power sharing, and metaxis, which are part of relational pedagogy in the drama classroom, are explored. In particular, the paper discusses how traditional power and knowledge positions are 'disrupted' through the drama strategy of 'teacher-in-role' - a strategy with both political significance and pedagogical force
summary: This paper explores how relational pedagogy manifests in classroom practice, particularly focusing on how power relationships can be altered between teachers and children through drama. Findings from a two-year collaborative project between elementary teachers and university researchers reveal that pedagogy is enhanced when spaces are negotiated in real and fictional drama worlds. The study examines trust, power sharing, and metaxis as part of relational pedagogy in drama, highlighting how traditional power dynamics are disrupted using the 'teacher-in-role' strategy, which holds both political and pedagogical significance. Key concepts include relational pedagogy, drama teaching, power relationships, teacher-in-role, and co-constructed learning.

title: Stepping out of the picture: Using drama in storyline topics
abstract: This chapter discusses using drama in storyline topics
summary: This chapter explores the integration of drama into Storyline topics, advocating for its use to enhance cross-curricular learning experiences. The author proposes that drama allows students to embody characters and events from the Storyline frieze, bringing the narrative to life beyond imagination. Key strategies like 'hot seating' are highlighted for enabling deeper interaction with story elements. The article outlines the benefits of linking drama education with Storyline, providing a framework for meaningful and purposeful learning, and includes a lesson plan from a drama workshop. This approach supports active, immersive learning and character development within educational settings.

title: Traffic placement policies for a multi-band network
abstract: Recently protocols were introduced that enable the integration of synchronous traffic (voice or video) and asynchronous traffic (data) and extend the size of local area networks without loss in speed or capacity. One of these is DRAMA, a multiband protocol based on broadband technology. It provides dynamic allocation of bandwidth among clusters of nodes in the total network. A number of traffic placement policies for such networks are proposed and evaluated. Metrics used for performance evaluation include average network access delay, degree of fairness of access among the nodes, and network throughput. The feasibility of the DRAMA protocol is established through simulation studies. DRAMA provides effective integration of synchronous and asychronous traffic due to its ability to separate traffic types. Under the suggested traffic placement policies, the DRAMA protocol is shown to handle diverse loads, mixes of traffic types, and numbers of nodes, as well as modifications to the network structure and momentary traffic overloads
summary: This paper introduces and evaluates DRAMA, a multiband protocol based on broadband technology, designed for integrating synchronous (voice/video) and asynchronous (data) traffic in expanded local area networks without performance loss. The research proposes and assesses various traffic placement policies for such networks, using metrics like average network access delay, fairness, and throughput. Through simulation studies, the feasibility and effectiveness of DRAMA are established, demonstrating its capability to handle diverse loads, traffic mixes, and network structure modifications, ensuring efficient traffic separation and dynamic bandwidth allocation. Keywords include DRAMA protocol, broadband networks, traffic integration, dynamic bandwidth allocation, and local area networks.

title: Review of Philip Arieti\u27s Interpreting Plato
abstract: Paula Saffire\u27s Review of Interpreting Plato: The Dialogues as Drama by James A. Ariet
summary: This is a review of James A. Arieti's "Interpreting Plato: The Dialogues as Drama," which proposes a subversive thesis: Plato's dialogues, including their philosophical remarks, should be interpreted primarily as dramatic works rather than serious philosophical treatises. While the reviewer acknowledges instances where this dramatic premise is effective, such as explaining the arguments' failure in the Phaedo to highlight Socrates' courage, it is ultimately deemed reductionist. The review criticizes Arieti for excessive plot summaries and for dismissing significant philosophical arguments, like those in the Meno or Phaedrus, as mere dramatic devices, arguing that this approach diminishes Plato's philosophical intent.

title: Relationships in drama education : a pedagogical model
abstract: The pedagogical model proposed in this chapter has been developed as a result of the analysis of a wide range of data, gathered over a series of educational drama lessons with pupils aged 10-12 years in three Scottish Primary schools. The data comprised: interviews; observers' commentaries; pupils' evaluations; teachers' reflective journal entries and video recordings of the lessons. Close analysis of the data uncovered an overarching theme: that the nature of the relationships betweenthe participants in drama lessons, and between the participants and the learning contexts, afforded a climate in which learning (in its widest sense) can take place
summary: This chapter proposes a pedagogical model for educational drama, developed from extensive data collected during drama lessons with 10-12-year-old pupils in three Scottish Primary schools. The research utilized interviews, observers' commentaries, pupil evaluations, teacher journals, and video recordings. A key finding was that strong relationships between participants and with learning contexts are crucial for fostering a comprehensive learning environment. This model emphasizes pedagogy, holistic development, partnership, issues-based learning, and process in drama education.

title: Citing your References in the MHRA Style
