abstract: A guide for English Literature, Creative Writing and Drama students on how to use the MHRA referencing styl
summary: This guide outlines the MHRA referencing style, crucial for English Literature and Drama students at Oxford Brookes University. It provides comprehensive guidelines and examples for citing various publication types in footnotes and bibliographies, covering everything from books and journal articles to electronic resources. The guide also explains how to effectively incorporate references and quotes into academic writing, emphasizing practical application. It includes templates for easy adaptation and directs students to the full MHRA Style Guide and library resources for further assistance. This resource is essential for academic integrity in humanities disciplines.

title: Performing Relevance/ Relevant Performances: Shakespeare, Jonson, Hitchcock
abstract: Engages with questions of historicism and presentism in the modern performance of early modern drama, and compares Ben Jonson with Alfred Hitchcock
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, Performance Studies, Film Studies
summary: This paper explores the interplay of historicism and presentism in staging early modern drama, specifically comparing Ben Jonson's works with Alfred Hitchcock's cinematic approach. It critically examines how contemporary performances of historical texts navigate the challenge of making past narratives relevant to a modern audience without distorting their original context. The author uses a striking juxtaposition from 1945 to highlight the "impossibility of commentary" in certain contexts, suggesting that some historical events resist straightforward interpretation or contemporary application. This analysis offers insights into performance theory, literary criticism, and the historical reception of dramatic works.

title: Black Feminism in Contemporary Drama.
fieldOfStudy: English, Theatre Studies, Feminist Theory, Drama
summary: This review article surveys four publications that explore the intersection of theatre and feminism: "Radical Acts: Theatre and Feminist Pedagogies of Change," "Footpaths and Bridges: Voices from the Native American Women Playwrights Archive," "Teatro Chicana: A Collective Memoir and Selected Plays," and "Black Feminism in Contemporary Drama." The publications collectively highlight how theatre serves as a radical medium for social change and feminist inquiry. Notably, Lisa M. Anderson's work on black feminism examines how contemporary drama by black women playwrights constructs and reconstructs history and identity, focusing on elements that invoke community history, politics, or philosophy rather than traditional aesthetics. This work is useful for understanding critical analyses of black feminist theory in dramatic contexts.

title: Lessons from Brecht: a Brechtian approach to drama, texts and education
abstract: In this piece the authors seek to re-read Brecht in terms of his contribution to drama education and pedagogic thought, rather than viewing him in conventional terms as a cultural icon and ‘great practitioner’ of theatre. The authors believe that a Brechtian conceptual framework, with its emphasis on critical production and critical audiences, is still pertinent to the conditions of contemporary cultural production. A Brechtian framework is seen as a way of taking drama education beyond the conventional polarities where on the one hand it is seen as a process of moral and social education dealing with universal truths, or on the other hand, as a set of formal and critical techniques
fieldOfStudy: English, Drama Education, Pedagogic Thought, Bertolt Brecht
summary: This piece re-examines Bertolt Brecht's contributions to drama education and pedagogic thought, moving beyond his conventional portrayal as a cultural icon. The authors propose that a Brechtian conceptual framework, emphasizing critical production and audiences, remains relevant to contemporary cultural production. This approach aims to elevate drama education beyond traditional views, which either categorize it as moral and social education focused on universal truths or as a collection of formal and critical techniques. The study suggests using Brecht's ideas to foster critical engagement in drama.

title: Emerging from Anonymity: The First Generation of Writers of Songs and Drama in Mid-Ming Nanjing
abstract: This article traces the first generation of writers of songs and drama in Nanjing who emerged from the anonymous context of early Ming court entertainment and established their name and reputation in the second half of the fifteenth century. These writers—Shi Zhong (1437-after 1516), Chen Duo (1454?-1507?), and Xu Lin (1462-1538)—represented a different mode of writing songs and drama. For them it was no longer a professional occupation, as in the case of the court performers, but became part of their cultural and social life. The extent to which our knowledge of these first generation qu writers depends on local sources and on acts of remembrance by later Nanjing authors is also examined
summary: This article examines the first generation of Nanjing writers of songs and drama, including Shi Zhong, Chen Duo, and Xu Lin, who rose from early Ming court entertainment anonymity to establish reputations in the latter half of the fifteenth century. It highlights their shift from professional occupation to a cultural and social pursuit. The study also investigates how contemporary knowledge of these 'qu' writers relies on local sources and the commemorative efforts of later Nanjing authors, emphasizing the importance of local historical documentation and acts of remembrance.

title: English Drama in the Late of Victorian Period (1880-1901): Realism in Drama Genre Revival
abstract: A progressive growth in literature was seen significantly during Victorian period. These decades also saw an overdue revival of drama, in which the existence of drama was started to improve when entering late of Victorian period. Along with that situation, Thomas William Robertson (1829-1871) emerged as a popular drama writer at that time besides the coming of Henrik Ibsen's works in 1880's. However, Robertson's popularity was defeated by other dramatists during late of Victorian period (1880-1901), drama writer like Oscar Wilde (1854-1900). Beside Wilde, there were several well known dramatists during late of Victorian period. Dramatists as Shaw, Jones, and Pinero were also influential toward the development of drama at that time. In the discussion of English drama development, role of late Victorian period's dramatists was really important toward the development of modern drama. Their works and efforts really influenced the triumph of realism and development of drama after Victorian period ended. Therefore, the development of drama during late of Victorian period is discussed in this particular writing, due to the important roles of dramatist such as Wilde, Shaw, Pinero, and Jones. Here, their roles to the revival of English drama and the trend of realism in the history of English literature are very important
summary: This writing discusses the significant revival of English drama during the late Victorian period (1880-1901), highlighting its importance for modern drama development. It examines the pivotal roles of popular dramatists like Oscar Wilde, George Bernard Shaw, Henry Arthur Jones, and Arthur Wing Pinero, who collectively influenced the triumph of realism in English literature. The study emphasizes their contributions to vitalizing drama, moving beyond earlier figures like Thomas William Robertson, and acknowledges the inspirational impact of Henrik Ibsen's realism. The period is framed as a "golden age" for English drama, marked by numerous playwrights and theatrical productions.

title: Conservatoire for Dance and Drama
publisher: Quality Assurance Agency for Higher Education
fieldOfStudy: English, Drama, Higher Education, Quality Assurance
summary: This report details the Quality Assurance Agency for Higher Education's (QAA) institutional audit of the Conservatoire for Dance and Drama (CDD) in June 2005. The audit aimed to ensure the provision of acceptable quality and academic standards in higher education and proper exercise of degree-awarding powers. Key findings included confidence in CDD's quality management and accuracy of public information. Post-audit, CDD approved an action plan, strengthened the Academic Board by establishing a Learning and Teaching Committee, and developed affiliate quality assurance forums. The audit highlighted the need to strengthen learning and teaching strategies and staff development.

title: The Sugi Sakit Ritual Storytelling in a Saribas Iban Rite of Healing
abstract: This paper describes a Saribas Iban rite of healing called the Sugi sakit. What distinguished this rite from other forms of Saribas Iban healing was that it incorporated within its performance a long narrative epic concerned with the adventures and love affairs of an Iban culture hero named Bujang Sugi. Here I explore the language used by Iban priest bards both in telling the Sugi epic and in performing the larger ritual drama in which it was set, and look, in particular, at how the Sugi epic, which was otherwise told for entertainment, was integrated into this drama and recast by the priest bards as they performed the ritual, so that it not only entertained their listeners, but also served as a serious instrument of healing
summary: This paper describes the Saribas Iban Sugi sakit healing rite, which uniquely integrates a narrative epic about the culture hero Bujang Sugi within its performance. The study explores the language used by Iban priest bards in both telling the Sugi epic and performing the ritual drama. It particularly examines how this epic, typically for entertainment, is recast and integrated into the ritual to serve as a serious instrument of healing. Key aspects include ritual storytelling, Iban culture, healing practices, and the role of narrative in traditional ceremonies.

title: Learning from participants' responses in educational drama in the teaching of education for sustainable development
abstract: The context for this paper is an on-going research project that sets out to examine the use of educational drama in the teaching of Education for Sustainable Development (ESD) in the upper stages of primary school. The drama lessons link with some of the key aims in ESD, with a particular locus in the Scottish education system. As 200515 has been designated by UNESCO as 'The Decade of Education for Sustainable Development', it is particularly important to examine and emphasise the key role of drama in the learning process. The main focus of the paper is the examination of what pupils' evaluations of the drama work reveal about how drama might be particularly appropriate for use in ESD-related work. The relationships between the participants in the drama, teacher and pupils, both in and out of role are explored. The conclusions suggest that active, participative learning and the unique way of working within the dramatic context might allow children to develop skills and attitudes necessary for active citizenship and might facilitate learning in ESD
summary: This paper examines the use of educational drama in teaching Education for Sustainable Development (ESD) to primary school children, particularly within the Scottish education system, aligning with UNESCO's 'Decade of Education for Sustainable Development'. The research focuses on how pupils' evaluations reveal drama's appropriateness for ESD, exploring relationships between participants (teacher and pupils) both in and out of role. Findings suggest that active, participative learning within dramatic contexts can foster skills and attitudes essential for active citizenship and facilitate ESD learning. Keywords: educational drama, Education for Sustainable Development, primary school, active citizenship, learning process.

title: Fearless: V Rosenberger and Tori Reynolds
abstract: “Getting Out,” the compelling prison drama by Marsha Norman, is opening tonight at 7:30pm on Kline Theater at Gettysburg, and bringing this play to life are two very fearless women. [excerpt
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: English, Theater, Performance Studies, Social Psychology
summary: This blog post announces the opening of Marsha Norman's prison drama "Getting Out" at Gettysburg College's Kline Theater, featuring actresses V. Rosenberger and Tori Reynolds. The play and an accompanying post-show panel discussion aim to illuminate the challenges of re-entry into society for formerly incarcerated individuals, highlighting the mental and physical difficulties. The actresses express a desire to raise awareness about this often-overlooked "separate trauma" and "culture shock." The event seeks to shed light on the realities of the prison system and post-incarceration struggles through performance and community discussion.

title: The Early English passion play
abstract: This discussion challenges the common understanding that biblical drama in England was dominated by ‘mystery plays’, narrowly understood to be cycles of short pageants, by drawing attention to the evidence for large-scale Passion Plays comparable with those better known from France and Burgundy. In so doing, it makes no apology for standing on the shoulders of Peter Meredith's work on the N-Town manuscript, and with John Tailby on the texts and documents illustrating the variety of staging of religious drama across Europe, as well as Meg Twycross's work on devisor Felsted of London, all of which demonstrate that this material has been available in the public domain for some years. Just as the N-Town Plays were still believed in some quarters to come from Coventry as late as the mid-twentieth century, although Francis Douce knew they did not almost 150 years earlier, so too the domination of modern understandings about English mystery plays has remained wedded to the model of four ‘cycles’ promulgated in the 1970s, despite the accumulation of evidence to the contrary. Peter Meredith's edition of The ‘Passion Play’ from the N. Town Manuscript is now all but unobtainable, and the volumes of Records of Early English Drama are the chosen bedtime reading of few, so here we revisit some texts and records to explore afresh one aspect of an already shifted paradigm
fieldOfStudy: English Early English Drama Medieval Theatre
summary: This essay challenges the prevailing understanding that biblical drama in England was solely dominated by 'mystery plays' (short pageant cycles). It highlights evidence for large-scale Passion Plays, comparable to those in France and Burgundy, building on the work of Peter Meredith, John Tailby, and Meg Twycross. The author revisits texts and records, including the N-Town manuscript, to argue that modern scholarship has been too fixated on the 'four cycles' model from the 1970s, despite contrary evidence. This re-examination aims to establish the English Passion Play as a distinct and significant sub-genre within early English theatrical history.

title: Drama for the Church: the Soul Purpose Plays
abstract: Intended as an introductory chapter to a book, this essay outlines the motivation for writing liturgical drama and for creating Soul Purpose. Unfortunately, John Steven Paul (1951-2009), professor of Theatre at Valparaiso University, passed away before he could complete the full manuscript
fieldOfStudy: English, Liturgical Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Stanislavski Method
summary: This introductory essay, intended for a book, outlines the motivation behind creating liturgical drama, specifically the "Soul Purpose" plays. It targets individuals seeking to integrate drama into church services, including ministers, worship committee members, youth leaders, and actors. The author, John Steven Paul, emphasizes the need for resources to initiate, sustain, or develop church drama programs. The text touches upon acting methods like Stanislavski's "magic if" to create believable theatrical environments and foster emotional connections with audiences in a church context. This work provides guidance for amateur performers to engage with liturgical drama effectively.

title: British literature since World War II : a selected bibliography of secondary sources with special reference to drama/theatre and narrative prose (period covered : mid-1940 to 2000)
abstract: British literature since world war II : a selected bibliography of secundary sources with special reference to drama/theatre and narrative prose (period covered : mid-1940 to 2000). Part I: Integrated alphabetical index. Part II: Specific bibliographies (as to author and subject
summary: This bibliography compiles secondary sources related to British literature since World War II, focusing on drama/theatre and narrative prose from the mid-1940s to 2000. It includes an integrated alphabetical index and specific bibliographies organized by author and subject. The document primarily lists scholarly articles, book chapters, and reviews pertaining to British dramatists like James Saunders and Charles Wood, with entries detailing works discussing their plays, themes, and contributions to contemporary British drama. Key subjects covered include dramatic techniques, character analysis, and thematic explorations within their oeuvres.

title: Marsby and the Martian Detectives
abstract: This CD uses song and drama to tell the story of Spirit and Opportunity, NASA's Mars Exploration Rovers, and their mission to search for signs of ancient water. It includes an inquiry-based lesson. Educational levels: Primary elementary, Intermediate elementary
summary: This CD, titled "Marsby and the Martian Detectives," uses song and drama to recount the mission of NASA's Mars Exploration Rovers, Spirit and Opportunity. Its primary purpose is to educate and inspire young students about space exploration and science through the arts, specifically focusing on the rovers' search for ancient water on Mars. The educational resource, suitable for primary and intermediate elementary levels, includes an inquiry-based lesson, an illustrated script storybook, and supplementary materials like game cards and a readalong song, connecting children to space history and scientific inquiry.

title: Book Review: Modernism, Drama, and the Audience for Irish Spectacle
abstract: In a book about drama and Irish spectacle, one would naturally assume that the reactions to Synge\u27s The Playboy of the Western World, Yeats\u27s and Gregory\u27s The Countess Cathleen, and O\u27Casey\u27s The Plough and the Stars would be discussed, and one might be concerned - that this is all well-worn territory. While the reactions to these plays are discussed in Modernism, Drama. and the Audience for Irish Spectacle, by Paige Reynolds, and while the treatments of the plays and the concomitant situations themselves offer little that is really surprising or new, what is surprising and new is the context of these treatments amid other much less familiar incidents of Irish spectacle. By including .chapters on Dublin Suffrage Week, the death and funeral of Terence MacSwiney, and the 1924 Tailteann Games, Reynolds expands our conception of Irish spectacle,in exciting and provocative ways
summary: This book review discusses Paige Reynolds' "Modernism, Drama, and the Audience for Irish Spectacle," which examines audience reactions to prominent Irish plays like Synge's "The Playboy of the Western World" and O'Casey's "The Plough and the Stars." While covering familiar theatrical events, the book's novelty lies in contextualizing these reactions alongside lesser-known Irish spectacles, such as Dublin Suffrage Week, Terence MacSwiney's funeral, and the 1924 Tailteann Games. Reynolds expands the understanding of Irish spectacle, offering a provocative new framework for studying Irish drama and its audience.

title: “She didn’t ask me about my grandma”. Using process drama to explore issues of cultural exclusion and educational leadership.
abstract: Purpose – This purpose of this paper is to describe a collaborative project from the University of Waikato, Hamilton New Zealand, in which the authors used process drama to engage final year teaching students with complex issues of cultural diversity, enabling them to “grow into” different kinds of leadership positions in an imagined educational setting. The paper describes the project and makes a case for process drama as a means of providing opportunities for leadership and as a potent tool for learning about issues of social justice. Design/methodology/approach – The drama was based on a fictional scenario described by Hall and Bishop, where a beginner teacher (of European descent) unwittingly diminishes the experiences of Maori and other non-European children in her class. Using a three-phase process planning model and with facilitators in role alongside the students, the drama explored the scenario from all points of view. Students were encouraged to build empathy for the beginner teacher and for the children and also to explore the dilemma faced by the teacher's tutor in deciding whether, and how, to confront the teacher on the issue. Findings – Through the drama, students built a sense of empathy for all sides of the issue and engaged in deep thinking about the experience of cultural exclusion. The safety and distance provided by the drama “frame” spurred students to take leadership roles and “stand up” for issues of social justice. The authors suggest that through such dramas students gain skills and perspectives that they may carry into their professional lives. Research limitations/implications – The paper describes a small project, over one lesson with a specific group of students. More research is needed into the effectiveness of process drama as a sustained strategy for teacher education. Originality/value – This scenario explored in the drama has currency in Aotearoa New Zealand, where the population is increasingly culturally diverse, where underachievement of Maori students continues to be of concern, and where research has shown the centrality of teacher-student relations in raising educational achievement for Maori. The authors believe this paper makes a compelling case for the value of drama as a tool for student teachers to encounter social justice issues in a meaningful way, and suggest that the paper is a valuable contribution to more than one discipline, as it straddles the fields of professional practice and drama as pedagogy
fieldOfStudy: English, Process Drama, Cultural Diversity, Educational Leadership, Social Justice
summary: This paper describes a collaborative project using process drama to engage final-year teaching students at the University of Waikato with complex issues of cultural diversity and educational leadership. Employing a three-phase planning model and facilitators in role, the drama explored a fictional scenario where a beginner teacher unwittingly diminished Maori and non-European children's experiences. Findings show students developed empathy, engaged in deep thinking about cultural exclusion, and took leadership roles in social justice issues. The authors advocate for process drama as a potent tool for learning and providing opportunities for leadership, suggesting it equips students with valuable professional skills.

title: Book Review: The TV Crime Drama
fieldOfStudy: English, Television Studies, Media Studies, Creative Writing
summary: This book review evaluates Sue Turnbull's "The TV Crime Drama" (2014), positioning it as a timely and valuable addition to academic literature on television studies, specifically within the crime genre. The review highlights the book's purpose as an introduction and overview of the lively and heterogeneous crime genre in television, rather than a deep dive into genealogical methodology or strict chronologies. It emphasizes its utility for media and creative writing students, providing foundational knowledge for understanding and future contributions to the genre. Key areas include television drama, crime genre, media studies, and creative writing.

title: Central School of Speech and Drama
publisher: Quality Assurance Agency for Higher Education
fieldOfStudy: English Higher Education Quality Assurance Drama
summary: This document outlines the purpose and methodology of institutional audits conducted by the Quality Assurance Agency for Higher Education (QAA) in England and Northern Ireland, specifically referencing a review of the Central School of Speech and Drama. The audits aim to ensure acceptable quality and academic standards, proper exercise of degree-awarding powers, and reliable public information. Judgments are made on the institution's management of quality, academic standards, and the integrity of published information, leading to broad, limited, or no confidence ratings. The report highlights areas for future audit focus, including program validation, annual monitoring, widening participation policy, and external professional peer involvement.

title: Increasing awareness of healthy eating through the use of performing arts: An evaluation of the StarBites project
abstract: This project report discusses an evaluation of StarBites - a joint initiative between the arts for health and foods for health strands of Halton's Healthy Living Programme. StarBites aims to convey healthy eating messages through drama, dance, poetry, and music performed by school children.Halton's Healthy Living programm
publisher: Centre for Public Health Research, University of Chester
fieldOfStudy: Public Health, Performing Arts, Health Education
summary: This project report evaluates StarBites, a joint initiative by Halton's Healthy Living Programme, which aims to convey healthy eating messages through performing arts. The evaluation assesses the effectiveness of drama, dance, poetry, and music performed by school children in increasing awareness of healthy eating. Key methods include gathering feedback from participating schools, teaching staff, and parents through interviews and questionnaires. The report details findings on the project's impact on children's and families' eating habits, highlighting changes like increased consumption of fruits and vegetables. This study provides insights into using performing arts for health promotion and community engagement in healthy living.

title: Affect and Metaphor Sensing in Virtual Drama
abstract: We report our developments on metaphor and affect sensing for several metaphorical language phenomena including affects as external entities metaphor, food metaphor, animal metaphor, size metaphor, and anger metaphor. The metaphor and affect sensing component has been embedded in a conversational intelligent agent interacting with human users under loose scenarios. Evaluation for the detection of several metaphorical language phenomena and affect is provided. Our paper contributes to the journal themes on believable virtual characters in real-time narrative environment, narrative in digital games and storytelling and educational gaming with social software
fieldOfStudy: English, Virtual Drama, Affect Sensing, Metaphorical Language
summary: This paper details the development of metaphor and affect sensing capabilities for a conversational intelligent agent. It focuses on detecting various metaphorical language phenomena, including affects as external entities, food, animal, size, and anger metaphors. The developed component is integrated into an agent interacting with human users under loose scenarios, with evaluations provided for both metaphorical language and affect detection. This work contributes to research on believable virtual characters, real-time narrative environments, digital games, storytelling, and educational gaming with social software, enhancing interactive virtual drama experiences.

title: You\u27ve Gotta Read This: Summer Reading at Musselman Library (2007)
abstract: Each year Musselman Library asks Gettysburg College faculty, staff, and administrators to help create a suggested summer reading list to inspire students and the rest of our campus community to take time in the summer to sit back, relax, and read. These summer reading picks are guaranteed to offer much adventure, drama, and fun!https://cupola.gettysburg.edu/summerreads/1006/thumbnail.jp
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
summary: This document compiles the 2007 summer reading list suggested by Musselman Library at Gettysburg College, aiming to inspire students and the campus community to engage with literature during the summer. The recommendations, covering fiction, non-fiction, and film, are curated by faculty, staff, and administrators, promising adventure, drama, and fun. Examples include "You've Gotta Read This" (2007) and various films and books that offer educational and entertaining content, such as "Schoolhouse Rock!" and works by Terry Pratchett. This initiative promotes reading and cultural engagement.

title: Institutional audit : Guildhall School of Music & Drama
publisher: Quality Assurance Agency for Higher Education
fieldOfStudy: English higher education quality assurance, institutional audit, performing arts education
summary: This June 2010 institutional audit report by the Quality Assurance Agency for Higher Education (QAA) focuses on the Guildhall School of Music & Drama. Its purpose is to safeguard public interest in higher education standards and promote continuous improvement in quality management. The audit examines academic standards and learning opportunities, identifying areas for commendation and making recommendations. Key areas for improvement include strengthening engagement with the Academic Infrastructure, enhancing student feedback mechanisms, ensuring consistent English language admission requirements, and implementing systematic staff training for teaching roles. The report is crucial for understanding quality assurance processes in higher education institutions, particularly in performing arts.

title: Brooks Better Not Come Back
abstract: Every time a new season of the Bachelorette starts, I tell myself that I won’t watch this season—that I won’t give in to the trashiness and the petty drama which is the Bachelor. But I can’t help it. Season after season I’m hooked and 17 seasons later… here I am. [excerpt
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: Gender and Sexuality, Politics and Social Change, Race and Ethnicity, Social Psychology and Interaction, Women's Studies
summary: This blog post offers a critical yet self-aware analysis of the enduring popularity of "The Bachelorette," despite its perceived "trashiness" and manufactured drama. The author, Helena E. Yang, examines the show's artificial elements, its low success rate for lasting relationships (only 3.5 couples out of 26 seasons), and ABC's commercially successful formula. Despite acknowledging these criticisms, the author admits to being a loyal viewer, highlighting the show's appeal as a "guilty pleasure." The piece critiques the Hollywood interpretation of romance and interracial relationships within the show's context.

title: Images of the 60s in the 80s: memories of social unrest in US tv series
abstract: In the 1960s American society was shaken to its foundations. This paper examines the representations of this decade two decades later, exploring the conflicting images of the sixties surfacing in various genre of the tv drama of the eighties. It queries how far any of them embody a genuine coming to terms with the times
summary: This paper examines how the turbulent 1960s in American society, marked by social unrest, protests, and questioning of the established order, were represented in television drama two decades later, in the 1980s. It analyzes the conflicting images and the general absence of meaningful engagement with the decade's impact, often presenting a fantasy of an untouched society. The study concludes that eighties TV drama largely failed to genuinely come to terms with the societal shifts of the 1960s, revealing a society still grappling with its past. Keywords: 1960s, American society, television drama, 1980s, social unrest, representation, historical memory.

title: Volume 13, Number 8 – May 1933
abstract: Volume 13, Number 8 – May 1933. 17 pages including covers and advertisements.    Who\u27s Who Herein  Conaty, Edward P.,  Catalogues   May  Murray, Herbert F.,  On Recent Deaths  Nagle, Hillard M.,  First Generations   Essays  McGuire, Peter J.,  Drama in Masques   Editorial  Higgins, Daniel J.,  Merely Players  Haylon, WIlliam D.,  Checkerboard  Skenyon, Francis J.,  Athletic
summary: This 1933 issue of "Alembic" from Providence College features various essays, editorials, and commentary by students and faculty. Key contributors include Hillard Nagle, who explores themes of immigration and nationality, focusing on individuals who came to America through Ellis Island, and Peter J. McGuire, who writes on "Drama in Masques." The editorial by Daniel J. Higgins offers reflections on current world events through a college man's perspective, primarily for a college audience. The publication also includes advertisements and a "Who's Who Herein" section, providing insights into early 20th-century college life and thought.

title: Wrong Priors
abstract:
All priors are not created equal. There are right and there are wrong priors.
That is the main conclusion of this contribution. I use, a cooked-up example
designed to create drama, and a typical textbook example to show the
pervasiveness of wrong priors in standard statistical practice.Comment: 9 pages, 8 figures. MaxEnt2007.org pape
summary: This contribution argues that not all statistical priors are equal, distinguishing between "right" and "wrong" priors. The author uses a specially crafted example and a typical textbook scenario to illustrate the pervasive use of incorrect priors in standard statistical practice. It highlights how information geometry can construct objectively meaningful prior distributions, showing that naive diffuse priors can be significantly less efficient than Jeffreys' rule. The paper discusses Bayesian inference's susceptibility to wrong priors, examining logistic regression with naive versus uniform priors over the manifold, and proposes a family of priors that maximizes ignorance, suggesting a path forward with more geometry. Keywords include Information Geometry, Volume Prior, and Bayesian Inference.

title: Selling the Bird : Richard Walton Tully´s the bird of paradise and the dynamics of theatrical commodification
abstract: The subject of this essay is a largely forgotten long-run play that had considerable impact on US culture in the first half of the twentieth century. Richard Walton Tully´s romantic drama "The Bird of Paradise" is a perfect example of a serious-minded, commercially successful play that has been erased from our disciplinary memory
summary: This essay investigates Richard Walton Tully's romantic drama "The Bird of Paradise," a commercially successful long-run play from the first half of the twentieth century that has been largely forgotten in disciplinary memory. The study aims to highlight the dichotomy between a play's cultural impact and its subsequent canonization, arguing against selective amnesia in theatre history. It examines how "The Bird of Paradise" reflected and intersected with eugenic philosophy and played a crucial role in defining the Pacific imaginary in the US, influencing various cultural systems. The article calls for an expanded understanding of commodification to grasp theatre's historical power.

title: Institutional audit : Conservatoire for Dance and Drama
publisher: Quality Assurance Agency for Higher Education
fieldOfStudy: English higher education quality assurance vocational training performing arts
summary: This document presents the findings of an institutional audit conducted by The Quality Assurance Agency for Higher Education (QAA) for the Conservatoire for Dance and Drama in June 2010. The audit's purpose was to safeguard public interest in higher education standards and encourage continuous improvement in quality management, specifically assessing the Conservatoire's academic standards and quality of learning opportunities. Key strengths identified include the formulation of level descriptors for curriculum development, engagement with professional practice, and effective support for disabled students. The report encourages the Conservatoire's continued leadership in vocational higher education for dance, drama, and circus arts, confirming progress since 2005 and supporting its pursuit of greater autonomy.

title: Province of drama in the elementary grades
abstract: Thesis (Ed.M.)--Boston Universit
summary: This 1926 thesis explores the "Province of Drama in the Elementary Grades," examining its application in both kindergarten and elementary school settings. The study outlines informal drama in kindergarten, emphasizing impromptu plays based on stories, poems, songs, or events, characterized by simplicity and performed in children's own words with goals of fostering freedom, vocabulary, imagination, and social sense. For elementary grades, it details semi-formal (student-written/produced) and formal (pre-written/easily understood) approaches, aiming to cultivate creative expression and social development through dramatic activities. The work also includes an extensive bibliography related to children's plays and educational dramatics.

title: The position of Echegaray in Spanish drama
abstract: Thesis (M.A.)--Boston Universit
summary: This thesis explores the position of Echegaray in Spanish drama, aiming to reconcile conflicting critical estimates. It examines his life, works, and public appeal, beginning with a biographical sketch covering his education, scientific accomplishments, and dramatic career. The study classifies his plays by theme (past vs. contemporary) and manner (prose vs. verse), analyzing the relationship between these elements and his success. It also investigates influences such as extensive readings, early theatre recollections, dramatization of novels, constant theatre attendance, and the impact of Calderon. The work includes a detailed outline and a list of Echegaray's plays with their publication dates and form (prose or verse).

title: NASKAH DRAMA JEBLOG KARYA NAZARUDIN AZHAR (Tilikan Strukturalisme Génétik)
abstract:
Penelitian ini dilatarbelakangi oleh kurangnya pemahaman masyarakat terhadap naskah drama terutama naskah drama sunda. Penelitian ini merupakan penelitian kualitatif dengan menggunakan metode deskriptif. Penelitian terhadap naskah drama masih dianggap langka jika dibandingkan dengan penelitian terhadap genre sastra lain seperti puisi dan novel. Naskah drama Jeblog karya Nazarudin Azhar dipilih sebagai objek penelitian. Pendekatan strukturalisme genetik dipilih untuk mempermudah pemahaman masyarakat terhadap naskah drama dan pandangan dunia pengarang yang terdapat didalamnya dengan tidak meninggalkan latar belakang sosial pengarang sebagai satu hal yang mempengaruhi terciptanya sebuah karya sastra. Di dalam penelitian ini ditemukan tokoh problematik dalam naskah serta latar balakang kehidupan pengarang. Kemudian ditemukan juga  representasi pandangan dunia pengarang yang tercermin dalam naskah drama yaitu sebagai berikut; (1) Pandangan tentang latar belakang kehidupan seseorang, (2) Pandangan tentang eksistensi perempuan, (3) Pandangan tentang pentingnya mengetahui sejarah, dan (4) Pandangan tentang bentuk naskah drama Sunda.

Kata Kunci: Naskah Drama, Strukturalisme Genetik



Kasang tukang ieu panalungtikan nya éta kurangna pamahaman masarakat kana naskah drama, utamana naskah drama Sunda. Panalungtikan ieu mangrupa panalungtikan kualitatif nu ngagunakeun metode deskriptip. Panalungtikan ngeunaan naskah drama masih jarang saupama dibandingkeun jeung panalungtikan ngeunaan genre sastra lainna saperti puisi jeung novel. Naskah drama Jeblog karya Nazarudin Azhar dipilih minangka objék panalungtikan. Dina ieu panalungtikan, kapanggih tokoh problématik dina naskah jeung kasang tukang kahirupan pangarang. Satuluyna kapanggih répréséntasi sawangan dunya pangarang anu aya dina naskah dramana, diantarana; (1) Sawangan ngeunaan kasang tukang kahirupan jalma, (2) Sawangan ngeunaan éksisténsi awéwé, (3) Sawangan ngeunaan pentingna mikanyaho sajarah, jeung (4) Sawangan ngeunaan bentuk naskah drama Sunda.



Kecap Galeuh: Naskah Drama, Strukturalisme Genetik, Pendidikan Bahasa Sunda



This research is based by less peopels knowledge about drama, especiallu insundanesse drama. This research is qualitative which use descriptive method. Research about drama rarely found if we compare with another genre of literature, such as poetry and novel. Jeblog’s drama manuscipt by Nazarudin Azhar is chosen as the object of this research.
