fieldOfStudy: English Language Education, Drama Studies, Educational Psychology
summary: This study investigates the effectiveness of the Think Pair Share method in teaching eighth-grade students at SMP Negeri 2 Cipatat to identify drama elements from scripts and foster a spirit of cooperation. The research aims to compare the ability of experimental and control groups in identifying drama elements and to determine if Think Pair Share is appropriate for cultivating cooperation. Findings indicate that the experimental group, utilizing the Think Pair Share method, achieved significantly higher scores in identifying drama elements (average 81.64 vs. 68.36) and demonstrated a stronger cooperative attitude (average 3.90 vs. 3.09), confirming its effectiveness for both learning outcomes and character development.

title: Analisis Komitmen Dari Tokoh Utama Dalam Drama the Merchant of Venice Karya William Shakespeare
abstract: The Merchant of Venice is a drama written by William Shakespeare. It is a popular comedy drama that was published in 1596. William Shakespeare shows how important a commitment in human life as shown in this drama. In addition, this drama makes us understand about how to show our commitment to someone or ourself. Therefore, commitment becomes the topic of this research.  The problem of this research is how the main characters' commitment is depicted in the drama The Merchant of Venice. The objective of this research is to identify, analyze and describe the main characters' commitment shown in this drama. In analysing this research, the writer used Robert's theory, Mc Crimmon's theory and several concepts about Commitment  The results indicate that there are two kinds of commitment shown by the main characters namely positive commitment and negative commitment. The examples of positive commitment found in this drama are sacrifice, loyalty, consistency, and generousity. Whilst, the negative commitment is shown through the character's plan to murder
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, Drama, Literary Theory, Character Analysis
summary: This research analyzes the depiction of commitment in William Shakespeare's drama, "The Merchant of Venice." The study aims to identify, analyze, and describe the main characters' commitments, utilizing theories from Robert and Mc Crimmon. Findings indicate two types of commitment: positive, exemplified by sacrifice, loyalty, consistency, and generosity; and negative, demonstrated through a character's murder plan. This analysis offers insights into human commitment as portrayed in classical literature and is relevant for literary studies, character analysis, and understanding moral themes within drama.

title: "Indigested in the Scenes: Hamlet's Dramatic Theory and Ours"
abstract:
(Forthcoming in PMLA, January 2018) Discussions of the relationship between drama and performance have been
dominated by two symmetrical, emancipatory impulses. Performance scholars have, for the past
half-century, sought to liberate performance from the authority of the drama. Literary scholars
have, for centuries if not millennia, sought to distinguish a “literary” dimension of the dramatic
text free of the flux of performance. This essay diagnoses in Shakespeare’s Hamlet an alternative
story about the relationship between drama and performance. Paying refreshed attention to the
earlier and less famous of Hamlet’s statements of dramatic theory—his blurb for the “excellent
play” featuring Aeneas’ speech to Dido—I find Hamlet bringing drama, especially in its
“literary” dimension, crashing back into performance. This collision does not reinstitute the
authority of the text; rather, it radically democratizes the scene of dramatic performance by
“indigesting” the behaviors of the participants therein
summary: This essay re-examines the relationship between drama and performance, challenging the traditional view that seeks to liberate performance from the dramatic text or a 'literary' dimension from performance flux. Focusing on Shakespeare's Hamlet, particularly his early dramatic theory as expressed in the Aeneas-Dido speech, the author argues that Hamlet integrates the literary aspect of drama directly into performance. This integration doesn't reassert textual authority but rather democratizes the dramatic performance by 'digesting' the participants' behaviors. This analysis offers an alternative perspective on drama-performance dynamics, relevant for performance studies and literary criticism.

title: Sairaan kaunis Minä : Draaman mahdollisuudet syömishäiriöön sairastuneiden vertaistukiryhmässä
abstract:
Tein opinnäytetyöni aiheesta ”Sairaan kaunis Minä – draaman mahdollisuudet syömishäiriöön sairastu-neiden vertaistukiryhmässä”. Opinnäytetyöni kehittämistehtävänä on havainnoida, miten draama toimii välineenä syömishäiriöön sairastuneiden vertaistukiryhmässä ja miten draama menetelmänä toimii kun-toutumisen tukena. Lisäksi tavoitteena oli, että ryhmään osallistuva henkilö kokisi voimaantumisen tun-netta.

Opinnäytetyöni toiminnallinen osuus oli Draamapaja, joka oli suunnattu syömishäiriöstä kokemuksia omaaville henkilöille. Draamapaja oli luonteeltaan vertaistukiryhmä ja ryhmän toimintaväline oli draama ja toiminnalliset teatterilähtöiset menetelmät. Draamapaja kokoontui tammi- ja helmikuun 2014 aikana kolme kertaa Kotkassa. Ensimmäisellä kerralla ryhmään osallistui kolme henkilöä, kahdella viimeisellä kerralla oli yksi henkilö, kahden lopetettua. Vertaistukiryhmän ohjaajana roolini oli enemmänkin toimia ryhmän innostaja eikä niinkään ryhmän ohjaajana.

Draaman menetelmät kuntoutumisen tukena olivat toimivia ja sopivat syömishäiriöön sairastuneiden vertaistukiryhmässä käytettäväksi. Toiminnalliset teatterilähtöiset menetelmät tukivat yhdessä vertaistuen kanssa yksilöä hyvin ja ekspressiivinen ilmaisu sopii osaksi kuntoutumisen tukea. Draamapajaan osallis-tunut nainen oli tyytyväinen toimintaan ja hän koki, että draaman menetelmien avulla hänen voimaantu-misprosessi oli alkanut.I made my thesis about ”Sickly beautiful Me – the opportunities of drama in the peer support group for people who had suffered from eating disorder”. The development task in my thesis is to observe how drama works as a method in a peer group and how drama works as part of rehab. The functional part in my thesis was a Drama Workshop and it was also a development task to observe whether a person in the Drama Workshop can attain a feeling of empowerment. 

The Drama Workshop was a peer support group and the method that was used was drama. The Drama Workshop had three meetings in January and February in 2014. At the first meeting there were three per-sons and at the last two meetings there was only one person. My role in the group was to be like an inspir-er more than a group leader.  

The methods of drama are useful. With that and the peer support a person can have support in life. Also the expressive methods are a suitable part of the rehab. ”The Drama Workshop has touched me on a very personal level. We have got to the pith of my feelings. I love drama and yeah, drama works.” – Woman in the Drama Work shop
summary: This thesis explored the potential of drama as a therapeutic tool in peer support groups for individuals recovering from eating disorders. A "Drama Workshop" was implemented as a functional component, aiming to observe drama's role in rehabilitation and fostering empowerment among participants. The workshop, conducted over three meetings in early 2014, utilized drama and functional theater-based methods within a peer support framework. Findings indicated that drama methods, combined with peer support, were effective for rehabilitation and expressive self-help, leading to a participant reporting an initiated empowerment process. Keywords: drama therapy, eating disorders, peer support, rehabilitation, empowerment, expressive methods.

title: Analisis Struktural dan Nilai Pendidikan Karakter Naskah Drama Lautan Bernyanyi Karya Putu Wijaya serta Relevansinya sebagai Materi Ajar Resensi Drama di Sekolah Menengah Kejuruan
abstract: Shinta Dewi Nur Rohmah. NIM K1211067. 2015. Analisis Struktural dan Nilai Pendidikan Karakter Naskah Drama Lautan Bernyanyi Karya Putu Wijaya Serta Relevansinya Sebagai Materi Ajar Resensi Drama di Sekolah Menengah Kejuruan. Skripsi: Program Pendidikan Bahasa Indonesia Universitas Sebelas Maret Surakarta. April 2016 Tujuan penelitian ini adalah untuk mendeskripsikan dan menjelaskan: (1) Unsur Intrinsik dalam naskah drama Lautan Bernyanyi karya Putu Wijaya, (2) Keterjalinan antar unsur dalam naskah drama Lautan Bernyanyi karya Putu Wijaya (3) Nilai Pendidikan Karakter yang terdapat dalam naskah drama Lautan Bernyanyi karya Putu Wijaya, dan (4) Relevansi naskah drama naskah drama Lautan Bernyanyi karya Putu Wijaya sebagai materi ajar resensi drama di Sekolah Menengah Kejuruan. Penelitian ini dilaksanakan pada April 2015 sampai dengan April 2016. Metode yang digunakan adalah metode kualitatif deskriptif. Sumber data penelitian ini ada dua, yaitu sumber data primer berupa dokumen naskah drama naskah drama Lautan Bernyanyi karya Putu Wijaya, serta sumber data sekunder berupa informan (guru, siswa, dan dosen dalam bidang drama/teater). Teknik pengumpulan data digunakan studi pustaka, dokumentasi, dan wawancara. Validitas data diuji dengan cara triangulasi teori dan triangulasi data. Teknik analisis data menggunakan model analisis interaktif, yaitu pengumpulan data, reduksi data, penyajian data, dan penarikan kesimpulan. Hasil penelitian ini dapat disimpulkan (1) Naskah drama Lautan Bernyanyi ini memiliki tema keyakinan. Tokoh yang dimunculkan dalam cerita ada 8 tokoh. Alur yang digunakan alur maju/progesif. Berlatar tempat diatas geladak kapal Harimau Laut, ditepi pantai Sanur, Denpasar, Bali. Ragam bahasa menggunakan bahasa baku dan dibubuhi bahasa Bali. Petunjuk teknis ditandai dengan huruf miring. Amanat yang dapat diambil adalah segala sesuatu harus dipikirkan terlebih dahulu sebelum kita mengambil sebuah keputusan. Dengan begitu, semua yang dilakukan akan menjadi jelas tanpa ada kebingungan dan kebimbangan. (2) Keterjalinan antar unsur antara tema dan penokohan mempengaruhi alur. Pemilihan tema dan tokoh-tokoh yang dimunculkan juga didukung oleh setting cerita. Kapal bajak laut yang sedang terdampar di pesisir pantai Sanur, Bali menciptakan sebuah setting diatas geladak kapal. Tokoh-tokoh yang berlatar belakang bajak laut juga didukung dengan pemakaian ragam bahasa. Dialog-dialog yang diucapkan tokoh dapat diperankan dengan lebih ekspresif mengacu pada petunjuk teknis dalam naskah drama. (3) Terdapat 11 nilai pendidikan karakter yang sesuai dalam kurikulum 2013 (4) naskah drama ini cocok untuk digunakan sebagai bahan ajar resensi drama di SMK. Sesuai dengan karakteristik materi ajar yang baik. Hal tersebut didukung oleh pendapat informan, yaitu guru bahasa Indonesia, dosen bidang drama/teater, serta para siswa di beberapa SMK. Kata kunci: unsur intrinsik, nilai pendidikan karakter, materi aja
summary: This research analyzes Putu Wijaya's drama script "Lautan Bernyanyi" to describe its intrinsic elements, the interrelation between these elements, the character education values present, and its relevance as teaching material for drama reviews in Vocational High Schools. Employing a qualitative descriptive method, data was collected from the drama script itself, as well as interviews with teachers, students, and drama lecturers. Key findings reveal the drama's theme of conviction, an eight-character cast, progressive plot, and the integration of eleven character education values according to the 2013 curriculum. The study concludes that the drama is suitable for drama review instruction in Vocational High Schools.

title: Things Never Change: Piecing Together College Life
abstract:
Sometimes you stumble on something on eBay you just can\u27t pass up. It\u27s that $6 buy that is awkward, odd and just a little out of your scope. But it\u27s only $6. If you\u27d buy a burger for $6, you shouldn\u27t pass up an original letter from 1835.
Every letter has a story. And each of those stories has its own drama, its own meaning, its own power. The mundanities of human life can be just as powerful as the battles and charges. [excerpt
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: Cultural History, Social History, United States History
summary: This blog post, "Things Never Change: Piecing Together College Life" by John M. Rudy of Gettysburg College, explores the enduring power of ordinary historical artifacts, using an original 1835 letter purchased on eBay as a central example. It argues that everyday human experiences captured in such documents can be as impactful as accounts of major historical events like battles. The post connects these personal narratives to broader historical contexts, including the Civil War era and early college life, emphasizing the dramatic meaning found in seemingly mundane details. This work is relevant to cultural and social history studies.

title: Implikatur Percakapan dalam Naskah Drama Gong Gusti Ayu Klatir Karya A.A. Wiyat S.Ardhi
abstract: Purnami, Ida Ayu. 2011. implicature in traditional drama script  Gusti Ayu Klatir written by A.A Wiyat S. Ardhi Supervisor I  : Prof. Dr. I Nyoman Sudiana, M.Pd Supervisor II  : Dr. Arifin, M.Pd Key words: implicature, traditional drama script  This research is a descriptive qualitative research aimed at describing (1) function of  implicature in traditional drama script Gusti Ayu Klatir , and (2) its language construction of implicature.  The source of data in this research is traditional drama script Gusti Ayu Klatir. Metode used is documentation study method. This method is used to collect data of function and language construction of implicature in traditional drama script Gusti Ayu Klatir. Data analysis was conducted by reducing data, interpreting data, and drawing conclusion and verification.  The results of study were: (1) the function of  implicature in traditional drama script Gusti Ayu Klatir were assertive, directive, and expressive. (2) the language construction of implicature in traditional drama script Gusti Ayu Klatir used declarative and interrogative. In this case, the implication is related to communicative competence, that is strategic competence. Strategic competence deals with the ability to choose language in order to increase the effectiveness of communication between the speaker and the listener
summary: This descriptive qualitative research investigates implicature in the traditional drama script "Gusti Ayu Klatir" by A.A Wiyat S. Ardhi. The study aimed to describe the function and language construction of implicature within the script. Using a documentation study method for data collection, the research involved data reduction, interpretation, and conclusion drawing. Key findings indicate that implicature functions as assertive, directive, and expressive, employing declarative and interrogative language constructions. The implication of these findings relates to communicative competence, specifically strategic competence, emphasizing the ability to choose language effectively for speaker-listener communication.

title: Additional guidance for the inspection of dance and drama colleges
publisher: Office for Standards in Education, Children’s Services and Skills
fieldOfStudy: English Education, Dance Education, Drama Education, Further Education Inspection, Skills Training
summary: This document provides additional guidance for inspecting dance and drama colleges participating in the Dance and Drama Awards (DaDA) scheme. It contextualizes inspection requirements, highlighting specific considerations and differences for DaDA inspections. The guidance should be used with the September 2012 'Handbook for the inspection of further education and skills'. It details inspection processes, including observing learning, assessments, and progress reviews, and outlines grading criteria for inspection judgements (Outstanding, Good, Requires improvement, Inadequate). The report aims to ensure excellence in education and skills for post-16 learners in these specialized arts fields.

title: Staging the new retail drama: at a metaverse near you!
abstract: Consumers have traditionally looked for products that could fulfill their needs and retailers responded to demand by initially adopting product-oriented, and then more recently, customer-oriented strategies. This shift was heavily underpinned by technology, which enabled retailers to implement more intelligent approaches that evolved around consumers based on their profiles. The next step in this transformation is now towards a “unique” experience creation, with retailers providing a retail theater experience that is different and special and consumers enjoying an increased opportunity to interact and participate in the overall experience. In this paper, we examine how metaverses, i.e. Internet-based virtual worlds, and more specifically Second Life, can potentially provide the stage for this retail theater experience. Our discussion takes place in the context of two cases that are used to highlight the implications of retail theater for both consumers and retailers and illustrate the opportunities and challenges they face
fieldOfStudy: Marketing, E-commerce, Virtual Worlds, Retail, Consumer Behavior
summary: This paper investigates how metaverses, specifically Second Life, can serve as a platform for a "retail theater" experience, marking the next evolution in consumer-oriented retail strategies. Moving beyond traditional product and customer-centric approaches, the study examines two case studies to highlight the implications, opportunities, and challenges of this immersive retail environment for both consumers and retailers. It aims to illustrate how virtual worlds can facilitate unique, interactive shopping experiences where consumers actively participate, fostering a deeper engagement beyond transactional exchanges. The research contributes to understanding the technological underpinning of evolving retail landscapes.

title: Cultural Stages Initiative Promotes World Cultures Through Drama and Dance
publisher: University of New Hampshire Scholars\u27 Repository
summary: The University of New Hampshire announces the "Cultural Stages: The Woodward International Drama and Dance Initiative" as part of the Paul Creative Arts Center's 50th anniversary. This project, funded by Ellis Woodward, aims to foster understanding of world cultures through drama and dance. It includes an international playwright in residence program and the Woodward International Playwriting Prize, which will feature plays addressing relevant themes and culminating in full productions at UNH. This initiative is considered unique in promoting international cultural understanding and is expected to attract attention in theatre and higher education circles.

title: Humanizing The Heart,  Or Romantic Drama And The Civilizing Process
summary: This article, "Humanizing The Heart," examines Romantic drama's relationship with the civilizing process, drawing on Charles Nodier's observation that Romantic drama is essentially melodrama. It explores the characteristics of early nineteenth-century melodramas, such as violent actions and reliance on plot, and discusses how these elements influenced Romantic works. title: Economic Man and Literary Woman: One Contrast
abstract:
The law and literature movement has been with us long enough that it is now possible to speak seriously of a  literary analysis of law,  just as it has become possible, and even standard, to speak of an  economic analysis of law.  It is also standard, of course, to speak of that abstract character who has emerged from the economic analysis of law:  economic man.  In these brief comments, I want to offer one contrast of the  economic man  that emerges from economic legal analysis with the  literary person  that is beginning to emerge from literary legal analysis. I will sometimes call the latter person, in the interest of rough justice and somewhat in the interest of accuracy,  literary woman.  The  literary woman  posited by literary legal theorists is coming into her own, and she is at least beginning to operate as a check on the excesses of economic man run wild.
I should add by way of caveat that these comments are intended to be programmatic and tentative. I am not suggesting, and do not believe, that the comparative vision of literary woman that contrasts with economic man and which I will describe in this essay is the only, or even the most, representative vision of humanity and human nature that has emerged from the law and literature movement. I do think, though, that it is a vision we ought to pursue. The idealized literary person, sometimes explicit, but most often implicit in much of our literary legal analysis, stands in sharp contrast to her closest interdisciplinary cousin, economic man. For that reason alone, the vision of human nature she represents has tremendous moral promise. We ought to begin to make good on it
fieldOfStudy: English, Law and Economics, Law and Gender, Law and Society
summary: This paper contrasts the "economic man" from economic legal analysis with the emerging "literary person" (often termed "literary woman") from literary legal analysis. It argues that while economic man represents an abstract character in legal discourse, literary woman offers a moral counterpoint, promoting empathy and understanding. The author suggests that this idealized literary person, implicit in much literary legal analysis, offers a vision of human nature with significant moral promise, emphasizing the importance of literature in fostering moral growth and compassion in legal education. Keywords: law and literature, economic analysis of law, literary analysis of law, economic man, literary woman, moral growth, legal education, empathy.

title: The Modality of the Textual Institutionalisation of Literary Studies: Towards a Sociology of Literature
abstract: This paper aims to present a sociology of literary studies that is distinguished from the sociology of literature in that its focus is on literary studies as a social practice rather than as a socio-cultural institution: how literary studies is institutionalized as such not how it functions in relation to literature. The sociological analysis of literary studies in this paper entails two tasks. Firstly, it constructs a methodological frame within which literary studies can be observed and analysed in terms of the rules of discursive formation rather than as a pre-discursive entity. This is achieved through conceptualizing the Foucauldian notion of discursive formation and knowledge practice as an analytic strategy and operationalising it via Paul Dowling's Social Activity Method. Empirically, the analysis produces a description of the practice of literary studies as instantiated in the particular region of the practice constituted with what I refer to as the crisis discourse. The analysis describes literary studies as that which is emergent upon differing institutionalising strategies articulated by its participants to mark out literary studies from other practices and to maintain its disciplinarity through regulating the distribution and the access of the distribution of the discourse within and beyond the practice. The generalisability of the research in this paper lies in the applicability of the analytical method that can be employed at any given level of analysis to examine discursive practiceâ€”such as literary studiesâ€”as the effects of the particular discourses in terms of how they articulate and sustain the institutionalised identity of the practice.Sociology of Literature, Sociology of Literary Studies, Cultural Studies, Sociology of Knowledge, Foucault, Discursive Formation, Social Activity Method, Disciplinarity, Institutionalisation, Research Methodology
fieldOfStudy: English, Sociology of Literature, Sociology of Literary Studies, Cultural Studies, Sociology of Knowledge, Foucault, Discursive Formation, Social Activity Method, Disciplinarity, Institutionalisation, Research Methodology
summary: This paper presents a sociology of literary studies, distinct from the sociology of literature, by focusing on literary studies as a social practice and its institutionalization. It employs a methodological framework that observes literary studies through the lens of discursive formation rules, utilizing Foucauldian concepts and Paul Dowling's Social Activity Method. The analysis empirically describes literary studies as emerging from institutionalizing strategies articulated by participants, particularly in relation to a 'crisis discourse.' The research emphasizes the method's generalizability for examining how discourses articulate and sustain the institutionalized identity of practices like literary studies, offering insights into disciplinarity and knowledge practices.

title: He Was The Best of Kings; He Was the Worst of Kings: A Critique of the Literary Presentation of Richard I
abstract: In order to achieve a more holistic understanding of Mediterranean History during the Third Crusade, a critical analysis of Richard I is necessary. This paper questions how accurately Richard I was portrayed in literary sources during the Third Crusade and attempts to construct as complete an image of the various motivations that led to differing depictions of Richard I as possible through a critical analysis of literary sources. Focusing on how his actions during the Third Crusade were interpreted, this paper will show the various, often opposing, sentiments held by both Western and Muslim authors on Richard I. Once a comprehensive presentation of the literary representations of Richard I has been established, this paper will question motives behind authors’ characterizations of King Richard in order to create a greater understanding of the politics and cultural biases that were driving forces behind the actions of the Third Crusade and modern interpretation
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: European History, English Literature, Medieval History
summary: This paper critically analyzes the literary portrayal of Richard I during the Third Crusade to achieve a more holistic understanding of Mediterranean History. It investigates the accuracy of Richard I's depiction in contemporary sources and aims to construct a comprehensive image of the various motivations behind these differing representations. By focusing on how his actions were interpreted by both Western and Muslim authors, the study reveals often opposing sentiments. The research establishes a comprehensive presentation of literary representations of Richard I, then questions the motives for authors' characterizations to understand the political and cultural biases driving the Third Crusade and its modern interpretations. Key entities include Richard I, Third Crusade, Mediterranean History, literary sources, Western authors, Muslim authors.

title: A rhetorical analysis of the two cultures in literary fiction
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, Rhetorical Analysis, Cultural Studies
summary: This chapter rhetorically analyzes the "two cultures" debate, specifically the divide between science and literature. It describes these fields as distinct "terministic screens," problematizing their binary opposition and emphasizing the importance of rhetoric, narrative, and the humanities. The study examines Ian McEwan's novels, "Saturday" and "The Children Act," as case studies to explore how a novelist confronts and thematizes the interplay between art and science. Key themes include C. P. Snow's concept of the two cultures and the role of literary culture in mediating this intellectual gap.

title: The Macabre on the Margins: A Study of the Fantastic Terrors of the Fin de Siècle
abstract: It demonstrates that in spite of the dominant associations of fantastic literature with horror, terror, as the marginal and marginalized fear of the unknown, with its uncanny, sublime and suspenseful qualities, holds a definitive presence in fin de siècle fantastic texts. Literary analysis of the chosen texts registers significant examples of the importance of terror to fantastic writing, and as such functions to extract an “aesthetics of sublime terror” from the margins of critical studies of this often macabre literary mode
fieldOfStudy:
English Literature, Literary Criticism, Fin de Si
u00e8cle, Fantastic Literature, Sublime Terror
summary:
This paper examines fin de si
u00e8cle fantastic literature, arguing that terror, as a marginal and marginalized fear of the unknown with uncanny, sublime, and suspenseful qualities, holds a definitive presence despite the dominant association with horror. Through literary analysis of texts like Maupassant
									's "Le Horla" and Haggard's *She*, the study extracts an "aesthetics of sublime terror," positioning it as crucial to fantastic writing. This work challenges existing critical discourse by highlighting the interconnected marginality of terror, the literary Fantastic, and the fin de si
u00e8cle period, enriching the understanding of macabre literary modes.

title: Citing the Elite: The Burden of Authorial Anxiety
abstract: Academic legal writing is known for extensive citation. Generally, scholars who study citation practices are increasingly likely to link citation with authors\u27 attempts to manage their impression. This Note offers an explanation of why authors of law review articles use citation as a means of managing impression. It combines a historical analysis that shows why excessive citation became conventional with a literary analysis that shows why excessive citation was unique in its ability to aid academics in substantively contributing to the bench and bar. It further shows how, because of the historic and literary significance of citation, a norm compelling excessive citation pervades the legal community. Finally, this Note questions this norm\u27s continued value given that excessive citation exacts a collateral price on the legal community and that law review readers are increasingly diverse
summary: This Note examines why authors of law review articles use extensive citation for impression management. It combines historical analysis, showing how excessive citation became conventional, with literary analysis, demonstrating its unique role in enabling academics to contribute to the legal community. The study reveals how this historical and literary significance created a pervasive norm for excessive citation within law. However, it questions the continued value of this norm, considering the collateral costs it imposes and the increasing diversity of law review readers. Key concepts include citation practices, impression management, legal writing, and scholarly norms.

title: A 'novel' approach to leadership development : using women's literary fiction to explore contemporary women's leadership issues : a thesis presented in partial fulfilment of the requirements for the degree of Masters of Business Studies in Management at Massey University, Albany, New Zealand
abstract:
The central aim of this thesis is to investigate how women’s literary fiction can be harnessed for the purpose of exploring contemporary women’s leadership issues. This thesis argues that literary fiction is a valuable source of interdisciplinary and ‘artful’ consciousness-raising material for proactively addressing at the interpersonal level a wide range of critical concerns related to women’s leadership experiences. Having identified a significant ‘gap’ in the extant literature – the underutilisation of women’s novels, short-stories and plays in leadership studies – this thesis adopts an interdisciplinary approach to demonstrate how literary works can be used to examine women’s contemporary leadership issues.
For this research project I adopted an interpretive qualitative research paradigm informed by critical leadership studies and a multiplicity of feminist perspectives. I developed a systematic method for long listing and short listing appropriate texts and analysed selected works in response to a five-point conceptual framework of critical concerns arising from a review of the women and leadership literature. I also kept a reflective blog to track the iterative nature of the research process and to record my learning during this study.
The findings demonstrate that women’s literary fiction offers a rich repository of thought-provoking illustrations of women’s leadership concerns, including gender binaries, power-play, socially constructed perceptions and gendered expectations, and women’s diverse range experiences as both leaders and followers. The extended analysis provides a number of in-depth examples and reflective questions, revealing myriad opportunities for critical theorising, illustrative analysis and critical reflection. Subsequently, this thesis argues that fictional stories are a viable and potentially transformative ‘artful’ intervention for addressing complex leadership issues concerned with gender within the context of women’s leadership development programmes. My recommendations for future studies include a focus on ethical leadership, the evaluation of participant ‘book club’ interventions and an extension of the reading lists to include more culturally relevant New Zealand authors.
To my knowledge, there are no studies that utilise women’s literary fiction for the purpose of exploring contemporary women’s leadership concerns and questions. Consequently, my thesis makes an original contribution to the leadership and humanities field, as well as providing an innovative and creative product that can be used for critical and interdisciplinary approaches to women’s leadership development
summary: This thesis investigates how women's literary fiction can address contemporary women's leadership issues, arguing it's a valuable source for consciousness-raising and interdisciplinary study. Adopting an interpretive qualitative research paradigm, the study developed a systematic method to analyze selected literary works against a five-point conceptual framework derived from leadership literature. Findings demonstrate that women's fiction offers rich illustrations of leadership concerns like gender binaries, power-play, and gendered expectations, providing opportunities for critical theorizing. The research suggests fictional stories are a transformative intervention for gender-related leadership development programs, contributing an original approach to leadership and humanities fields.

title: Computing the Affective-Aesthetic Potential of Literary Texts
abstract: In this paper, we compute the affective-aesthetic potential (AAP) of literary texts by using a simple sentiment analysis tool called SentiArt. In contrast to other established tools, SentiArt is based on publicly available vector space models (VSMs) and requires no emotional dictionary, thus making it applicable in any language for which VSMs have been made available (>150 so far) and avoiding issues of low coverage. In a first study, the AAP values of all words of a widely used lexical databank for German were computed and the VSM’s ability in representing concrete and more abstract semantic concepts was demonstrated. In a second study, SentiArt was used to predict ~2800 human word valence ratings and shown to have a high predictive accuracy (R2 > 0.5, p < 0.0001). A third study tested the validity of SentiArt in predicting emotional states over (narrative) time using human liking ratings from reading a story. Again, the predictive accuracy was highly significant: R2adj = 0.46, p < 0.0001, establishing the SentiArt tool as a promising candidate for lexical sentiment analyses at both the micro- and macrolevels, i.e., short and long literary materials. Possibilities and limitations of lexical VSM-based sentiment analyses of diverse complex literary texts are discussed in the light of these results
summary: This paper introduces SentiArt, a simple sentiment analysis tool designed to compute the affective-aesthetic potential (AAP) of literary texts. Unlike established tools, SentiArt utilizes publicly available vector space models (VSMs) and operates without an emotional dictionary, making it language-independent and applicable across over 150 languages. Three studies validated SentiArt: computing AAP for a German lexical databank, predicting human word valence ratings with high accuracy (R2 > 0.5), and predicting emotional states over narrative time (R2adj = 0.46). These findings establish SentiArt as a promising tool for lexical sentiment analysis in literary materials at both micro and macro levels. Keywords: SentiArt, sentiment analysis, affective-aesthetic potential, literary texts, vector space models, lexical sentiment.

title: Fusing Both Arts to an Inseparable Unity: Frank O\u27Hara as a Visual Artist
abstract: Frank O’Hara, a curator at the Museum of Modern Art in New York and a published poet in the 1950s and 60s, was an exemplary yet enigmatic figure in both the literary and art worlds. While he published poetry, wrote art criticism, and curated exhibitions—on Franz Kline, Robert Motherwell, and Jackson Pollock—he also collaborated on numerous projects with visual artists, including Larry Rivers, Michael Goldberg, Grace Hartigan, Joe Brainard, Jane Freilicher, and Norman Bluhm. Scholars who study O’Hara fail to recognize his work with the aforementioned visual artists, only considering him a “Painterly Poet” or a “Poet Among Painters,” but never a poet and a visual artist. Through W.J.T. Mitchell’s “imagetext” model, I apply a hybridized literary and visual analysis to understand O’Hara’s artistic work in a new way. I highlight O’Hara’s previously under-acknowledge artistic collaborations that secure his place as both a poet and an artist
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
summary:
This study re-examines Frank O

O'Hara's role in the literary and art worlds, challenging the conventional view that he was solely a "Painterly Poet" or "Poet Among Painters." Utilizing W.J.T. Mitchell

O'Hara's "imagetext" model, the research applies a hybrid literary and visual analysis to highlight O'Hara's under-acknowledged artistic collaborations with visual artists like Larry Rivers, Michael Goldberg, and Grace Hartigan. The analysis aims to establish O'Hara's legitimate place as both a poet and a visual artist, offering a new perspective on his artistic work and influence within the New York School.

title: The Persistence Of Romanticism: Essays In Philosophy And Literature
abstract: Has Romanticism been superseded by realism, modernism, and postmodernism, all of which are often taken to acknowledge reality more fully than Romanticism? What is it that Romantic thinkers and writers do? Why does what they do matter? Is Romanticism a think of the past?  These challenging essays defend Romanticism against its critics. They argue that Romantic thought, interpreted as the ongoing pursuit of freedom in concrete contexts, crossed by frustration and marked by desire, remains a central and exemplary form of both artistic work and philosophical understanding. Marshaling a wide range of texts from literature, philosophy, and criticism, Richard Eldridge traces the central themes and stylistic features of Romantic thinking in the work of Kant, Holderlin, Wordsworth, Hardy, Wittgenstein, Cavell, and Updike. Through his analysis he shows that Romanticism is neither emptily literary and escapist nor dogmatically optimistic and sentimental.   This philosophical defense of the ideals and practice of Romanticism will appeal particularly to all professionals and students in philosophy, literature, and aesthetics who are interested in expressivist thinking about value and freedom, as it is developed in both literary and philosophical texts
summary: This collection of essays defends Romanticism against its detractors, arguing that it remains a central and exemplary form of artistic and philosophical understanding. Richard Eldridge traces themes and stylistic features of Romantic thinking in the works of Kant, Holderlin, Wordsworth, Hardy, Wittgenstein, Cavell, and Updike, demonstrating that Romanticism is neither escapist nor dogmatically optimistic. The analysis aims to show Romantic thought as the ongoing pursuit of freedom in concrete contexts, marked by frustration and desire. This philosophical defense will appeal to professionals and students in philosophy, literature, and aesthetics interested in expressivist thinking about value and freedom.

title: The Singer of Tibet:  Shabkar (1781-1851), the “Inescapable Nation,” and Buddhist Universalism
abstract: This paper examines the concept of ‘Tibet (Tib. bod)’ in the spiritual autobiography of the celebrated Tibetan Buddhist author, Shabkar Tsokdruk Rangdröl (1781–1851). I use both literal and literary modes of analysis in conjunction with Steven Grosby’s and Lama Jabb’s definitions of ‘nation’ to demonstrate how Shabkar initially builds a vivid persona— the ‘Singer of Tibet’—that is rooted in the Tibetan landscape, but then shifts to a different persona— ‘Shabkar’—that transcends Tibet altogether and embraces a sense of Buddhist universalism. Throughout the process, Shabkar evokes deities and historical figures that are fundamental to Tibetan historical, cultural, and religious memory and alludes to customs and tropes central to Tibetan culture, such as orality, song, and the bardic tradition. In addition to demonstrating the efficacy and potency of literary tropes in creating the sense of an imagined nation, this essay makes a contribution to the ‘Where is Tibet?’ debate by exploring how Tibetan identity is articulated in one of the great masterpieces of classical Tibetan Buddhist literature
fieldOfStudy: Literary Analysis, Tibetan Studies, Buddhist Literature
summary:
This paper analyzes the concept of 'Tibet' in the spiritual autobiography of Shabkar Tsokdruk Rangdröl (1781

-1851), a celebrated Tibetan Buddhist author. Employing literal and literary analysis alongside definitions of 'nation' from Steven Grosby and Lama Jabb, the study shows how Shabkar first adopts a 'Singer of Tibet' persona rooted in the Tibetan landscape before transitioning to a 'Shabkar' persona that embodies Buddhist universalism. The paper highlights Shabkar's use of deities, historical figures, and Tibetan cultural tropes like orality and song, contributing to the 'Where is Tibet?' debate by exploring Tibetan identity in classical Tibetan Buddhist literature and demonstrating the power of literary tropes in constructing an imagined nation.

title: The Chronotope and the Study of Literary Adaptation : The Case of Robinson Crusoe
abstract: This paper proposes a reflection on the potential of the chronotope as a heuristic tool in the field of adaptation studies. My goal is to situate the chronotope in the context of adaptation studies, specifically with regard to perhaps the most central treatise in the field of literary adaptation, Gérard Genette’s “Palimpsests: Literature in the Second Degree”, and to draw attention to perhaps one of the most overlooked works in the field of adaptation studies, Caryl Emerson’s chronotope-inspired “Boris Godunov: Transpositions of a Russian Theme”. I will demonstrate how the chronotope might be used in the study of literary adaptation by examining the relationships between Daniel Defoe’s “Robinson Crusoe”, its historical sources, and Michel Tournier’s twentieth-century adaptation of the Robinson story, “Friday”. My analysis draws upon three of the semantic levels of the chronotope presented in the introduction to this volume: (1) chronotopic motifs linked to two opposing themes: enthusiasm for European colonial expansionism and skepticism regarding the supremacy of European culture; (2) major chronotopes that determine the narrative structure of a text; and (3) the way in which such major chronotopes may be linked to broader questions of genre
summary: This paper explores the potential of the chronotope as a heuristic tool within adaptation studies. It aims to situate the chronotope in the context of Gérard Genette’s “Palimpsests” and Caryl Emerson’s “Boris Godunov.” The study demonstrates the chronotope's utility in literary adaptation by analyzing relationships between Daniel Defoe’s “Robinson Crusoe,” its historical sources, and Michel Tournier’s adaptation, “Friday.” The analysis draws on three semantic levels of the chronotope: chronotopic motifs (colonial expansionism vs. skepticism), major chronotopes determining narrative structure, and their link to broader genre questions. This research is valuable for understanding literary theory and adaptation.

title: Computational Literary Genre Stylistics
abstract:
The project in a nutshell: This project will investigate the relation between literary genres (generic facets) and style (stylistic attributes). Analyses are based on large collections of literary texts and use or develop state-of-the-art methods in computational stylistics and text analysis. This will enable the project to combine attention to minute stylistic details with the investigation of large trends and patterns in literary history.

What does the project aim to accomplish? The project brings together scholars from Romance Philology and Computer Scientists, building a common ground in Computational Philology. It aims to change the way we think about the concepts of genre and style as well as about the relation between literary interpretation and computation. In particular, the project aims to strengthen the engagement with digital methods in Romance Philology
fieldOfStudy: English, Computational Philology, Literary Computing, Romance Philology
summary: This project investigates the relationship between literary genres and stylistic attributes, utilizing large collections of literary texts and advanced computational stylistics methods. It aims to combine detailed stylistic analysis with the study of broad trends in literary history. Bringing together Romance Philology and Computer Science, the project seeks to redefine concepts of genre and style, and to strengthen the integration of digital methods in literary interpretation, specifically within Romance Philology. Key methods include linguistic preprocessing with machine learning, cluster analysis, principal component analysis, topic modeling, and visualization techniques.

title: “Past Master”: Czeslaw Milosz and his Impact on Seamus Heaney's Poetry
abstract: The essay examines the influence of Czeslaw Milosz on Seamus Heaney's writing, focusing primarily on the early 1980s, which was a period of major transition in Heaney's literary and academic career, following the success of Field Work (1979) in the USA and his appointment as a Visiting Lecturer at Harvard. It establishes the political and biographical contexts for Heaney's reception of Milosz's prose and poetry, and discusses the importance of Milosz's Nobel Lecture and his memoir, Native Realm, in fostering Heaney's feelings of affinity and sense of difference. Composed in the wake of Solidarity's challenge to the post-war status quo, Milosz's reflections in the Nobel Lecture on history, art, and the artist's responsibilities had a profound resonance for his fellow exile, uncertain as he was how to address the Hunger Strikes in the collection he was working on, Station Island. The essay thus explores the range of factors which resulted in Milosz becoming The Master to Heaney, and ends offering an analysis of his poem of that title. It draws on a range of literary and historical sources, including the Heaney archives at Emory, Atlanta. Since it is the centenary of Milosz's birth, it offers a timely reminder of his importance in world literature. (Since it may not be familiar to many readers, I have included an outline of Milosz's biography at the start of the essay.) © 2013 Taylor and Francis Group, LLC
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, Poetry, Literary Criticism, Polish and Irish Poetry
summary: This essay explores the profound influence of Czeslaw Milosz on Seamus Heaney's writing, particularly during the early 1980s. It establishes the political and biographical contexts of Heaney's engagement with Milosz's work, emphasizing the impact of Milosz's Nobel Lecture and memoir, "Native Realm," on Heaney's sense of affinity and difference. The study examines how Milosz's reflections on history, art, and an artist's responsibilities resonated with Heaney, especially concerning the Hunger Strikes, and ultimately led Milosz to be considered "The Master" by Heaney. The essay concludes with an analysis of Heaney's poem of that title, drawing on Heaney archives at Emory.

title: '“A strange enough region wherein to wander and muse": Mapping Clerkenwell in Victorian Popular Fictions'
abstract: Drawing on the work of Bertrand Westphal, this essay attempts to perform a geocritical reading of the London district of Clerkenwell. After discussing the spatial turn in the Humanities and introducing a range of spatial critical approaches, the essay “maps” literary Clerkenwell from the perspectives  of genre  hybridity and intertextuality, spatially articulate cartography, multifocal and historically aware public  perception  and potentially  transgressive connection  to  outside  areas.  Clerkenwell  is  seen  to have  stimulated  a  range  of  genre  fiction,  including  Newgate,  realist,  penny  and  slum  fiction,  and social  exploration  journalism.  In  much  of  this  writing,  the  district was  defined  by  its negative associations  with  crime,  poverty,  incarceration  and  slaughter. Such  negative  imageability,  the  essay suggests,  was self-perpetuating, since authors  would be  influenced by their reading to create literary worlds repeating existing tropes; these literary representations, in turn, influenced readers’ perceptions of the area.Intertextual, multi-layered and polysensorial geocritical readings,the essay concludes, can producepowerful  andnuanced  pictures  of  literary  placesbut also  face  a formidable challenge in defining an adequate geocentric corpus
summary: This essay conducts a geocritical reading of Clerkenwell, London, drawing on Bertrand Westphal's work. It discusses the spatial turn in Humanities and various spatial critical approaches, mapping literary Clerkenwell through genre hybridity, intertextuality, cartography, public perception, and transgression. Clerkenwell is shown to have inspired diverse genre fiction, often defining the district by its negative associations with crime, poverty, and incarceration. The essay suggests this negative image was self-perpetuating, influencing authors and readers' perceptions. It concludes that intertextual, multi-layered geocritical readings offer nuanced pictures of literary places but face challenges in defining an adequate geocentric corpus. Keywords: geocriticism, Clerkenwell, Victorian fiction, spatial turn, literary geography.

title: E-methods in literary production: integrating e-learning in creative writing
abstract: This paper discusses the integration of e-learning in creative writing. The online approach to the teaching of creative writing takes into account today’s Malaysian youth and their fascination with computer technology. It is this appeal of innovation in electronics and knowledge that leads an educator to design an on-line approach to a creative writing course. The theoretical construct used to support the discussion is Anderson’s theory that on-line learning is knowledge-, community-, assessment-, and learner-centered. The writer, who is also the course developer, analyses a poetry-writing activity, which students undertake, and the e-portfolio used in the course. To analyze the processes involved in this creative writing exercise Macherey’s (1978) Theory of Literary Production is adapted and utilized. This theory, which regards literary production as a process imitating that of a production line, provides the methodology and conceptual framework for analyzing the raw materials collected by the students and their transformation during the writing process. This paper thus addresses the benefits of e-learning in a creative writing context
publisher: Pusat Pengajian Bahasa dan Linguistik, FSSK, UKM
summary: This paper explores the integration of e-learning into creative writing, specifically targeting Malaysian youth's interest in computer technology. The authors leverage Anderson's theory of knowledge-, community-, assessment-, and learner-centered online learning. The study analyzes a poetry-writing activity and e-portfolio usage, adapting Macherey's (1978) Theory of Literary Production to examine the transformation of raw materials during the writing process. The paper highlights the benefits of e-learning in a creative writing context, focusing on concepts like e-learning, creative writing, and literary production.

title: CD Manuscript B and the Community Rule – Reflections on a Literary Relationship
abstract: This article begins by noting the proliferation of textual overlap between the Damascus Document and the Rule of the Community. Some examples of such overlap, such as the penal code, have received a large amount of scholarly attention in the wake of the publication of all the Cave 4 manuscripts. This study returns to a passage from CD manuscript B (CD 20:1b-8a) that has long been recognized as closely related to 1QS 8-9 and offers a reconsideration of the relationship between both texts in the light of the full publication of all the S manuscripts. The analysis offered here uncovers a complex inter-relationship between both texts as well as some intriguing pointers towards a complex literary history within the S tradition
fieldOfStudy: Literary Criticism, Dead Sea Scrolls, Qumran, Ancient Texts
summary: This article re-examines the literary relationship between the Damascus Document (CD manuscript B, CD 20:1b-8a) and the Rule of the Community (1QS 8-9), focusing on textual overlaps. The study leverages the full publication of all S manuscripts to offer a nuanced reconsideration of previously recognized connections, such as the penal code. The analysis uncovers a complex inter-relationship between these Dead Sea Scrolls texts, providing intriguing insights into the literary history within the S tradition. This research is crucial for understanding the textual mosaic of Qumran literature.

title:
Review of Bring on the books for everybody: how

literary culture became popular culture by Jim Collins [2010]
fieldOfStudy: English, Literary Analysis, Cultural Studies, Sociology of Taste
summary: This is a review of "Bring on the books for everybody: how literary culture became popular culture" by J. Collins. The review critically examines Collins's interpretation of semiotic universes surrounding books, writers, and films, noting a potential over-reliance on this approach rather than empirical evidence of reader practices. It suggests that the book might primarily enable increased participation among existing "reading class" members. Despite this, the reviewer considers the book a valuable resource for initiating conversations about the evolving literary landscape and challenging assumptions within literary/literacy policymaking.

title: Literary taste : an empirical study of literature scholars, secondary school teachers and students
fieldOfStudy: English, Literary Analysis, Sociology of Education
summary: This paper investigates variations in reading practices and literary taste among literary scholars, upper secondary school teachers, and students in Sweden. Utilizing unique survey data, the study analyzes responses regarding author familiarity, literary genre preferences, and reading expectations. Multiple Correspondence Analysis reveals distinct taste profiles, providing empirical support for theoretical analyses of differences in literary taste. These profiles are strongly linked to the institutional roles of the respondents, offering insights into the sociology of education, culture, and literary consumption.

title: The image of a writer in nobel lectures delivered by laureates in literature
abstract:
Background. A growing interest in discursive nature of Nobel lectures resulted in a number of studies which emphasize their rhetorical force to influence public opinion and to popularize ideas in different spheres of human life. Analyzing Literature Laureates’ lectures, most researchers focus on linguistic means and the personality of the Nobelist himself/herself. However, characteristics of a writer proper have not been dealt with indepth. This article maintains our previous study, which indicates a close relationship between the content component of the Nobel lecture and the laureate’ outlook; the lecture itself can be regarded as a brief but extremely powerful expression of his/her human and professional qualities.
          
          Purpose. The aim of this paper is to examine how literature laureates interpret the notion of a writer in their Nobel lectures and to identify main common themes in creating this collective image.
          
          Methods. A method of linguistic description and observation, a descriptive method, and a contextual-interpretation method were employed to analyse the sample of 17 Nobel lectures.
          
          Results. The outcomes of our study indicate that Nobel lectures are extremely powerful expression of prizewinners’ human and professional qualities. We have devised a set of five themes, namely the writer’s social duty, his/her destiny, literary background, tools, and literary outcome to describe the collective image of a writer. Within the framework of our research, literary background falls into two subthemes (literary heritage and a personal writing process); discussing the writer’s toolkit, we focus on language and words.
          
          Discussion. Our findings show that laureates develop the concept “writer” to varying degrees but all of them stress a direct interconnection between an active social position and the writer’s destiny. Further research can involve the in-depth study of a definite Nobel lecture in terms of the compositional structure and employed linguistic means
summary: This study investigates how literature laureates interpret the notion of a "writer" in their Nobel lectures, aiming to identify common themes in forming this collective image. Employing linguistic description, observation, and contextual-interpretation methods on 17 Nobel lectures, the research highlights Nobel lectures as powerful expressions of prizewinners' human and professional qualities. Five key themes emerged: the writer's social duty, destiny, literary background (heritage, personal process), tools (language, words), and literary outcome. Findings indicate a strong link between an active social position and the writer's destiny, suggesting Nobel lectures offer valuable insights into the literary identity.

title: Reading Joyce in and out of the Archive
abstract: This essay contains a critical overview of responses to the 'scholarship' (by which is meant the study of the manuscripts and notebooks, the writing of biographical, the editing of his texts, the amalgamation of annotations, etc.) as opposed to 'criticism' of Joyce's later works. It argues for a greater textual awareness in the critical study of his writings.This is a pre-copyedited version of an article accepted for publication in the 'Joyce Studies Annual' following peer review. The definitive publisher-authenticated version is available through the University of Texas Press
summary: This essay critically examines the academic reception of James Joyce's later works, distinguishing between 'scholarship' (manuscript study, biography, textual editing) and 'criticism.' It argues for a more textually informed approach in critical studies of his writings, particularly highlighting a paradox in reader responses: while some dismiss Joyce criticism as overproduced and abstruse, others rely heavily on foundational works like Ellmann's biography and various annotations. The discussion emphasizes how academic writing has shaped and guided the reception of Joyce's oeuvre, urging a nuanced engagement with critical methodologies and textual awareness.

title: Reading, Trauma and Literary Caregiving 1914-1918: Helen Mary Gaskell and the War Library
abstract: This article is about the relationship between reading, trauma and responsive literary caregiving in Britain during the First World War. Its analysis of two little-known documents describing the history of the War Library, begun by Helen Mary Gaskell in 1914, exposes a gap in the scholarship of war-time reading; generates a new narrative of "how," "when," and "why" books went to war; and foregrounds gender in its analysis of the historiography. The Library of Congress's T. W. Koch discovered Gaskell's ground-breaking work in 1917 and reported its successes to the American Library Association. The British Times also covered Gaskell's library, yet researchers working on reading during the war have routinely neglected her distinct model and method, skewing the research base on war-time reading and its association with trauma and caregiving. In the article's second half, a literary case study of a popular war novel demonstrates the extent of the "bitter cry for books." The success of Gaskell's intervention is examined alongside H. G. Wells's representation of textual healing. Reading is shown to offer sick, traumatized and recovering combatants emotional and psychological caregiving in ways that she could not always have predicted and that are not visible in the literary/historical record
summary: This article explores the relationship between reading, trauma, and responsive literary caregiving in Britain during the First World War, focusing on Helen Mary Gaskell's neglected War Library. Analyzing two documents, it reveals a new narrative of wartime reading, highlighting gender's role in historiography. The study argues that Gaskell's distinct model, discovered by T. W. Koch and covered by The British Times, provided crucial emotional and psychological care for sick and traumatized combatants. A literary case study of a popular war novel further demonstrates the "bitter cry for books" and textual healing, as represented by H. G. Wells, often exceeding contemporary predictions and historical records.

title: Literary machine translation under the magnifying glass : assessing the quality of an NMT-translated detective novel on document level
abstract: Several studies (covering many language pairs and translation tasks) have demonstrated that translation quality has improved enormously since the emergence of neural machine translation systems. This raises the question whether such systems are able to produce high-quality translations for more creative text types such as literature and whether they are able to generate coherent translations on document level. Our study aimed to investigate these two questions by carrying out a document-level evaluation of the raw NMT output of an entire novel. We translated Agatha Christie's novel The Mysterious Affair at Styles with Google's NMT system from English into Dutch and annotated it in two steps: first all fluency errors, then all accuracy errors. We report on the overall quality, determine the remaining issues, compare the most frequent error types to those in general-domain MT, and investigate whether any accuracy and fluency errors co-occur regularly. Additionally, we assess the inter-annotator agreement on the first chapter of the novel
summary: This study evaluates the quality of neural machine translation (NMT) for creative texts like literature by assessing the raw NMT output of an entire novel. Researchers translated Agatha Christie's "The Mysterious Affair at Styles" from English to Dutch using Google's NMT system, then systematically annotated all fluency and accuracy errors. The study reports on overall translation quality, identifies persistent issues, compares error types to general-domain machine translation, and investigates co-occurrence of accuracy and fluency errors. Key findings concern the ability of NMT to produce coherent, high-quality literary translations on a document level, offering insights into remaining challenges for creative text translation.

title: Statistical keyword detection in literary corpora
abstract:
Understanding the complexity of human language requires an appropriate
analysis of the statistical distribution of words in texts. We consider the
information retrieval problem of detecting and ranking the relevant words of a
text by means of statistical information referring to the "spatial" use of the
words. Shannon's entropy of information is used as a tool for automatic keyword
extraction. By using The Origin of Species by Charles Darwin as a
representative text sample, we show the performance of our detector and compare
it with another proposals in the literature. The random shuffled text receives
special attention as a tool for calibrating the ranking indices.Comment: Published version. 11 pages, 7 figures. SVJour for LaTeX2
fieldOfStudy: English, literary analysis, natural language processing
summary: This study addresses the information retrieval problem of detecting and ranking relevant words in texts by analyzing their statistical distribution and "spatial" use. It leverages Shannon's entropy for automatic keyword extraction. Using "The Origin of Species" as a sample, the authors demonstrate the detector's performance and compare it to existing methods. The research emphasizes the use of random shuffled text for calibrating ranking indices, providing a robust approach to understanding human language complexity through word statistics and keyword detection.

title: Plotting Devices: Literary Darwinism in the Laboratory
abstract: Critics of literary Darwinism like to point out the weaknesses of its scientific scaffolding, but the real flaw in this research program is its neglect of literary history and stylistic evolution. A full-fledged scientific approach to literary criticism should incorporate the kind of work being done by Franco Moretti at the Stanford Literary Lab—a quantitative analysis of the history of literary form. While Moretti and the literary Darwinists are almost never mentioned together, I contend that their work is not only compatible but also necessarily so for a more consilient literary criticism. The Darwinian aesthetics promoted by Denis Dutton can help to unite these two approaches
fieldOfStudy: English Language and Literature, Literary Criticism
summary: This article argues that critics of literary Darwinism overlook its primary flaw: the neglect of literary history and stylistic evolution. It proposes integrating Franco Moretti's quantitative analysis of literary form, conducted at the Stanford Literary Lab, with Darwinian aesthetics, particularly those promoted by Denis Dutton. The author contends that combining these seemingly disparate approaches—Moretti's historical and stylistic analysis with literary Darwinism—is essential for developing a more comprehensive and robust scientific literary criticism, thereby addressing weaknesses in the existing research program.

title: Four close readings on introducing the literary in organizational research
summary: This chapter argues that organizational studies often reduce literary theory to a static source of concepts for argumentative tools or theoretical support, treating it as a 'supermarket' for methods to research organizational reality or theorize on organization generally. The authors conduct four close readings to demonstrate this reduction, exploring how literary theory is used for text structuring, distinguishing 'good' from 'bad' texts, or as a status symbol. The goal is to advocate for a more nuanced and dynamic integration of literary perspectives within organizational research, moving beyond a simplistic appropriation of literary concepts.

title: Lydia H. Liu. Translingual practice : literature, national culture, and translated modernity : China, 1900-1937
abstract: This article reviews the book  Translingual Practice: Literature, National Culture, and Translated Modernity—China, 1900-1937 , written by Lydia H. Liu
fieldOfStudy: English, Literary Analysis, Modern Chinese Literature, Translation Studies
summary: This article reviews Lydia H. Liu's book, "Translingual Practice: Literature, National Culture, and Translated Modernity—China, 1900-1937." The book explores how translation and translingual practices shaped modern Chinese literature, highlighting the interplay between Chinese and Western/Japanese influences. Liu analyzes the intellectual backgrounds and antagonisms between conservative National Essence Movements and radical New Culturalists, demonstrating their complementary roles in conceptualizing "Chinese national literature." The review emphasizes the book's interrogative approach, raising stimulating questions about literature, nation, and modernity that remain relevant today. It also notes an invaluable appended list of loan-words and neologisms.

title: Contextualizing the Writings of J.R.R. Tolkien on Literary Criticism
abstract: This essay offers a reinterpretation of Tolkien\u27s writings about literary criticism, which are focused on Beowulf, fairy stories, and his own works. Whereas his writings have often been taken to mean that analytic scholarship is not valid and should not be pursued, my essay takes the intellectual climate of the time into consideration and offers an alternative interpretation, according to which he did not mean to forbid these studies outright and indeed intended that scholars should continue writing them. The essay ends with a call to academics not to be discouraged by his strong language from producing analytic studies
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, Literary Criticism, Tolkien Studies
summary: This essay reinterprets J.R.R. Tolkien's writings on literary criticism, specifically concerning Beowulf, fairy stories, and his own works. Contrary to common interpretations that suggest he invalidated analytic scholarship, this study considers the intellectual climate of his time to argue that Tolkien did not intend to outright forbid such studies but rather encouraged their continuation. The essay concludes by urging academics not to be deterred by Tolkien's strong language from producing analytical literary studies, thus providing a nuanced understanding of his critical stance and its implications for literary scholarship.

title: CAROLINE LEVINE. Forms: Whole, Rhythm, Hierarchy, Network
abstract: Review of English Studies 66 (2015), 1001-
summary: Caroline Levine's "Forms: Whole, Rhythm, Hierarchy, Network" offers a bold reappraisal and defense of formalism, returning to its first principles. She defines 'form' as an arrangement of elements, arguing its concept transcends aesthetics and must be examined alongside philosophical and sociopolitical meanings. Drawing on design theory, literary criticism, and social sciences, Levine analyzes structural patterns in diverse forms, from poems and novels to legal cases and gender norms. Her analysis of Dickens's *Bleak House* exemplifies this approach, showing how literary form actively rewrites sociopolitical forms, emphasizing the specificities of literary texts in understanding social patterns and political structures. This interdisciplinary work advocates for a broader, more engaged formalist analysis.

title: Literary Value and Evaluation
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, Australian Literature, Literary Criticism
summary:
This volume, "Anglistentag 1988 G\u00f6ttingen Vortr
\u00e4ge," presents a collection of lectures focusing on English and Australian literature, culture, and academic studies. Key topics include the role of G\u00f6ttingen in 18th-century English literature, the sense of place in Australian writing, the Macquarie Dictionary, Australian literary nationalism, and the depiction of Ludwig Leichhardt in poetry. The volume also explores the relationship between Henry Handel Richardson's work and German culture, Blakean contraries in Patrick White's novels, and modernist fiction. A central theme is the critical evaluation of literary texts and canon formation.

title: Linguistics in the Study and Teaching of Literature
abstract: Literary texts include linguistic form, as well as specialized literary forms (some of which also involve language). Linguistics can offer to literary studies an understanding of these kinds of form, and the ways by which a text is used to communicate meaning. In order to cope with the great variety of creative uses of language in literature, linguistics must acknowledge that some texts are assigned structure by non-linguistic means, but the boundaries between linguistic and non-linguistic explanations for literary language are not clearly drawn. The article concludes with discussion of what kinds and level of linguistics might usefully be taught in a literature classroom, and offers practical suggestions for the application of linguistics to literature teaching
summary: This article explores how linguistics can enhance literary studies by clarifying linguistic and specialized literary forms, and how texts communicate meaning. It argues that linguistics must recognize non-linguistic structural assignments in literature, acknowledging the blurry line between linguistic and non-linguistic explanations for literary language. The paper concludes by suggesting suitable types and levels of linguistics for literature classrooms, offering practical applications for teaching literature effectively. Key terms include linguistics, literary studies, linguistic form, literary form, meaning communication, and language in literature.

title: Japanese Modernism And  Cine-Text : Fragments And Flows At Empire\u27s Edge In Kitagawa Fuyuhiko And Yokomitsu Riichi
abstract: This article notes that Kitagawa Fuyuhiko\u27s writings from the 1920s and 1930s, together with the contemporaneous works of prose author Yokomitsu Riichi, are strongly marked by the confluence of the literary and the cinematic. Kitagawa and Yokomitsu\u27s engagement with film was not limited to a fascination with the precision, objectivity, or mobility of the “camera eye.” Rather, it extended to the entire ability of the cinematic apparatus to capture the temporality of objects in motion, and of the ability of the filmmaker to organize segments of space into a new synthetic whole. The article explores this confluence through a brief examination of four instances of “cine-text”: Kitagawa\u27 poetry collection War, Yokomitsu\u27 novel Shanghai, the concept of literary formalism Yokomitsu proposed around the year 1930, and the theory of the “prose film” that Kitagawa unveiled in the following decade
fieldOfStudy: English, Literary Analysis, Japanese Modernism, Film Studies
summary: This article explores the significant confluence of literary and cinematic elements in the works of Japanese authors Kitagawa Fuyuhiko and Yokomitsu Riichi during the 1920s and 1930s. The authors' fascination extended beyond the "camera eye" to the cinematic apparatus's ability to capture temporality and organize space synthetically. The study examines this interplay through four "cine-text" instances: Kitagawa's poetry collection War, Yokomitsu's novel Shanghai, Yokomitsu's concept of literary formalism, and Kitagawa's "prose film" theory, highlighting how their writings emulated the "machine eye" for objective representation. This analysis contributes to understanding Japanese modernism and its engagement with early film aesthetics.

title: “In This Way the Moons and the Seasons Passed”: Distantly Reading the Literary Criticism of Things Fall Apart.
abstract: I employ distant reading techniques and data visualization tools to assess the literary criticism of Chinua Achebe's Things Fall Apart. My findings suggest that the scholarly literary criticism of Things Fall Apart did not occur independently with the publication of Achebe’s work in 1958, but was a part of a larger trend in literary criticism and theory associated with the establishment of postcolonial studies. Moreover, distantly reading the literary criticism of  Things Fall Apart points towards the ways in which critics have narrowly focused on framing Achebe’s text as a work of African culture and colonialism, in comparison with other texts in the genre. This has implications not only for locating Achebe's text within a narrow literary genre but also for the ways in which literary scholars can apply quantitative literary analysis to literary criticism in order to make inferences about the production of literary theory and culture
summary: This study employs distant reading and data visualization to analyze literary criticism of Chinua Achebe's "Things Fall Apart." The research indicates that the scholarly discourse surrounding Achebe's novel is deeply intertwined with the emergence of postcolonial studies, rather than being an independent phenomenon. Furthermore, the analysis reveals a narrow critical focus on framing the text primarily within the contexts of African culture and colonialism, potentially limiting its broader literary classification. This approach has implications for situating Achebe's work within a restrictive genre and demonstrates the utility of quantitative literary analysis in understanding the evolution of literary theory and culture. Keywords: distant reading, data visualization, Chinua Achebe, Things Fall Apart, postcolonial studies, literary criticism, quantitative literary analysis.

title: Homeland Beyond Homelands : Reinventing Algeria Through A Transnational Literary Community: Assia Djebar\u27s  Le Blanc De L\u27Algérie
fieldOfStudy: French and Francophone Language and Literature
summary: This article explores Assia Djebar's "Le Blanc de l'Algérie" to demonstrate how Algeria is reinvented through a transnational literary community, moving "Homeland beyond Homelands." The study analyzes Djebar's approach to Algerian identity, history, and postcoloniality within a broader literary context, examining her discourses on "Algérianité." It aims to highlight the role of literature in re-imagining national narratives and identities through the lens of a prominent Francophone author. Key themes include transnationalism, postcolonial literature, and cultural identity in the context of Algeria.

title: Reading Tehran in Lolita: Seizing Literary Value for Neoliberal Multiculturalism
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, Gender and Sexual Politics, Critical Race Theory
summary: This article, "Reading Tehran in Lolita: Seizing Literary Value for Neoliberal Multiculturalism" by Jodi Melamed, critiques how literary value is extracted for neoliberal multiculturalism. Focusing on the interpretation of Vladimir Nabokov's "Lolita" in a specific cultural context, the author explores the racialized and gendered dimensions embedded within such readings. It analyzes how difference, particularly related to women and identity, is deployed and reconfigured within academic discourse. The work delves into the intersection of literary studies, gender and sexual politics, and comparative racialization, drawing on theories from women of color feminism and queer of color critique. Key themes include critical race theory, gender studies, postcolonial reason, and the politics of knowledge production.

title: GCE AS and A level subject criteria for English literature
publisher: Office of Qualifications and Examinations Regulation
