summary: This document outlines the GCE AS and A Level Subject Criteria for English Literature, detailing the aims, objectives, subject content, and assessment objectives for these qualifications. It specifies the knowledge and understanding students should acquire, including engagement with literary texts across different genres and periods, and the skills to analyze and interpret them. Key assessment areas include understanding literary forms, contexts, and critical approaches, with an emphasis on written communication and synoptic assessment to evaluate integrated learning. This establishes a framework for academic standards in literary studies.

title: Teaching Edith Eaton/Sui Sin Far: Multiple Approaches
abstract: This essay compares pedagogical approaches to teaching the literature of Edith Eaton in two distinct contexts: a course on Asian American Literature and a course on Asian Americans of Mixed Heritage.  This is a comparison of the variant pedagogical approaches in these two different contexts
fieldOfStudy: English Asian American Literature Mixed Heritage
summary: This essay compares pedagogical approaches to teaching Edith Eaton's literature in two distinct academic contexts: an Asian American Literature course and a course on Asian Americans of Mixed Heritage. The study aims to synthesize these variant pedagogical methods, suggesting how each context can enrich the other. A literature course typically focuses on literary qualities, themes, and issues, while a mixed heritage course explores the social, legal, and historical circumstances surrounding Eaton's life as reflected in her work. The paper highlights the interdisciplinary nature of Asian American literary studies and the developing cultural and literary components within mixed heritage Asian American studies.

title: Review of \u3cem\u3eSongs of Ourselves: The Uses of Poetry in America\u3c/em\u3e by Joan Shelley Rubin
summary: This review examines Joan Shelley Rubin's "Songs of Ourselves: The Uses of Poetry in America," which argues for poetry's utilitarian value beyond mere enjoyment. The reviewer critiques Rubin's historical scope, suggesting an underutilization of existing scholarship on topics like the "girl poet" phenomenon and sentimental collaborations in nineteenth-century American women's poetry. Despite these criticisms, the review praises Rubin's fluent writing and acknowledges the book as a compelling overview of poetry's historical significance to readers, exploring the dynamic interplay between individuals, texts, and institutions. It highlights the refreshing reminder that reading often transcends ideological divides for pleasure.

title: Internal Chronotopic Genre Structures : The Nineteenth-Century Historical Novel in the Context of the Belgian Literary Polysystem
abstract: One of the most fundamental problems of systemic approaches to literature is the question of how systemic principles might be translated into a manageable methodological framework. This contribution proposes that a combination of functionalistsystemic theories (in casu Itamar Even-Zohar’s Polysystem theory – especially the textually oriented versions – and the prototypical genre approach proposed by Dirk De Geest and Hendrik Van Gorp 1999) with Mikhail Bakhtin’s chronotope theory shows great promise in this respect. Since I am primarily interested in literary genres, the prototypical genre approach assumes a central position in my theoretical framework. My main argument is that Bakhtin’s chronotope concept offers interesting perspectives as a heuristic tool within a functionalist-systemic approach to genre studies, enabling the study not only of the constitutive elements of genre systems, but also of their mutual relations. Bakhtin’s own vague definitions of the concept somewhat hamper the process of putting it into practice for this purpose, but with the aid of the distinction between generic and motivic chronotopes, that problem can be solved. A detailed, comprehensive account of the theoretical premises underlying my proposal can be found in Bemong (under review); here I restrict myself to the basics
fieldOfStudy: English, Literary Analysis, Polysystem Theory, Genre Studies, Chronotope Theory
summary: This contribution addresses the challenge of translating systemic literary principles into a methodological framework, proposing a combination of functionalist-systemic theories, specifically Itamar Even-Zohar's Polysystem theory and Dirk De Geest and Hendrik Van Gorp's prototypical genre approach, with Mikhail Bakhtin's chronotope theory. The author argues that Bakhtin's chronotope concept serves as a valuable heuristic tool within a functionalist-systemic approach to genre studies, enabling the analysis of constitutive elements of genre systems and their interrelations. The distinction between generic and motivic chronotopes helps overcome the vagueness in Bakhtin's original definitions, providing a practical application for literary genre studies.

title: Worlds at our fingertips:reading (in) What Remains of Edith Finch
abstract: Video games are works of written code which portray worlds and characters in action and facilitate an aesthetic and interpretive experience. Beyond this similarity to literary works, some video games deploy various design strategies which blend gameplay and literary elements to explicitly foreground a hybrid literary/ludic experience. We identify three such strategies: engaging with literary structures, forms and techniques; deploying text in an aesthetic rather than a functional way; and intertextuality. This paper aims to analyse how these design strategies are deployed in What Remains of Edith Finch (Giant Sparrow, 2017) to support a hybrid readerly/playerly experience. We argue that this type of design is particularly suited for walking simulators because they support interpretive play (Upton, 2015) through slowness, ambiguity (Muscat et al., 2016; Pinchbeck 2012), narrative and aesthetic aspirations (Carbo-Mascarell, 2016). Understanding walking sims as literary games (Ensslin, 2014) can shift the emphasis from their lack of ‘traditional’ gameplay complexity and focus instead on the opportunities that they afford for hybrid storytelling and for weaving literature and gameplay in innovative and playful ways
summary: This paper analyzes how video games, particularly "walking simulators" like "What Remains of Edith Finch," blend gameplay and literary elements to create a hybrid experience. The authors identify three strategies: engaging with literary structures, aesthetic text deployment, and intertextuality. They argue that walking simulators are particularly suited for this design, supporting interpretive play through slowness, ambiguity, narrative, and aesthetic aspirations. Understanding these as literary games shifts focus from traditional gameplay complexity to opportunities for innovative storytelling and weaving literature and gameplay. Keywords: video games, literary games, walking simulators, What Remains of Edith Finch, hybrid experience, interpretive play, game design, narrative, intertextuality.

title: Women and Intertextuality: On the Example of Margaret Atwood’s The Penelopiad
abstract:
The aim of the study is to consider feminist retellings of myths and legends. As an example,
Margaret Atwood’s book The Penelopiad is analyzed. The interpretation is situated in
a broader context of intertextual practices characteristic of the feminist vision of literature. I
present the ideas which Atwood shares with authors engaged in women’s movement. Among
these there is Atwood’s understanding of intertextuality (noticeable especially in The
Penelopiad). Bibliographical basis of the study comprises books which are fundamental to
feminist and gender criticism (e.g. Poetics of Gender, ed. by N. Miller, New York 1986;
S. M. Gilbert, S. Gubar The Madwoman in the Attic. The Woman Writer and the Nineteenth-
Century Literary Imagination, New Haven and London 1984). What is more, the study refers to
the books which allow considering the notion of intertextuality (G. Allen, Intertextuality,
London and New York 2010, J. Clayton. E. Rothstein (eds.), Influence and Intertextuality in
Literary History, Wisconsin 1991) and connecting the interpretation with the problems crucial
to contemporary literary studies (L. Hutcheon L. A Poetics of Postmodernism. History, Theory,
Fiction, New York and London 1988, B. Johnson, A World of Difference, Baltimore and London
1989)
publisher: Department of Studies in Drama and Pre-1800 English Literature, University of Łódź
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, Feminist Criticism, Gender Studies
summary: This study analyzes feminist retellings of myths, using Margaret Atwood's "The Penelopiad" as a primary example. The research contextualizes Atwood's work within broader intertextual practices aligned with feminist literary vision and the women's movement, specifically highlighting her unique understanding of intertextuality. The methodology draws on foundational texts in feminist and gender criticism, alongside key works on intertextuality and contemporary literary studies. The main finding emphasizes Atwood's contribution to feminist literature through her intertextual engagement with myths and legends. Keywords include feminist retellings, intertextuality, Margaret Atwood, The Penelopiad, feminist criticism, gender criticism, literary studies.

title: Muatan Materi Sastra dalam Buku Teks Bahasa Indonesia Kelas VIII Serta Relevansinya dengan Kompetensi Inti dan Kompetensi Dasar
abstract: This study aims to describe (a) the content of material literary contained in Indonesian textbooks class VIII (b) the relevance of material literary contained in the Indonesian textbooks class VIII with the Core Competence of Curriculum 2013, and (c) the relevance of material literary contained in the Indonesian textbooks class VIII with Basic Competence of Curriculum 2013. The type of this research is descriptive qualitative research which is focused in research content or documents analysis.the Data is in the form of words, sentences, core competence and basic competence, and material literary on Indonesian textbooks for Junior High School class VIII published by the ministry of Education and Culture in 2017. The Techniques data collection by reading techniques, references, notes, interviews and questionnaires. The data analysis by analysis content technique and qualitative technique. The research findings show that (a) the content of material literary presented in this text is poetry, prose covering novels, film reviews, song reviews, short stories and drama, (b) the relevance of material literary with Core Competence is presented in six subjects the literary material is said to be relevant because it will provide adequate activity and explanation while the two subjects of the material literary is irrelevant because it is not the focus of providing explanations and adquate activities for the achievement of Core Competencies; and the last (c) the relevance of material literary with Basic Competence is present by eight subjects material literary that relevant to Basic Competence and as much as five subject matter of material literary that’s not relevant to Basic Competence
fieldOfStudy: English, literary analysis, education, curriculum development
summary: This descriptive qualitative study analyzed the content and relevance of literary materials in Indonesian textbooks for 8th grade, published by the Ministry of Education and Culture in 2017. Using content analysis and qualitative techniques, the research examined the alignment of literary content (poetry, prose, drama, reviews) with the Core Competencies and Basic Competencies of the 2013 Curriculum. Findings indicated that while some literary materials were relevant, others were not, highlighting areas for improvement in curriculum design and textbook content to better achieve learning objectives. This study is crucial for evaluating educational materials and curriculum development in language education.

title: Литературоведческие исследования: Введение в литературоведение
abstract: Мета навчальної дисципліни «Літературознавчі студії: Вступ до літературознавства» – оволодіння студентами головним термінологічним апаратом літературознавства, здобуття навичок літературознавчого аналізу художнього тексту та вмінням орієнтуватись у літературному процесі.The purpose of the academic discipline "Literary Studies: Introduction to Literary Studies" is the mastery of students by the main terminology apparatus of literary studies, the acquisition of skills in literary analysis of artistic text and the ability to orientate in the literary process.Цель учебной дисциплины "Литературоведческие исследования: Введение в литературоведение" - овладение основным терминологическим аппаратом литературоведения, приобретение навыков литературоведческого анализа художественного текста и умения ориентироваться в литературном процессе
summary: This academic discipline, "Literary Studies: Introduction to Literary Studies," aims to equip students with the core terminology of literary studies, foster skills in literary analysis of artistic texts, and develop their ability to navigate the literary process. The curriculum emphasizes mastering key concepts and analytical methods to understand literary works and their historical and theoretical contexts. This foundation is crucial for students pursuing further study or careers in literature, criticism, and related humanities fields, enhancing their critical thinking and interpretive capacities within the broader literary landscape.

title: The American Dream and American Greed in Fanny Fern’s Ruth Hall: Sentimental and Satirical Christian Discourse in the Popular Domestic Tale
abstract:
Although Fanny Fern’s Ruth Hall: A Domestic Tale of the Present Time originally was a widely
popular book in the nineteenth century, Fern and Ruth Hall were criticized after readers
learned about the similarities among Fern’s life and book. Contemporary critics have
recovered Ruth Hall from the literary margins and situated Ruth’s story in the context of the
popular American dream story while emphasizing the book’s satirical elements. Reexamining
the novel’s originally popular sentimental elements alongside the novel’s more recently
popular satirical elements expands the literary critical focus from Ruth’s sentimental
struggles and Fern’s satirical accomplishments to Ruth Hall’s equally important critique of
American greed, especially among wealthy and socially-conscious Christians
publisher: Department of Studies in Drama and Pre-1800 English Literature, University of Łódź
summary: This article reexamines Fanny Fern's novel, "Ruth Hall," which was initially popular but later criticized due to its autobiographical similarities. While contemporary critics highlight its satirical elements and connection to the American dream narrative, this study expands the focus to include the novel's original sentimental aspects. The purpose is to demonstrate how "Ruth Hall" offers a significant critique of American greed, particularly among affluent, socially-conscious Christians. This analysis integrates both sentimental and satirical readings to broaden literary critical understanding of the work's social commentary. Keywords: domesticity, literary marketplace, sentimentality, social class, Fanny Fern, Ruth Hall, American greed.

title: Selected bibliography for work in reading, literacy, and pedagogy
fieldOfStudy: English, Comparative Literature, Cultural Studies, Education
summary: This bibliography provides a selected resource for scholarship in reading, literacy, and pedagogy. It supports research in comparative literature, cultural studies, education, and language studies, reflecting the interdisciplinary nature of these fields. Published in CLCWeb: Comparative Literature and Culture, the compilation aids researchers and scholars by offering a structured overview of relevant academic works, facilitating further study and discussion in areas such as literacy and society, culture, media, and education. The bibliography is an open-access resource, promoting broad dissemination of scholarly information.

title: Back to where we came from: evolutionary psychology and children’s literature and media
abstract:
In 2010, The New York Times ran an article which announced that ‘the next big thing in English [Studies]’ was ‘using evolutionary theory to explain fiction’.  This announcement may be considered somewhat belated, given that the interest in the potential relevance of evolutionary psychology  to literary studies might be traced back to a considerably earlier date than 2010.  Joseph Carroll first published on the subject as far back as 1995, and by 2002 Steven Pinker could claim that ‘within the academy, a growing number of mavericks are looking to Evolutionary psychology and cognitive science in an effort to re-establish human nature as the center of any understanding of the arts’.  Nevertheless, The New York Times’s announcement may be taken as a measure of an increasingly visible trend in both popular and academic thinking.  

We argue in this chapter that this trend is motivated specifically by nostalgia, or the longing for a past which seems forever lost. A second aspect of this nostalgia will also be discussed to do with the way that we argue that this supposedly ‘new’ area of research repeats exactly a long history of prior claims of many eminent children’s literature critics with respect to ideas of childhood, language and children’s literature and media. Despite the repeated, insistent claims of several of the Literary Darwinists, including, for instance, Joseph Carroll, one of the founders of this way of thinking, that they are working in heroic opposition to a dominant, obscurantist and anti-science ‘literary theory’,  we argue here that in fact there is a high degree of convergence between the claims made about childhood, language and children’s literature in Literary Darwinism and much children’s literature criticism. We therefore see Literary Darwinism and (children’s) literature studies as not being in any sense about an opposition or separation between science and literary or humanist studies, but about a convergence underpinned and driven by the same nostalgia for a singular, stable, uniform and universal past, leading to a singular, stable, uniform and universal present.

Finally, we suggest that it is not just in these two fields in which this nostalgia operates, but that this can currently be seen in sub-streams within many disciplines – in both in arts, sciences and humanities -- as a founding, powerfully political, driver
summary: This chapter argues that the increasing trend of using evolutionary psychology in literary studies, particularly "Literary Darwinism," is driven by a form of nostalgia for a lost past and repeats earlier claims made in children's literature criticism. Despite assertions by proponents like Joseph Carroll of opposing dominant literary theory, the authors find significant convergence between Literary Darwinism's claims about childhood, language, and children's literature and existing children's literature criticism. They conclude that this trend represents a convergence, not an opposition, between science and humanities, fueled by a shared longing for a singular, stable, and universal understanding of the past and present. This nostalgic driver is suggested to operate across many disciplines.

title: Sally Taylor lieberman. The mother and narrative politics in modern China
abstract: This article reviews the book  The Mother and Narrative Politics in Modern China  written by Sally Taylor Lieberman
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, Modern Chinese Literature, Gender Studies, Literary Criticism
summary: This article reviews Sally Taylor Lieberman's book, "The Mother and Narrative Politics in Modern China," which examines modern Chinese literature through the lens of the mother figure. Lieberman employs feminist, postmodern, and psychoanalytic theories to explore how the mother symbolizes modernity, nationhood, and revolution. The review highlights how the book complicates the understanding of Chinese literature by connecting various texts through the mother motif, exposing the limitations of the literary canon and gender politics in its formation. It emphasizes the value of a topical approach in literary studies, contributing to knowledge of the narrative mother and broader issues like sentimentality and national identity.

title: The Problem of Temporality in the Literary Framework of Nicholas of Cusa’s De pace fidei
abstract: This paper explores Nicholas of Cusa’s framing of the De pace fidei as a dialogue taking place incaelo rationis. On the one hand, this framing allows Nicholas of Cusa to argue that all religious rites presuppose the truth of a single, unified faith and so temporally manifest divine logos in a way accommodated to the historically unique conventions of different political communities. On the other hand, at the end of the De pace fidei, the interlocutors in the heavenly dialogue are enjoined to return to earth and lead their countrymen in a gradual conversion to the acceptance of rites which would explicitly acknowledge the metaphysically presupposed transcendent unity of all true faiths. In light of these two aspects of the literary framing of the De pace fidei, the question that motivates this paper concerns the extent to which the understanding of history subtending Cusanus’ temporal political aims is consistent with the understanding of history grounded in his metaphysical presupposition that there is una religio in omni diversitate rituum. In addressing this question, I shall argue that the literary strategy of the De pace fidei sacrifices Nicholas of Cusa’s apologetic doctrinal aims insofar as the text creates an allegorical space in which the tension between its literal and figurative dimensions assigns to its readers the task of choosing their own orientations to the significance of history as a foundation for future action
summary: This paper examines Nicholas of Cusa's framing of "De pace fidei" as a dialogue in "caelo rationis," where religious rites manifest a unified faith accommodating diverse political communities. It questions the consistency between Cusanus's temporal political aims and his metaphysical belief in "una religio in omni diversitate rituum." The author argues that the text's literary strategy, by creating an allegorical space with tension between literal and figurative dimensions, ultimately sacrifices Nicholas of Cusa's apologetic doctrinal aims, assigning readers the task of interpreting history's significance for future action. Keywords: Nicholas of Cusa, De pace fidei, temporality, literary framing, religious unity, political aims, metaphysics, allegory.

title:
Quantifying origin and character of long-range correlations in narrative
  texts
abstract:
In natural language using short sentences is considered efficient for
communication. However, a text composed exclusively of such sentences looks
technical and reads boring. A text composed of long ones, on the other hand,
demands significantly more effort for comprehension. Studying characteristics
of the sentence length variability (SLV) in a large corpus of world-famous
literary texts shows that an appealing and aesthetic optimum appears somewhere
in between and involves selfsimilar, cascade-like alternation of various
lengths sentences. A related quantitative observation is that the power spectra
S(f) of thus characterized SLV universally develop a convincing `1/f^beta'
scaling with the average exponent beta =~ 1/2, close to what has been
identified before in musical compositions or in the brain waves. An
overwhelming majority of the studied texts simply obeys such fractal attributes
but especially spectacular in this respect are hypertext-like, "stream of
consciousness" novels. In addition, they appear to develop structures
characteristic of irreducibly interwoven sets of fractals called multifractals.
Scaling of S(f) in the present context implies existence of the long-range
correlations in texts and appearance of multifractality indicates that they
carry even a nonlinear component. A distinct role of the full stops in inducing
the long-range correlations in texts is evidenced by the fact that the above
quantitative characteristics on the long-range correlations manifest themselves
in variation of the full stops recurrence times along texts, thus in SLV, but
to a much lesser degree in the recurrence times of the most frequent words. In
this latter case the nonlinear correlations, thus multifractality, disappear
even completely for all the texts considered. Treated as one extra word, the
full stops at the same time appear to obey the Zipfian rank-frequency
distribution, however.Comment: 28 pages, 8 figures, accepted for publication in Information Science
fieldOfStudy: English, Literary Analysis, Complex Systems Theory, Information Science
summary:
This study investigates sentence length variability (SLV) in world-famous literary texts, finding an aesthetic optimum that involves self-similar, cascade-like alternation of sentence lengths. The power spectra S(f) of SLV universally exhibit a "1/f^beta" scaling with an average exponent beta 
A related quantitative observation is that the power spectra S(f) of thus characterized SLV universally develop a convincing `1/f^beta' scaling with the average exponent beta =~ 1/2, similar to musical compositions and brain waves. Hypertext-like novels, especially "stream of consciousness" works, show pronounced fractal and multifractal attributes, indicating long-range correlations and nonlinear components in texts. The research highlights the distinct role of full stops in inducing these long-range correlations, manifesting in SLV rather than word recurrence times, while also obeying Zipfian rank-frequency distribution. These findings offer quantitative insights into narrative text structure and complexity.

title: Menorah Review (No. 65, Summer/Fall, 2006)
abstract: A Rebbe in Skirts -- By Way of Introduction: Reflections on Israeli Women\u27s Studies: A Reader -- Israeli Literature and Israeli Politics -- More in than Out -- Revisiting Old Themes Through a Contemporary Lens -- The World of Rabbi Nathan -- Noteworthy Book
fieldOfStudy: Religious Thought, Theology and Philosophy of Religion, History of Religion
summary: This collection of review essays from "Menorah Review" (No. 65, Summer/Fall, 2006) delves into various aspects of Jewish thought and literature. Key essays include "A Rebbe in Skirts," "Reflections on Israeli Women's Studies: A Reader," "Israeli Literature and Israeli Politics," and "The World of Rabbi Nathan." The issue also features "More in than Out" and "Revisiting Old Themes Through a Contemporary Lens." The publication aims to enrich Jewish thought through critical reviews of contemporary works, exploring themes such as religious figures, gender studies, political intersections with literature, and historical perspectives.

title: Reception problems for women writers: the case of Simone de Beauvoir
summary: This essay examines the reception of Simone de Beauvoir's writing, specifically how her readership and critical image have evolved over time, particularly in relation to the publication of *Le Deuxième Sexe*. It investigates how initial perceptions, gendered criticism, and literary traditions shaped her reception, exploring whether she can be understood within a general framework for women writers. The study finds that Beauvoir's work often faced accusations of impropriety, aligning with broader issues in the reception of women's writing, despite her initial attempts to align with male literary traditions. Keywords: Simone de Beauvoir, literary reception, feminist criticism, women's writing, Le Deuxième Sexe, literary history.

title: Literary translation and cultural memory
abstract: This article intends to investigate the relationship between literary translation and cultural memory, using a twentieth century film version of one of Shakespeare’s plays as a case study in inter-semiotic translation. The common perception of translation is often confined to its use as a language learning tool or as a means of information transfer between languages. The wider academic concept embraces not only inter-lingual translation, but both intra-lingual activity or rewording in the same language and inter-semiotic translation defined by Roman Jacobson as “the interpretation of verbal signs by means of signs of nonverbal sign systems” (Jakobson, 1959: 114)
fieldOfStudy: English, Literary Analysis, Translation Studies, Cultural Memory
summary: This article investigates the intricate relationship between literary translation and cultural memory, using a 20th-century film adaptation of a Shakespearean play as a case study in inter-semiotic translation. It expands the traditional view of translation beyond mere language transfer, embracing intra-lingual and inter-semiotic activities, as defined by Roman Jakobson. The study highlights how cultural memory serves as a crucial resource for translators, influencing their interpretive choices and the broader reception of translated works. This research contributes to understanding translation studies, cultural studies, and the enduring legacy of classical literature.

title: Evaluative criteria in literature for elementary grades.
abstract: Thesis (Ed.M.)--Boston Universit
fieldOfStudy: English, Education, Literary Criticism, Elementary Education
summary: This thesis aims to establish evaluative criteria for literature in elementary grades, focusing on enriching life through appreciation and enjoyment of worthwhile literary experiences. The study outlines a problem statement and its justification, reviews existing research, and details procedures for developing materials, involving jury members, and analyzing their criticisms. Key methods include constructing criteria and proposing suggestions for their application, supported by an appendix and bibliography. This research provides a structured approach for educators to assess and select appropriate literary texts for young students, emphasizing the importance of literary experience in elementary education.

title: Keith Foulcher and Tony Day (Eds), Sastra Indonesia Modern: Kritik Postkolonial; Edisi Revisi ‘Clearing a Space'. with Foreword by Manneke Budiman and Translated by Koesalah Soebagyo Toer and Monique Soesman. Jakarta: Yayasan Obor Indonesia and KITLV-Jaka
fieldOfStudy: English, Literary Analysis, Gender Studies, Indonesian History
summary: This review discusses a book examining the correspondence of Soemantri, the youngest sister of Kartini, highlighting her modern perspective and involvement in public activities in early 20th-century Indonesia. Unlike her sisters, Soemantri's letters ceased in 1936, reflecting her liberation from traditional constraints and her role, alongside her husband, as a representative of a new Indonesian middle class. The text also touches on themes of gender, ethnicity, and nationalism in relation to the position of Indonesian women, referencing Nira Yuval-Davis's work and Cora Vreede-De Stuers's historical analysis. It explores the interplay between Javanese and colonial reformers, and Muslim and secular nationalists.

title: Should Canada Enact a New Sui Generis Database Right?
publisher: FLASH: The Fordham Law Archive of Scholarship and History
fieldOfStudy: English, Intellectual Property Law, Entertainment Arts and Sports Law
summary: This article explores whether Canada should implement a new sui generis database right, analyzing the economic justifications for protecting databases against the public interest in access to data. It examines the complexities of intellectual property protection for databases, considering existing frameworks and the potential implications of new legislation. The author emphasizes the necessity of a meaningful mechanism to balance competing interests and suggests that decisions regarding public interest uses are best addressed through policy by Parliament, rather than through abstract legal permissions. Key concepts include database rights, intellectual property, public interest, and legislative policy.

title: Literary Modernity between Arabic and Persian Prose: Jurji Zaydan's Riwayat in Persian Translation
abstract: Our understanding of nineteenth-century literary practice is often mediated by the national literature model of study that continues to govern discussions of modern literature. Put differently, contemporary evaluations of literary texts of the nineteenth century are often arrived at by using the national literature models that remain ascendant. This results in particular from the interplay of two concepts, 'nationalism' and 'novelism', and the role that these ideological agendas play in establishing the frameworks for literary study that predominate in today's academy. Novelism is defined by Clifford Siskin as 'the habitual subordination of writing to the novel' —it is the prevalent tendency to approach prose writing in general using a framework of value derived from criticism of the novel.1 Rather than evaluating texts of the period in question by using criteria that can be validly ascribed to the sites of their production, we often tend to employ instead criteria derived from the novel as a currently-ascendant form of writing. Together with the tendency to read literature as defined exclusively by the trajectories offered in national-literature frameworks, this dual agenda has come to represent the most widespread tendency in literary historical scholarship, that of the nationalist-novelist paradigm, which presumes national literatures to be its subject matter, and which evaluates (non-European) prose writing largely through the critical tools developed for assessing the European novel
fieldOfStudy: English, literary analysis, comparative literature, nineteenth-century literature, nationalism, novelism
summary: This study examines how nineteenth-century literary practice, particularly non-European prose, is often evaluated through the 'national literature' model and 'novelism.' Novelism, defined as the subordination of writing to the novel framework, combined with national literature paradigms, creates a nationalist-novelist approach. This paradigm predominantly assesses prose using critical tools developed for the European novel, rather than criteria relevant to the texts' original production contexts. The research highlights the ideological agendas of nationalism and novelism in shaping contemporary literary study frameworks and their impact on understanding literary modernity, particularly in Arabic and Persian prose.

title: Introduction: The Configuration of Feminist Criticism and Theoretical Practices in Hispanic Literary Studies
summary: This introduction examines the configuration of feminist criticism and theoretical practices within Hispanic literary studies, addressing the ongoing confusion and debate despite an increase in feminist-labeled literary analyses of Hispanic texts. It aims to clarify the goals, methodologies, and evolving nature of feminist approaches, emphasizing their role in challenging patriarchal structures within language, literature, and society. The discussion highlights efforts to revise the literary canon, expose sexism in previously perceived neutral texts, and ultimately empower marginalized voices. Keywords: feminist criticism, Hispanic literary studies, patriarchal society, literary canon, sexism, gender studies.

title: Transmission and Mortal Anxiety in the Tale of Aqhat
abstract: Forthcoming in Like ʾIlu Are You Wise: Studies in Northwest Semitic Languages and Literature in Honor of Dennis G. Pardee, Oriental Institute Publications
fieldOfStudy: English, Literary Analysis, Northwest Semitic Languages and Literature
summary: This study analyzes the Ugaritic tale of Aqhat, arguing that it subverts conventional expectations of the father-son relationship, particularly concerning themes of sonship and mortality. The narrative establishes the traditional father-son dynamic only to replace it with an alternative: the blessing and success generated through the father-daughter relationship. The author explores how the story's events and character discourse reshape social relationships to align with this agenda. Keywords: Ugaritic tale, Aqhat, father-son relationship, father-daughter relationship, sonship, mortality, ancient literature, Northwest Semitic.

title: Joseph A. Feustle, Jr. sobre John C. Wilcox: \u3cem\u3eSelf and Image in Juan Ramón Jiménez\u3c/em\u3e
fieldOfStudy: English, Latin American Literature, Modern Literature, Poetry, Literary Analysis, Literary Criticism
summary:
This review by Joseph A. Feustle, Jr. examines John C. Wilcox's study, "Self and Image in Juan Ram
Jim
ez" (1987), which applies contemporary critical theories from Barthes, Culler, Derrida, and others, to analyze the poetry of Nobel laureate Juan Ram
Jim
ez. Wilcox's work critically reads five poetic texts representing different phases of Jim
ez's output. The reviewer praises the rigor of Wilcox's analysis but suggests a reduced reliance on what are perceived as "current fads in literary criticism" and obscure jargon, advocating for a deeper exploration of Hispanic traditions for certain themes and a focus on the heterogeneity of Jim
ez's early poetry.

title: Literary Cognitivism
fieldOfStudy: English, Philosophy of Literature, Literary Theory
summary: This text explores literary cognitivism, the idea that knowledge can be acquired from reading literature, particularly fictional narrative works. It highlights the central role literature plays in education and cultural practices, yet also examines the complexities surrounding the *kind* of knowledge gained and *how* literature functions as a source of knowledge. The discussion focuses on psychologically realistic novels from the 18th and 19th centuries, but also includes other literary forms. It delves into the debate on whether literature offers arguments or opportunities for reflection, and touches upon its potential to function like philosophical or scientific thought experiments, challenging readers to clarify and reflect on existing views. This analysis is crucial for understanding the epistemological value of literary works.

title: Olea Franco, Rafael. \u3cem\u3eBorges:desesperaciones aparentes y consuelos secretos\u3c/em\u3e. México:El Colegio de México, 1999. 312 pp.
fieldOfStudy: English, literary analysis, Hispanic literature, Jorge Luis Borges
summary: This collection of fifteen essays, published to commemorate the hundredth anniversary of Jorge Luis Borges's birth, offers critical readings from diverse perspectives united by a shared appreciation for his work. The essays, spanning all genres practiced by Borges, are thematically organized into five sections, exploring his influence on writers like Danilo Kis and W. G. Sebald, and the importance of time and space in his fiction. This compilation demonstrates the enduring relevance of Borges's oeuvre, serving to both elucidate his writing and highlight areas that continue to challenge interpretation, prompting ongoing critical engagement and 'desesperaciones' that necessitate a search for 'consuelo.'

title: Reterritorialising literary studies: deconstructing the scripts of empire
abstract: In this article, I demonstrate the ways in which archival material can be gainfully employed within literary studies. Focusing on the figure of the Indian coolie of colonial Malaya, I argue that adopting such an interdisciplinary paradigm is a necessary bridge to aid the quest for the story of the pioneer Indian immigrant experience for its trail stretches across two terrains of narrativisation, one historical, the other literary. As I seek out the texts that have constructed the base of the sign-system that has in many ways locked the subject in question within its confining structures, I also propose to read them against the grain, to dislodge their deeply embedded discursive pillars. In other words, I will proceed with what is primarily a deconstructive reading of the colonialist sign-systems of the coolie. The article thus demonstrates the reterritorialising of literary studies as it excavates the scripts of empire buried within the terrain of history through the mechanisms of literary deconstruction, thus re-reading history as literatur
publisher: Pusat Pengajian Bahasa dan Linguistik, FSSK, UKM
summary: This article demonstrates the effective use of archival material within literary studies, focusing on the Indian coolie in colonial Malaya. It argues for an interdisciplinary approach to narrativize the pioneer Indian immigrant experience, bridging historical and literary terrains. The author deconstructs colonialist sign-systems that confined the coolie subject, reading existing texts against the grain to dislodge discursive pillars. The study reterritorializes literary studies by excavating empire's scripts buried in history through literary deconstruction, re-reading history as literature. Keywords include subaltern, deconstruction, interdisciplinary, colonialism, and diaspora.

title: Representations of the fin-de-siècle literary salon in the chronicles of Matilde Serao
abstract: This article looks into the representations of the Italian literary salon in the print press during the 1880’s. Special attention is given to Matilde Serao’s mediation in the private as well as in the public sphere and to her double role as salon chronicler and salon attendee. Her views with regard to the artistic and political landscape of fin-de-siècle Italy are examined through a series of chronicles on Pasquale Mancini, Baroness Magliani, Francesco De Renzis, and the salon of the literary magazine Capitan Fracassa. The representations of these salons in the fortnightly periodical Cronaca Bizantina (Rome, 1881-1886) as well as in the daily newspaper Corriere di Roma (1883-1886) offered a new reading experience to a wide audience and encouraged the creation of an imagined community of salon attendees. Thus, salon participation is studied through the prism of the periodical press, which interpreted salon life as a meaningful collective experience and a decisive factor in the formation of culture. Serao’s chronicle is also viewed as an instrument of social critique, which raised questions on the rapid expansion of mass media, the growing demand for human progress, the withering away of politics, and the growing importance of art as a means of personal expression
summary: This article examines representations of Italian literary salons in 1880s print media, focusing on Matilde Serao's dual role as chronicler and attendee. It analyzes her views on fin-de-si\u00e8cle Italian artistic and political landscapes through chronicles of prominent salons in periodicals like Cronaca Bizantina and Corriere di Roma. The study highlights how these representations shaped a collective reading experience and an imagined community of salon participants. Serao's work is also viewed as social critique, addressing mass media expansion, human progress, political decline, and art's growing importance for personal expression.

title: Playground of gender : cross-dressing and self-mutilation as negation of gender identity in Tanja Duckers’s Spielzone (1999)
abstract: Although it is an outstanding example of writing life as negotiation of gender roles as well as exploration of the body as site of identity constructs, Tanja Dückers’s novel Spielzone, published in 1999, has not yet received the critical attention it deserves. The novel displays an interesting aesthetic technique of representing the milieu of two Berlin districts and their inhabitants, whose identity conflicts can be shown to reflect the state of construction of the urban space before its homogenization through gentrification. Especially with regard to gender identities, Dückers portrays the search for a different lifestyle, which is expressed through a striking focus on aesthetic differentiation and cross-dressing. The protagonists stage masculinity and femininity through a theatrical masquerade, which reveals the construct of gender identities and advocates a postmodern transgender existence. The negotiation of a new identity without binary gender attributions ranges from the negation of traditional role assignments to self-mutilation. In the following paper, Dückers’s text will be analysed as uncanny playground of gender between masquerade and brutal gender embodiment, which nevertheless, with all its negations of conventional values, eventually moves near to a return to traditional patterns.peer-reviewe
publisher: University of Malta. Department of English
fieldOfStudy: English Studies, Literary Criticism, Gender Studies
summary: This paper analyzes Tanja Dückers’s 1999 novel “Spielzone” as an exploration of gender roles and identity constructs, arguing it has been critically overlooked despite its significant aesthetic techniques. The study examines how the novel portrays the milieu of two Berlin districts, reflecting urban space construction before gentrification and focusing on gender identities through aesthetic differentiation and cross-dressing. It reveals how protagonists use theatrical masquerade to expose the construct of gender identities, advocating for a postmodern, transgender existence. The analysis discusses the negotiation of new identities, from negating traditional roles to self-mutilation, interpreting the text as an “uncanny playground” that ultimately approaches traditional patterns despite its rejections of conventional values.

title: School Literary Societies--Model Constitution, Rules of Parliamentary Procedure, and Principles of Debating
abstract: "August 22, 1913."Mode of access: Internet
publisher: 'The University of Texas at Austin, Bureau of Economic Geology'
summary: This document, a 1913 bulletin from the University of Texas Extension Series, provides guidance for establishing and running school literary societies. It includes a model constitution and by-laws, rules of parliamentary procedure, and principles of debating, authored by Edwin Dubois Shorter. The publication emphasizes the educational benefits of such societies for developing public speaking, debate skills, and general culture among students, particularly in connection with the University Interscholastic League. It also offers a comprehensive list of questions suitable for debate, covering a wide range of social, political, and educational topics relevant to the early 20th century.

title: Legal Classics: After Deconstructing the Legal Canon
abstract:
The debate over the canon has gripped the University in recent years. Defenders of the canon argue that canonical texts embody timeless and universal themes, but critics argue that the process of canonization subordinates certain people and viewpoints within society in order to assert the existence of a univocal tradition. Originating primarily in the field of literary criticism, the canon debate recently has emerged in legal theory.
Professor Francis J. Mootz argues that the issues raised by the canon debate are relevant to legal scholarship, teaching and practice. After reviewing the extensive commentary on the literary canon, Professor Mootz criticizes the polemical structure of the debate and asserts that an appreciation of classical, as opposed to canonical, texts opens the way for a productive inquiry. He defines a classical text as one that both shapes contemporary concerns and also serves as a point of reference for revising these concerns. Classical texts enable critical perspectives rather than submitting to them, he continues, because they provide the arena for debates about issues of public concern. Using Hadley v. Baxendale as an example of a legal classic, Professor Mootz contends that the power of such a classical text is its ability to shape hotly contested legal debates.
Our time . . . seems unpropitious for thinking about the question of the classic, for . . . it seems to be a simple either/or that requires merely a choosing of sides: for or against? back to the classics or away from them? Our time calls not for thinking but a vote. And it may well be too late for thinking about the classic in any case, for the vote is already in, and the nays have it
summary: This article explores the debate over the canon, which originated in literary criticism and has recently extended to legal theory. Professor Francis J. Mootz argues that appreciating classical texts, rather than strictly canonical ones, fosters productive inquiry. He defines a classical text as one that both shapes contemporary concerns and allows for their revision, serving as an arena for public debate. Using *Hadley v. Baxendale* as an example, Mootz contends that the power of such texts lies in their ability to shape hotly contested legal discussions, moving beyond polemical structures to facilitate ongoing, productive questioning.

title: Power and Limits of a Picture: On the Notion of Thought Experiments in the Philosophy of Literature
fieldOfStudy: English, literary analysis, philosophy of literature
summary: This paper examines the application of thought experiments within the philosophy of literature, contrasting it with philosophical tendencies towards neat, structured reality. It critiques the idea that reality is inherently chaotic and explores how philosophers, particularly in natural sciences, use experiments to discern deep structures. The author suggests that the preference for order also influences the philosophy of literature, potentially limiting its scope. This analysis delves into the nature of philosophical inquiry, scientific method, and their intersection with literary theory, questioning the perceived clarity and structure in philosophical thought.

title: Authorizing Tolkien: Control, Adaptation, and Dissemination of J.R.R. Tolkien\u27s Works
abstract: This article is the introduction to the special theme issue consisting of four essays on Authorizing Tolkien. Reid and Elam discuss medieval and postmodern theories of adaptation and interpretation and introduce the essays in the issue
summary: This article serves as the introduction to a special theme issue titled "Authorizing Tolkien," which comprises four essays exploring control, adaptation, and dissemination of J.R.R. Tolkien's works. Authors Robin A. Reid and Michael D. Elam delve into medieval and postmodern theories of adaptation and interpretation, setting the stage for the subsequent essays. The paper discusses concepts of authorship, authority, and how Tolkien's creations are understood and transformed through various media. Key themes include literary theory, intellectual property, and fan studies within Tolkien scholarship.

title: FIGURATIVE LANGUAGE IN SCORPIONS’SONG WIND OF CHANGE
summary: This final project analyzes the use of figurative language in the Scorpions' song "Wind of Change," focusing on metaphors, similes, personification, and hyperbole to understand how these literary devices contribute to the song's themes of hope and political change during the fall of the Soviet Union. The study aims to identify and interpret the various figures of speech present in the lyrics, providing insights into the song's deeper meaning and its impact as a cultural artifact reflecting historical events. This linguistic analysis contributes to understanding lyrical interpretation and popular music's role in social commentary.

title: Ohrid Literary School in the Period of Tzar Samoil and the Beginnings of the Russian Church Literature
abstract: The article is concerned with the role of St. Clement’s Church in the preservation and the spread of Cyril and Methodius’s literary tradition and Slavic church services. Special emphasis is placed on the work of the Ohrid Literary School in the time of Tsar Samoil and the spread of Slavic literacy from its centers toward Macedonia’s neighboring countries and the Kievan Rus
summary: This article explores the significant role of St. Clement's Church and the Ohrid Literary School, particularly during Tsar Samoil's reign, in preserving and disseminating the Cyrillic and Methodian literary tradition and Slavic church services. It highlights the spread of Slavic literacy from these centers to neighboring countries and Kievan Rus'. The paper discusses the historical context of Slavic literacy's expansion and the potential migration of Macedonian literary scholars to Russia following the fall of Samoil's empire, contributing to early Russian church literature and explaining the discovery of old Macedonian manuscripts abroad. Keywords: St. Clement's Church, Ohrid Literary School, Tsar Samoil, Cyrillic and Methodian tradition, Slavic literacy, Kievan Rus', Russian church literature, Macedonian manuscripts.

title: Mao Chen. Between tradition and change : the hermeneutics of May Fourth literature
abstract: This article reviews the book  Between Tradition and Change: The Hermeneutics of May Fourth Literature , written by Mao Chen
summary: This article reviews Mao Chen's book, "Between Tradition and Change: The Hermeneutics of May Fourth Literature," which re-examines the May Fourth period in Chinese cultural history. Chen employs a hermeneutical and theoretical approach, positioning May Fourth literature at the intersection of tradition and change, past and present. The review discusses Chen's analysis of authors like Hu Shi and his perceived connections to feminism. While acknowledging the book's comparative and theory-heavy nature, the reviewer suggests improvements such as including Chinese characters, an index, and more robust arguments, particularly regarding "Chinese feminism" and non-canonical texts. The book's process-oriented treatment of May Fourth literature and its focus on the fusion of writer and reader offer potential avenues for future studies.

title: 'Things are never fixed, finally formed and closed': Alan Riach on Scotland's literature media
abstract: No abstract available
summary: This paper by Alan Riach explores the evolving landscape of Scottish literature and media, examining the historical role of newspapers and magazines in nourishing literary and political culture, from early 19th-century rivals like "Blackwood's Magazine" and "Edinburgh Review" to 20th-century publications. Riach discusses the shift towards new media, highlighting the importance of balancing immediate online content with incisive, reflective thought from essayists and critics. He emphasizes the dynamic, open nature of Scottish literature, contrasting it with fixed forms and arguing for the necessity of critical engagement with new technologies and their impact on arts and education. Keywords: Scottish literature, media, literary journalism, new media, cultural criticism, Alan Riach, Edwin Morgan, Ali Smith.

title: The aesthetics of ambiguity
summary: This document comprises the proceedings of the XII National Congress of the Spanish Association of Anglo-American Studies, held in Alicante in 1988. It features conferences and communications covering various topics in English and American literature and linguistics. Key themes include discourse and focalization, historical criticism, race in American literature, modernization of Gaelic literature, defining the American literary canon, text linguistics, new trends in British fiction, feminist readings of Victorian narratives, contemporary American novel between Post-Modernism and Neo-Realism, British English dialectology, feminist dystopias, Thatcherite women in drama, pragmatics in linguistic analysis, standardization of Creole languages, Chicana literature, and rhythm in poetry. Modernist literature and the aesthetics of ambiguity are also explored, emphasizing the orchestration of human consciousness and the proliferation versus suppression of meanings.

title: Suspicious minds : the dramatisation of paranoia in Victorian poetry : a thesis presented in partial fulfilment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Arts in English at Massey University
abstract: This thesis contains readings of a number of Victorian poems by Alfred Tennyson, Robert Browning and Dante Gabriel Rossetti which dramatise paranoia and jealousy. A range of twentieth-century theories of paranoia (including clinical, Freudian and Lacanian) have been used as explanatory tools for interpreting the representations of paranoia in the poems. The reading of Tennyson's Maud is based on Freud's theory of homoerotic motives. The reading of Browning's "'Childe Roland to the Dark Tower Came'" is based on the Lacanian concepts of foreclosure and the Name-of-the-Father. The readings of the jealousy poems are based on both theories, and this section includes a discussion of the limitations of the theories as explanatory tools. The general approach has been to apply clinical and psychoanalytical constructs and explanations to each poem separately, although there is some discussion involving the comparison of paranoid behaviours and motives across all the poems. Areas for further research are suggested in the concluding chapter
fieldOfStudy: English Literature, Victorian Poetry, Psychoanalytic Theory
summary: This thesis explores the dramatization of paranoia and jealousy in Victorian poems by Alfred Tennyson, Robert Browning, and Dante Gabriel Rossetti. It applies twentieth-century theories of paranoia, including clinical, Freudian, and Lacanian perspectives, as interpretative tools. Specifically, Tennyson's 'Maud' is analyzed through Freud's theory of homoerotic motives, while Browning's "'Childe Roland to the Dark Tower Came'" is examined using Lacanian concepts of foreclosure and the Name-of-the-Father. The study also discusses the limitations of these theories and compares paranoid behaviors across the poems, suggesting areas for further research in literary analysis and psychoanalytic literary criticism.

title: Beyond cultural and national identities : current re-evaluation of the Kominka literature from Taiwan\u27s Japanese period
abstract: This paper is an offshoot of a larger, ongoing project that intends to deal with the relationship between various artistic formations and the dominant culture in Taiwan\u27s post-1949 era. Though the lifting of martial law in 1987 has demarcated this era into two drastically different periods and a clearer contour of the new period seems to be just beginning to emerge in the mid-1990s, various cultural forces are still busily negotiating with each other. Nonetheless, there seems to be a general consensus as to what constitutes a core of the new dominant culture: the spirit of pen-t\u27u, or a nativist imperative that obliges one to treat Taiwan as the  center  in one\u27s cultural mapping. The primary driving force for this recent reconstitution of Taiwan\u27s dominant culture undoubtedly came from the momentous changes in the political arena in the post-martial law period. This rather crude factor, however, should not obscure our vision of the longer, more far-reaching evolutionary process of cultural change in contemporary Taiwan. Simply put, since the early 1980s, the older cultural hegemony has been seriously contested by forces coming from the Taiwanese cultural nationalism advocated in a vibrant pen-t\u27u (nativization) trend on the one hand, and from various radical cultural formations on the other. Limited by space, this paper will only deal with specific aspects of the nativization trend, with the main paradigm taken from the literary field. The paper will begin with a brief overview of the indigenous literary discourse in Taiwan’s post-1949 era, followed by analyses of recent scholarly re- evaluations of the Kominka literature from Taiwan’s Japanese period. Through this investigation, I hope to reach a better understanding of some important issues pertaining to contemporary cultural transformation in Taiwan, such as the role of cultural nationalism, the problem of identity construction, and efforts toward institutionalizing Taiwanese literary studies as an academic discipline
fieldOfStudy: Literary Studies, Cultural Studies, Taiwanese History
summary: This paper investigates the evolving relationship between artistic formations and dominant culture in post-1949 Taiwan, particularly focusing on the nativist imperative (pen-t'u) that emerged after the lifting of martial law in 1987. It examines how Taiwanese cultural nationalism has challenged older cultural hegemonies since the early 1980s. Drawing primarily from the literary field, the study provides an overview of indigenous literary discourse and analyzes recent re-evaluations of Kominka literature from Taiwan's Japanese colonial period. The aim is to understand contemporary cultural transformation, the role of cultural nationalism, identity construction, and the institutionalization of Taiwanese literary studies.

title: Three Books on the Scottish Sixties
abstract: Discusses three recent books about Scottish culture in the 1960s: a collection of documents and interviews, The International Writers\u27 Conference Revisited, ed. Bartie and Bell; a collection of essays, The Scottish Sixties, ed. Bell and Gunn; and a monograph, The Edinburgh Festivals, by Angela Bartie
summary: This article reviews three recent books examining Scottish culture in the 1960s: "The International Writers' Conference Revisited," edited by Bartie and Bell; "The Scottish Sixties," edited by Bell and Gunn; and "The Edinburgh Festivals," by Angela Bartie. The review critically analyzes how these works portray the "Scottish Sixties" as a complex cultural phenomenon, distinguishing it from the chronological decade and highlighting conflicts between various forces. It also explores the re-evaluation of 'Scottishness' in literary culture and the internationalist spirit influencing post-1960s Scottish art. Keywords include Scottish literature, cultural history, 1960s, Edinburgh Festivals, and literary criticism.

title: From One Dialogue to Another: Johannine Polyvalence from Origins to Receptions
abstract: Throughout the ages, one of the primary mistakes committed in studying the Gospel of John has been to read the text monologically instead of dialogically. This error has often led some readers of the Fourth Gospel to “get it wrong,” needing correction by later interpreters. Put otherwise, many an ecumenical council or more nuanced interpretation has restored the tension that had been lost by interpreters who had sided with one aspect of John’s witness without considering another. Likewise, one flaw of modern literary-critical theories is that they have often sought to ascribe the sources of the Fourth Gospel’s theological tensions to sets of imagined literary poles, failing to consider the possibility that the origin of those tensions was been integral to the thinking and style of the Evangelist. John’s material developed dialogically, and it must be read dialogically if its epistemological origin, developmental character, and rhetorical design are to be adequately understood. Indeed, there are different levels and types of dialogical operation underlying the Johannine text—from origins to receptions—and these involve theological, historical, and literary factors that require a polyvalent approach to Johannine interpretation
fieldOfStudy: English, Literary Analysis, Christianity, Biblical Studies
summary: This paper argues that studying the Gospel of John requires a dialogical approach, rather than a monological one, to properly understand its epistemological origin, developmental character, and rhetorical design. Past interpretations have often failed by taking one-sided views or attributing theological tensions to imagined literary poles, rather than acknowledging them as integral to the Evangelist's style. The author proposes that the Johannine text operates on multiple dialogical levels, encompassing theological, historical, and literary factors. This necessitates a polyvalent approach to interpretation, inviting readers to engage in the ongoing making of meaning, challenging certainties, and embracing the liberating promise found within its narratives.

title: Ghost talk in 1936 :  living ghosts  and  real ghosts  in Republican-Era literary discourse and the two Analects Fortnightly ghost-story special issues = 說鬼1936 : 民國文學話語中的「活鬼」與「真鬼」及《論語半月刊》的兩個鬼故事專號
summary: This article examines the discourse surrounding "living ghosts" and "real ghosts" in Republican-Era Chinese literary discourse, specifically focusing on two special ghost-story issues of the Analects Fortnightly from 1936. It explores how these spectral figures were used as vehicles for self-expression and cultural critique, challenging conventional understandings of ghostly narratives. The analysis delves into the works of various writers, including Shao Xunmei and Lu Xun, and traces the evolution of phantom heroines in 20th-century Chinese cultural politics, highlighting their significance in narratives of modernization. Key concepts include Republican-Era literature, ghost stories, cultural critique, and Chinese modernization.

title: Schemata
abstract: No abstract available
fieldOfStudy: English, Cognitive Science, Narrative Theory, Stylistics
summary: This document defines schemata as cognitive structures representing generic knowledge, not specific instances, but rather general forms. Readers utilize schemata to comprehend events and descriptions by supplying default background information, compensating for omitted details in texts. As schemata form an individual's knowledge base, they are crucial for understanding discourse. This work explores schema theory within narrative studies and its applications, particularly in stylistics, text analysis, and cognitive science. The research was supported by the Arts and Humanities Research Council as part of the STACS Project, focusing on interdisciplinary perspectives on reading.

title: Teaching Students How to Write : The Literary Essay in a Learning Society.
summary: This text discusses the challenges students face in academic writing, specifically the literary essay, within higher education. It highlights a common sentiment among educators regarding students' lack of basic writing competencies, such as grammar and structure. The piece implicitly advocates for methods to improve student writing, emphasizing the importance of adaptability, autonomy, and communicative ability gained through studies in English. It suggests that English studies foster creative, motivated reflection and contribute to students' self-realization through essay production, making it crucial for developing essential academic skills.

summary: This review analyzes two books, "Reading for the Law: British Literary History and Gender Advocacy" by Christine L. Krueger and "Law, Literature, and the Transmission of Culture in England, 1837-1925" by Cathrine O. Frank, within the interdisciplinary field of law and literature. It highlights their contributions to understanding Victorian culture, particularly how imaginative writers engaged with legal developments. Krueger's work explores the efficacy of storytelling for social justice, while Frank's examines ownership, selfhood, and the evolving relationship between law and literature, including insightful readings of inheritance plots and legal developments, though her book could benefit from a narrower focus. Both books offer sophisticated models of the legal-literary nexus and the role of subjectivity in 19th-century legal culture.

title: The Relationship Between Ethics and Literature in Light of Levinas’s Work
abstract:
In my paper I intend to uncover the relationship between ethics and
literature. The aforementioned issue is connected to ’ethical turn’ —
new orientation in literary studies, which was introduced in the
nineties of 20th century. In order to uncover its source of inspiration, I
refer to Lévinas’s works, such as Reality and its Shadow, The poet’s
vision, Totality and Infinity, Otherwise than Being. I advocate the view
that not only Lévinas’s concept of language, but also his account of
poetry and responsibility underlie ethical criticism. Therefore, they are
regarded as crucial to understand this new approach to literary studies.
To illustrate my thesis, I attempt to interpret literary works, i.e.
Wordsworth’s and Coetzee’s in light of Lévinas’s concepts.Numer został przygotowany przy wsparciu Ministerstwa Nauki i Szkolnictwa Wyższego
summary: This paper explores the relationship between ethics and literature, specifically examining the 'ethical turn' in literary studies from the 1990s. Drawing inspiration from Emmanuel Lévinas's works, including *Reality and its Shadow*, *The poet's vision*, *Totality and Infinity*, and *Otherwise than Being*, the author argues that Lévinas's concepts of language, poetry, and responsibility are fundamental to ethical criticism. The study analyzes literary works by Wordsworth and Coetzee through Lévinas's framework to illustrate this thesis, highlighting the importance of the reader's responsibility and the ethical significance of narrative form. Key concepts include ethical criticism, Lévinas, poetry, responsibility, and language.

The issue contains articles discussing the avant-garde's relationship with war, examining figures like Alfred Jarry, Guillaume Apollinaire, Gertrude Stein, and Muriel Rukeyser, and includes reviews of related modernist and surrealist scholarship. Key themes include modernism, avant-garde, literature, war, and criticism.

summary: This document presents book reviews for several literary works, focusing primarily on "The Sacred River: Coleridge's Theory of the Imagination" by James V. Baker. The review highlights Baker's in-depth analysis of Coleridge's aesthetics, emphasizing imagination as organic, reconciling opposites, and developing unconsciously. It praises Baker's comprehensive approach, integrating Romantic, earlier period, German, English, and classical thinkers like Plato and Aristotle. The document also critically reviews "Literary Reviews and Essays" by Henry James, edited by Albert Mordell, criticizing Mordell's clumsy writing and misinterpretations of James's literary criticism and political views. Keywords: Coleridge, imagination, aesthetics, Romanticism, literary criticism, Henry James.

The index also includes reviews of numerous books on diverse literary topics, from Shakespearean tragedies to Victorian novels and modern American literature.

title: Former Presidents: Pensions, Office Allowances, and Other Federal Benefits
abstract:
[Excerpt] The Former Presidents Act (FPA; 3 U.S.C. § 102 note) charges the General Services Administration (GSA) with providing former Presidents a pension, support staff, office support, travel funds, and mailing privileges. The FPA was enacted to “maintain the dignity” of the Office of the President by giving a former President — and his or her spouse — certain benefits so that he would not have to enter unsuitable occupations after leaving office. Former Presidents currently receive a pension that is equal to pay for the head of an executive department (Executive Level I), which was $191,300 as of January 1, 2008.
The FY2008 Consolidated Appropriations Act allocated $2,478,000 for pensions and GSA assistance to former Presidents. The President’s FY2009 budget requested $2,934,000 for expenditures for former Presidents. Pending House and Senate appropriations legislation recommends the requested amount.
Prior to 1958, former Presidents leaving office received no pension or federal assistance. After leaving office, some former Presidents — including Ulysses S. Grant and Harry S Truman — struggled financially. In 1912, industrialist and philanthropist Andrew Carnegie unveiled a plan to pay $25,000 pensions to all future former Presidents and their widows. The pensions were to be funded by the Carnegie Foundation of New York. Some Members of Congress and the public suggested it was inappropriate for a private company to pay pensions to former Presidents. Legislation was introduced that year to grant public pensions to former Presidents, but none of the bills were reported from committee. William Howard Taft, the only former President who was then eligible for Carnegie’s offer, refused the pension.
Since 1962, the U.S. Secret Service has provided protection to former Presidents because of their status as “visible national symbol[s].” Protection has subsequently been expanded to cover a former President’s wife until death or remarriage. Minor children of former Presidents who are under 16 years of age also receive protection. In 1994, the law was amended to limit U.S. Secret Service coverage to 10 years for any President, and his spouse, who left office after January 1, 1997. President George W. Bush will be the first former President affected by this statutory change.
In the 110th Congress, Representative John Conyers introduced a bill (H.R. 5938) that would extend U.S. Secret Service Protection to a Vice President, his or her spouse, and family for up to six months after leaving office. Currently, Secret Service protection for a Vice President and his or her family is provided on an ad hoc basis.
This report describes the benefits Presidents receive upon leaving office, details the history of the FPA, and analyzes some legislative options for the 110th Congress related to former Presidents
summary: This report examines the Former Presidents Act (FPA), which mandates the General Services Administration (GSA) to provide former Presidents with a pension, support staff, office support, travel funds, and mailing privileges to maintain the dignity of the office. It details the history of these benefits, noting the financial struggles of some former presidents before the FPA's enactment in 1958 and the subsequent expansion of Secret Service protection. The document also analyzes legislative options considered by the 110th Congress, including potential modifications to Secret Service protection durations and clarifying laws governing office allowances to address varying costs.
